बलस्य मुख्यामः च सुहृज् जनम् च || २-८२-३१_END
BEGIN_
Sumantra, having received that explicit command from Bharata, which fulfilled his
highest hopes, called all the ministers-in-chief, the chiefs of the army and the friendly
multitude._END

B_2_C_82_31
BEGIN_
ततः समुत्थाय कुले कुले ते |
राजन्य वैश्या वृषलाः च विप्राः |
अयूयुजन्न् उष्ट्र रथान् खरामः च|
नागान् हयामः चैव कुल प्रसूतान् || २-८२-३२_END
BEGIN_
Thereupon, from every house, warriors merchants, Shudras and Brahmanas rose up and
harnessed their chariots to camels, mules, well-bred elephants and horses._END

B_2_C_83_0
BEGIN_
ततः समुत्थितः काल्यम् आस्थाय स्यन्दन उत्तमम् |
प्रययौ भरतः शीघ्रम् राम दर्शन कान्क्षया || २-८३-१_END
BEGIN_
Bharata rose up at day-break, mounted on excellent chariot and went quickly with a
desire to see Rama._END

B_2_C_83_1
BEGIN_
अग्रतः प्रययुस् तस्य सर्वे मन्त्रि पुरोधसः |
अधिरुह्य हयैः युक्तान् रथान् सूर्य रथ उपमान् || २-८३-२_END
BEGIN_
All the ministers and priests ascended, chariots yoked with horses, resembling those
of the sun, and went ahead of Bharata._END

B_2_C_83_2
BEGIN_
नव नाग सहस्राणि कल्पितानि यथा विधि |
अन्वयुर् भरतम् यान्तम् इक्ष्वाकु कुल नन्दनम् || २-८३-३_END
BEGIN_
Nine thousand elephants suitably duly arranged escorted Bharata the joy of the
Ikshvaku dynasty, on his journey._END

B_2_C_83_3
BEGIN_
षष्ठी रथ सहस्राणि धन्विनो विविध आयुधाः |
अन्वयुर् भरतम् यान्तम् राज पुत्रम् यशस्विनम् || २-८३-४_END
BEGIN_
Sixty thousand chariots filled with archers, furnished with weapons of various
kinds, followed the illustrious prince Bharata._END

B_2_C_83_4
BEGIN_
शतम् सहस्राणि अश्वानाम् समारूढानि राघवम् |
अन्वयुर् भरतम् यान्तम् राज पुत्रम् यशस्विनम् || २-८३-५_END
BEGIN_
A hundred thousand cavalry accompanied the moving Bharata, born in Raghu dynasty,
who was true to his promise and who subdued his senses._END

B_2_C_83_5
BEGIN_
कैकेयी च सुमित्रा च कौसल्या च यशस्विनी |
राम आनयन सम्हृष्टा ययुर् यानेन भास्वता || २-८३-६_END
BEGIN_
Kaikeyi, Sumitra and the illustrious Kausalya rode in a resplendent chariot,
delighted as they were at the thought of Rama's return._END

B_2_C_83_6
BEGIN_
प्रयाताः च आर्य सम्घाता रामम् द्रष्टुम् सलक्ष्मणम् |
तस्य एव च कथाः चित्राः कुर्वाणा हृष्ट मानसाः || २-८३-७_END
BEGIN_
The whole body of noble men with their jubiliant hearts followed Bharata to see Rama
again as also Lakshmana, recounting the marvelous exploits of that hero to each other saying:_END

B_2_C_83_7
BEGIN_
मेघ श्यामम् महा बाहुम् स्थिर सत्त्वम् दृढ व्रतम् |
कदा द्रक्ष्यामहे रामम् जगतः शोक नाशनम् || २-८३-८_END
BEGIN_
"When shall we see the mighty armed prince, of the hue of dark cloud, whose courage
is unshakable, of inflexible purpose Rama, who banished sorrow from the earth?"_END

B_2_C_83_8
BEGIN_
दृष्टएव हि नः शोकम् अपनेष्यति राघवः |
तमः सर्वस्य लोकस्य समुद्यन्न् इव भास्करः || २-८३-९_END
BEGIN_
"Beholding Rama, our entire sorrow will indeed be dispelled, as darkness of the
entire earth is dispelled at the rising of the sun."_END

B_2_C_83_9
BEGIN_
इति एवम् कथयन्तः ते सम्प्रहृष्टाः कथाः शुभाः |
परिष्वजानाः च अन्योन्यम् ययुर् नागरिकाः तदा || २-८३-१०_END
BEGIN_
Thus did the citizens of Ayodhya recount happily of Rama's glorious deeds, and they
embraced each other as they went along._END

B_2_C_83_10
BEGIN_
ये च तत्र अपरे सर्वे सम्मता ये च नैगमाः |
रामम् प्रति ययुर् हृष्टाः सर्वाः प्रकृतयः तदा || २-८३-११_END
BEGIN_
Those others who were held in high esteem, merchants and all common people proceeded
merrily to join Rama._END

B_2_C_83_11
BEGIN_
मणि काराः च ये केचित् कुम्भ काराः च शोभनाः |
सूत्र कर्म कृतः चैव ये च शस्त्र उपजीविनः || २-८३-१२
मायूरकाः क्राकचिका रोचका वेधकाः तथा |
दन्त काराः सुधा काराः तथा गन्ध उपजीविनः || २-८३-१३
सुवर्ण काराः प्रख्याताः तथा कम्बल धावकाः |
स्नापक आच्चादका वैद्या धूपकाः शौण्डिकाः तथा || २-८३-१४
रजकाः तुन्न वायाः च ग्राम घोष महत्तराः |
शैलूषाः च सह स्त्रीभिर् यान्ति कैवर्तकाः तथा || २-८३-१५_END
BEGIN_
Some lapidaries, skilled potters, those who lived by manufacture of arms,
carpenters, those who made various articles from peacock-feather, sawyers, workers in artificial
ornaments, those who pierced gems, pearls etc, those who made articles of ivory, those who lived by
perfumery, highly reputed goldsmiths, weavers of blankets and other wollen goods, those who
provided hot-water baths for other, physicians, distillers and vendors of spirituous liquors,
fumigators, washer-men, tailors, chiefs of villages and hamlets, dancers with their women-folk and
fishermen started on the journey._END

B_2_C_83_12
BEGIN_
समाहिता वेदविदो ब्राह्मणा वृत्त सम्मताः |
गो रथैः भरतम् यान्तम् अनुजग्मुः सहस्रशः || २-८३-१६_END
BEGIN_
Thousands of Brahmanas, well-composed, renowned for their virtuous conduct, versed
in sacred scriptures and riding on bullock-carts, accompanied Bharata._END

B_2_C_83_13
BEGIN_
सुवेषाः शुद्ध वसनाः ताम्र मृष्ट अनुलेपनाः |
सर्वे ते विविधैः यानैः शनैः भरतम् अन्वयुः || २-८३-१७_END
BEGIN_
All of them, attired in clean and fair raiment, anointed with pure red sandal-paste,
mounted on various kinds of vehicles, followed Bharata tranquilly._END

B_2_C_83_14
BEGIN_
प्रहृष्ट मुदिता सेना सान्वयात् कैकयी सुतम् |
भ्रातुरानयने यान्तम् भरतम् भ्रातृवत्सलम् || २-८३-१८_END
BEGIN_
Exceedingly pleased and cheerful, that army escorted the son of Kaikeyi- Bharta who
was affectionate towards his brother and who had set out along with his family to bring his
brother, Rama._END

B_2_C_83_15
BEGIN_
ते गत्वा दूरमध्वानम् रथम् यानाश्वकुञ्जरैः |
समासेदुस्ततो गङ्गाम् शृङ्गिबेरपुरम् प्रति || २-८३-१९
यत्र रामसखो वीरो गुहो ज्ञातिगणैर्वृतः |
निवसत्यप्रमादेन देशम् तम् परिपालयन् || २-८३-२०_END
BEGIN_
Having gone for a considerable distance in their chariots, carts, horses and
elephants, they reached the River Ganga close to the city of Shringaberapura, where the valiant
Guha, a bosom friend of Rama along with multitude of relatives was ruling that region
carefully._END

B_2_C_83_16
BEGIN_
उपेत्य तीरम् गङ्गायाश्चक्रमाकैरलङ्कतम् |
व्यवतिष्ठत सा सेना भरतस्य अनुयायिनी || २-८३-२१_END
BEGIN_
That army, which was accompanying Bharata, arrived at the bank of Ganga River,
looking beautiful as it was with Charka* birds and stopped there._END

B_2_C_83_17
BEGIN_
निरीक्ष्य अनुगताम् सेनाम् ताम् च गन्गाम् शिव उदकाम् |
भरतः सचिवान् सर्वान् अब्रवीद् वाक्य कोविदः || २-८३-२२_END
BEGIN_
Seeing the army behind, which accompanied him and the River Ganga in front with its
propitious waters, Bharata who was skillful in words, spoke to all his officers (as follows):_END

B_2_C_83_18
BEGIN_
निवेशयत मे सैन्यम् अभिप्रायेण सर्वशः |
विश्रान्तः प्रतरिष्यामः श्वैदानीम् महा नदीम् || २-८३-२३_END
BEGIN_
"It is my will that my army should take rest by all means. When they are refreshed
we shall cross the river tomorrow."_END

B_2_C_83_19
BEGIN_
दातुम् च तावद् इच्चामि स्वर् गतस्य मही पतेः |
और्ध्वदेह निमित्त अर्थम् अवतीर्य उदकम् नदीम् || २-८३-२४_END
BEGIN_
"Meanwhile, descending into the river, I desire to make offering of the sacred water
as libation for the infinite spirit relating to the state after death, to the king Dasaratha who
has gone to heaven."_END

B_2_C_83_20
BEGIN_
तस्य एवम् ब्रुवतः अमात्याः तथा इति उक्त्वा समाहिताः |
न्यवेशयंस् तामः चन्देन स्वेन स्वेन पृथक् पृथक् || २-८३-२५_END
BEGIN_
Hearing these words from Bharata, the officers attentively answered, "Be it so" and
each of them encamped their respective forces in accord with his pleasure._END

B_2_C_83_21
BEGIN_
निवेश्य गन्गाम् अनु ताम् महा नदीम् |
चमूम् विधानैः परिबर्ह शोभिनीम् |
उवास रामस्य तदा महात्मनो |
विचिन्तयानो भरतः निवर्तनम् || २-८३-२६_END
BEGIN_
Having meticulously arranged for encampment of the army which looked lovely along
Ganga that great river with the surrounding equipment (like tunts, furnishings etc), Bharata halted
then, reflecting as to how to bring back the magnanimous Rama._END

B_2_C_84_0
BEGIN_
ततः निविष्टाम् ध्वजिनीम् गन्गाम् अन्वाश्रिताम् नदीम् |
निषाद राजो दृष्ट्वा एव ज्ञातीन् सम्त्वरितः अब्रवीत् || २-८४-१_END
BEGIN_
Just on seeing an army encamped and positioned along the River Ganga, Guha the king
of Nishadas hastily spoke to his relatives as follows:_END

B_2_C_84_1
BEGIN_
महती इयम् अतः सेना सागर आभा प्रदृश्यते |
न अस्य अन्तम् अवगच्चामि मनसा अपि विचिन्तयन् || २-८४-२_END
BEGIN_
"On this side, a huge army is seen like an ocean. I am not able to comprehend the
extent of this army even by my discerning mind."_END

B_2_C_84_2
BEGIN_
यथा तु खलु दुर्भद्धिर्भरतः स्वयमागतः |
स एष हि महा कायः कोविदार ध्वजो रथे || २-८४-३_END
BEGIN_
"Here is seen on that chariot, a towering banner bearing Kovidara tree and hence
Bharata himself with an evil intent seems to have come."_END

B_2_C_84_3
BEGIN_
बन्धयिष्यति वा दाशान् अथ वा अस्मान् वधिष्यति |
अथ दाशरथिम् रामम् पित्रा राज्यात् विवासितम् || २-८४-४
सम्पन्नाम् श्रियमन्विच्चंस्तस्य राज्ञः सुदुर्लभाम् |
भरतः कैकेयी पुत्रः हन्तुम् समधिगच्चति || २-८४-५_END
BEGIN_
"Will Bharata the son of Kaikeyi bind us with chains or slay us? Or is he coming to
kill Rama, the son of Dasaratha, who was exiled from the kingdom by his father, desirous as Bharata
is to get the prosperous Ayodhya kingdom, a luxury and that which is inaccessible to another?"_END

B_2_C_84_4
BEGIN_
भर्ता चैव सखा चैव रामः दाशरथिर् मम |
तस्य अर्थ कामाः सम्नद्धा गन्गा अनूपे अत्र तिष्ठत || २-८४-६_END
BEGIN_
"Rama the son of Dasaratha is my Lord and my companion too. Hence you, covered with
armor, be stationed on this bank of Ganga River, desiring to advance the interest of Rama."_END

B_2_C_84_5
BEGIN_
तिष्ठन्तु सर्व दाशाः च गन्गाम् अन्वाश्रिता नदीम् |
बल युक्ता नदी रक्षा मांस मूल फल अशनाः || २-८४-७_END
BEGIN_
"Let all our ferrymen guarding the river, along with the troops, eating meat roots
and fruits ( in their boats), stay positioned along the River Ganga."_END

B_2_C_84_6
BEGIN_
नावाम् शतानाम् पन्चानाम् कैवर्तानाम् शतम् शतम् |
सम्नद्धानाम् तथा यूनाम् तिष्ठन्तु अत्यभ्यचोदयत् || २-८४-८_END
BEGIN_
"Let five hundred boats, each manner by a hundred youthful ferrymen, be stationed
and made ready" -thus announced Guha._END

B_2_C_84_7
BEGIN_
यदा तुष्टः तु भरतः रामस्य इह भविष्यति |
सा इयम् स्वस्तिमयी सेना गन्गाम् अद्य तरिष्यति || २-८४-९_END
BEGIN_
"If Bharata is favourably disposed now towards Rama, then only his army may (be
allowed to) cross the River Ganga in safety."_END

B_2_C_84_8
BEGIN_
इति उक्त्वा उपायनम् गृह्य मत्स्य मांस मधूनि च |
अभिचक्राम भरतम् निषाद अधिपतिर् गुहः || २-८४-१०_END
BEGIN_
After uttering thus, Guha the king of Nishadas took fish, meat and honey as an
offering and approached Bharata._END

B_2_C_84_9
BEGIN_
तम् आयान्तम् तु सम्प्रेक्ष्य सूत पुत्रः प्रतापवान् |
भरताय आचचक्षे अथ विनयज्ञो विनीतवत् || २-८४-११_END
BEGIN_
Seeing him approach, Sumantra the charioteer, a majestic man who knows the rules of
discipline, humbly told Bharata as follows:_END

B_2_C_84_10
BEGIN_
एष ज्ञाति सहस्रेण स्थपतिः परिवारितः |
कुशलो दण्डक अरण्ये वृद्धो भ्रातुः च ते सखा || २-८४-१२_END
BEGIN_
"This Lord who is surrounded by a thousand of his own people, is fully acquainted
with the forest of Dandaka and also an old friend of your elder brother."_END

B_2_C_84_11
BEGIN_
तस्मात् पश्यतु काकुत्स्थ त्वाम् निषाद अधिपो गुहः |
असंशयम् विजानीते यत्र तौ राम लक्ष्मणौ || २-८४-१३_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata! For that reason, let Guha the king of Nishadas see you. He knows surely
where those two Rama and Lakshmana - are stationed."_END

B_2_C_84_12
BEGIN_
एतत् तु वचनम् श्रुत्वा सुमन्त्रात् भरतः शुभम् |
उवाच वचनम् शीघ्रम् गुहः पश्यतु माम् इति || २-८४-१४_END
BEGIN_
Hearing the auspicious words of Sumantra, Bharata answered, "Introduce Guha to me
without delay."_END

B_2_C_84_13
BEGIN_
लब्ध्वा अभ्यनुज्ञाम् सम्हृष्टः ज्ञातिभिः परिवारितः |
आगम्य भरतम् प्रह्वो गुहो वचनम् अब्रवीइत् || २-८४-१५_END
BEGIN_
Having obtained permission, Guha along with his own people, joyfully and humbly
approached Bharata and spoke as follows:_END

B_2_C_84_14
BEGIN_
निष्कुटः चैव देशो अयम् वन्चिताः च अपि ते वयम् |
निवेदयामः ते सर्वे स्वके दाश कुले वस || २-८४-१६_END
BEGIN_
"This place is like a pleasure-grove near your house. We are your subjects and are
reporting to you as such. Stay in this servant's house."_END

B_2_C_84_15
BEGIN_
अस्ति मूलम् फलम् चैव निषादैः समुपाहृतम् |
आर्द्रम् च मांसम् शुष्कम् च वन्यम् च उच्च अवचम् महत् || २-८४-१७_END
BEGIN_
"Here are the roots and fruits gathered by my tribe as well as fresh and dried meat
of great quality and of various kinds, and all a produce of the forest."_END

B_2_C_84_16
BEGIN_
आशंसे स्वाशिता सेना वत्स्यति इमाम् विभावरीम् |
अर्चितः विविधैः कामैः श्वः ससैन्यो गमिष्यसि || २-८४-१८_END
BEGIN_
"I hope the army, after eating well, can halt for the night here. Furnished with all
you could desire, you can continue your journey tomorrow along with your troops."_END

B_2_C_85_0
BEGIN_एवमुक्तस्तु भरतो निषादाधिपतिं गुहम् ।
प्रत्युवाच महाप्राज्ञो वाक्यं हेत्वर्थसंहितम् ॥ २-८५-१_END
BEGIN_Hearing those words, the highly intelligent Bharata replied toGuha, the lord of Nishadas, 
in words that were full of reason and meaning._END

B_2_C_85_1
BEGIN_ऊर्जितः खलु ते कामः कृतःमम गुरोह् सखे।
यो मे त्वम् ईदृशीम् सेनाम् एको अभ्यर्चितुम् इच्चसि॥ २-८५-२_END
BEGIN_?O, friend of my elder brother! Indeed, your desire to offerhospitality to my army of 
such a magnitude, is great.?_END

B_2_C_85_2
BEGIN_इति उक्त्वा तु महा तेजा गुहम्वचनम् उत्तमम्।
अब्रवीद् भरतः श्रीमान् निषाद अधिपतिम् पुनः॥ २-८५-३_END
BEGIN_Having spoken these excellent words to Guha; the greatlyillustrious Bharata, possessed 
of great splendor, said again to Guha the kingof Nishadas (as follows):_END

B_2_C_85_3
BEGIN_कतरेण गमिष्यामि भरद्वाजाश्रमम् गुह।
गहनो अयम् भृशम् देशो गङ्गा अनूपो दुरत्ययः॥ २-८५-४_END
BEGIN_?O, Guha! By which of these two routes can I go to the hermitageof Bharadvaja? This region 
engulfed in waters of Ganga River is not very much easy to negotiate and is difficult to cross.?_END

B_2_C_85_4
BEGIN_तस्य तत् वचनम् श्रुत्वा राजपुत्रस्य धीमतः।
अब्रवीत् प्रान्जलिर् वाक्यम् गुहो गहन गोचरः॥ २-८५-५_END
BEGIN_Hearing the words of the wise prince; Guha, who roams about inwoods, with joined palms 
answered as follows:_END

B_2_C_85_5
BEGIN_दाशाः तु अनुगमिष्यन्तिधन्विनः सुसमाहिताः।
अहम् च अनुगमिष्यामि राज पुत्र महा यशः॥ २-८५-६_END
BEGIN_?O highly illustrious prince! My ferrymen wielding their bows,and very attentive, will 
certainly accompany you. I too will follow you (inperson).?_END

B_2_C_85_6
BEGIN_कच्चिन् न दुष्टः व्रजसि रामस्याक्लिष्ट कर्मणः।
इयम् ते महती सेना शन्काम् जनयति इव मे॥ २-८५-७_END
BEGIN_?I hope you are not going to attack Rama, who is unwearied inaction. This great army 
of yours is begetting an apprehension in my mind.?_END

B_2_C_85_7
BEGIN_तम् एवम् अभिभाषन्तमाकाशैव निर्मलः।
भरतः श्लक्ष्णया वाचा गुहम् वचनम् अब्रवीत्॥ २-८५-८_END
BEGIN_Bharata, whose heart resembled a taintless sky, spoke thefollowing words in smooth voice, 
to that Guha, who confessed his doubt asaforesaid._END

B_2_C_85_8
BEGIN_मा भूत् स कालो यत् कष्टम् नमाम् शन्कितुम् अर्हसि।
राघवः स हि मे भ्राता ज्येष्ठः पितृ समः मम॥ २-८५-९_END
BEGIN_?Let not such an occasion of wretchedness come! You should neverhave suspected me. That 
Rama my elder brother is indeed regarded as my father.?_END

B_2_C_85_9
BEGIN_तम् निवर्तयितुम् यामि काकुत्स्थम्वन वासिनम्।
बुद्धिर् अन्या न ते कार्या गुह सत्यम् ब्रवीमि ते॥ २-८५-१०_END
BEGIN_?I am going to get back Rama who is now living in the forest. O,Guha! No other apprehension 
should be made by you. I am telling you the truth.?_END

B_2_C_85_10
BEGIN_स तु सम्हृष्ट वदनः श्रुत्वाभरत भाषितम्।
पुनर् एव अब्रवीद् वाक्यम् भरतम् प्रति हर्षितः॥ २-८५-११_END
BEGIN_Hearing the words of Bharata, Guha on his part, with his faceradiated with joy spoke 
again to Bharata as follows:_END

B_2_C_85_11
BEGIN_धन्यः त्वम् न त्वया तुल्यंपश्यामि जगती तले।
अयत्नात् आगतम् राज्यम् यः त्वम् त्यक्तुम् इह इच्चसि॥ २-८५-१२_END
BEGIN_?You be blessed! I do not see your equal on this earth - you, whowish to renounce the 
empire you acquired now, even without effort.?_END

B_2_C_85_12
BEGIN_शाश्वती खलु ते कीर्तिर्लोकान् अनुचरिष्यति।
यः त्वम् कृच्च्र गतम् रामम् प्रत्यानयितुम् इच्चसि॥ २-८५-१३_END
BEGIN_Assuredly your fame will traverse permanently in all provinces,as you are the very person 
who wishes to bring back Rama from his terribleplight._END

B_2_C_85_13
BEGIN_एवम् सम्भाषमाणस्य गुहस्यभरतम् तदा।
बभौ नष्ट प्रभः सूर्यो रजनी च अभ्यवर्तत॥ २-८५-१४_END
BEGIN_While Guha was talking thus to Bharata, the sun diffused lesslight and the night fell._END

B_2_C_85_14
BEGIN_सम्निवेश्य स ताम् सेनाम् गुहेनपरितोषितः।
शत्रुघ्नेन सह श्रीमान् शयनम् पुनर् आगमत्॥ २-८५-१५_END
BEGIN_The illustrious Bharata, lodging that army in camps, feltdelighted by Guha?s hospitality, 
returned to his camp and took rest along withShatrughna._END

B_2_C_85_15
BEGIN_राम चिन्तामयः शोको भरतस्यमहात्मनः।
उपस्थितः हि अनर्हस्य धर्म प्रेक्षस्य तादृशः॥ २-८५-१६_END
BEGIN_The high soled Bharata, whose only aim is to fulfill his duty andwho is undeserving of 
sorrow, indeed felt grief, born of anguish for Rama._END

B_2_C_85_16
BEGIN_अन्तर् दाहेन दहनः सम्तापयतिराघवम्।
वन दाह अभिसम्तप्तम् गूढो अग्निर् इव पादपम्॥ २-८५-१७_END
BEGIN_As a fire is hidden in a hollow tree while a forest is on fire, sodid Bharata?s fire 
of anguish burn with in his heart._END

B_2_C_85_17
BEGIN_प्रस्रुतः सर्व गात्रेभ्यः स्वेदःशोक अग्नि सम्भवः।
यथा सूर्य अंशु सम्तप्तः हिमवान् प्रस्रुतः हिमम्॥ २-८५-१८_END
BEGIN_Perspiration born of fieriness of grief poured off from all hislimbs, as the snow heated 
by solar rays melts and flows from Himavat mountain._END

B_2_C_85_18
BEGIN_ध्यान निर्दर शैलेनविनिह्श्वसित धातुना।
दैन्य पादप सम्घेन शोक आयास अधिशृंगिणा॥ २-८५-१९
प्रमोह अनन्त सत्त्वेन सम्ताप ओषधि वेणुना।
आक्रान्तः दुह्ख शैलेन महता कैकयी सुतः॥ २-८५-२०_END
BEGIN_Bharata, the son of Kaikeyi was pressed by the weight of thatcolossal mountain of agony 
consisting of rocky caverns in the shape of settledcontemplations on Rama, minerals in the shape of 
groans and sighs, a cluster oftrees in the shape of depressive thoughts, summits in the form of sufferingsand 
fatigue, countless wild beasts in the shape of swoons, herbs and bamboos inthe form of his exertions._END

B_2_C_85_19
BEGIN_विनिश्श्वसन्वैभृशदुर्मनास्ततः।
प्रमूढसम्ज्ञः परमापदम् गतः।
शमम् न लेभे हृदयज्वरार्दितो।
नरर्षभो यूथहतो यथर्षभः॥ २-८५-२१_END
BEGIN_Thereafter, Bharata the excellent among men sighing much inmelancholy, his mind utterly 
confused in consequence, having obtained anextreme distress, afflicted as he was with burning fever 
in his breast and likea bull strayed from its herd, found no peace._END

B_2_C_85_20
BEGIN_गुहेन सार्धम् भरतःसमागतः।
महा अनुभावः सजनः समाहितः।
सुदुर्मनाः तम् भरतम् तदा पुनर्।
गुहः समाश्वासयद् अग्रजम् प्रति॥ २-८५-२२_END
BEGIN_The noble soled Bharata, with his escort, met Guha too in acomposed mind. Then Guha slowly 
reassured Bharata again as regards his elderbrother._END

B_2_C_86_0
BEGIN_
आचचक्षे अथ सद्भावम् लक्ष्मणस्य महात्मनः |
भरताय अप्रमेयाय गुहो गहन गोचरः || २-८६-१_END
BEGIN_
Then Guha the foremost dweller reported Bharata, who was having incomprehensible
qualities, about the quality of goodness of Lakshmana(as follows):_END

B_2_C_86_1
BEGIN_
तम् जाग्रतम् गुणैर् युक्तम् वर चाप इषु धारिणम् |
भ्रातृ गुप्त्य् अर्थम् अत्यन्तम् अहम् लक्ष्मणम् अब्रवम् || २-८६-२_END
BEGIN_
"I spoke as follows to that Lakshmana, who is endowed with virtues and wielding
arrows bow and a sword and who was keeping a vigil for the safe guard of his brother."_END

B_2_C_86_2
BEGIN_
इयम् तात सुखा शय्या त्वद् अर्थम् उपकल्पिता |
प्रत्याश्वसिहि शेष्व अस्याम् सुखम् राघव नन्दन || २-८६-३_END
BEGIN_
"O, dear brother! Here is a comfortable bed made ready for you. Feel yourself at
ease. Rest peacefully on this, O, delight of the Raghu race!"_END

B_2_C_86_3
BEGIN_
उचितो अयम् जनः सर्वे दुह्खानाम् त्वम् सुख उचितः |
धर्म आत्ममः तस्य गुप्त्य् अर्थम् जागरिष्यामहे वयम् || २-८६-४_END
BEGIN_
"All my people are habituated for hardships, o virtuous prince! You are used to
comfort. Hence ,we shall keep awake for the safe guard of Rama."_END

B_2_C_86_4
BEGIN_
न हि रामात् प्रियतरो मम अस्ति भुवि कश्चन |
मा उत्सुको भूर् ब्रवीम्य् एतद् अप्य् असत्यम् तव अग्रतः || २-८६-५_END
BEGIN_
"None is more dear to me than Rama on this earth. Moreover, do not become restless.
I am telling this truth in your presence."_END

B_2_C_86_5
BEGIN_
अस्य प्रसादाद् आशंसे लोके अस्मिन् सुमहद् यशः |
धर्म अवाप्तिम् च विपुलाम् अर्थ अवाप्तिम् च केवलाम् || २-८६-६_END
BEGIN_
"By the grace of Rama, I wish to attain a very great renown in this earth, an
extensive acquisition of righteousness, an unalloyed wealth and enjoyment."_END

B_2_C_86_6
BEGIN_
सो अहम् प्रिय सखम् रामम् शयानम् सह सीतया |
रक्षिष्यामि धनुष् पाणिः सर्वैः स्वैर् ज्नातिभिः सह || २-८६-७_END
BEGIN_
"I as such with a bow in my hand, along with my relatives will guard my dear friend
Rama, who slept together with Seetha."_END

B_2_C_86_7
BEGIN_
न हि मे अविदितम् किंचिद् वने अस्मिमः चरतः सदा |
चतुर् अन्गम् ह्य् अपि बलम् प्रसहेम वयम् युधि || २-८६-८_END
BEGIN_
"Nothing is indeed unknown to me, who forever wander in this forest. We can defeat
even an army consisting of all the four limbs in battle."_END

B_2_C_86_8
BEGIN_
एवम् अस्माभिर् उक्तेन लक्ष्मणेन महात्मना |
अनुनीता वयम् सर्वे धर्मम् एव अनुपश्यता || २-८६-९_END
BEGIN_
"Thus spoken as aforesaid by us the high soled Lakshmana, who perceives
righteousness alone,politely replied to all of us( as follows)_END

B_2_C_86_9
BEGIN_
कथम् दाशरथौ भूमौ शयाने सह सीतया |
शक्या निद्रा मया लब्धुम् जीवितम् वा सुखानि वा || २-८६-१०_END
BEGIN_
"How is it possible for me to get a sleep, or even life or comforts when Rama is
reposing on the floor along with Seetha?"_END

B_2_C_86_10
BEGIN_
यो न देव असुरैः सर्वैः शक्यः प्रसहितुम् युधि |
तम् पश्य गुह सम्विष्टम् तृणेषु सह सीतया || २-८६-११_END
BEGIN_
"O, Guha! Behold that Rama, who cannot be conquered in a battle even by all the
celestials and demons, sleeping on the blades of grass along with Seetha."_END

B_2_C_86_11
BEGIN_
महता तपसा लब्धो विविधैः च परिश्रमैः |
एको दशरथस्य एष पुत्रः सदृश लक्षणः || २-८६-१२_END
BEGIN_
"This Rama is an excellent son, having qualities equal to those of Dasaratha. The
king obtained Rama by performing a great penance and after facing various troubles."_END

B_2_C_86_12
BEGIN_
अस्मिन् प्रव्राजिते राजा न चिरम् वर्तयिष्यति |
विधवा मेदिनी नूनम् क्षिप्रम् एव भविष्यति || २-८६-१३_END
BEGIN_
"When Rama having seen exiled, the king Dasaratha will not survive for long.This
earth will surely be without a husband soon."_END

B_2_C_86_13
BEGIN_
विनद्य सुमहा नादम् श्रमेण उपरताः स्त्रियः |
निर्घोष उपरतम् नूनम् अद्य राज निवेशनम् || २-८६-१४_END
BEGIN_
"The women in the gynoecium's, having cried with a great noise, would have ceased
their crying out of fatigue. Now, the great noise would have stopped in the royal palace by
now."_END

B_2_C_86_14
BEGIN_
कौसल्या चैव राजा च तथा एव जननी मम |
न आशंसे यदि ते सर्वे जीवेयुः शर्वरीम् इमाम् || २-८६-१५_END
BEGIN_
"I do not expect whether all of them, like Kausalya Dasaratha and even my mother
Sumitra will survive at all till this night."_END

B_2_C_86_15
BEGIN_
जीवेद् अपि हि मे माता शत्रुघ्नस्य अन्ववेक्षया |
दुह्खिता या तु कौसल्या वीरसूर् विनशिष्यति || २-८६-१६_END
BEGIN_
"By beholding Shatrughna, my mother perhaps may even survive. However, the afflicted
Kausalya who gave birth to the eminent Rama will surely die."_END

B_2_C_86_16
BEGIN_
अतिक्रान्तम् अतिक्रान्तम् अनवाप्य मनो रथम् |
राज्ये रामम् अनिक्षिप्य पिता मे विनशिष्यति || २-८६-१७_END
BEGIN_
Without realising his long-cherished wish and failing to install Rama in the kingdom
of Aodhya, my father Dasaratha will expire."_END

B_2_C_86_17
BEGIN_
सिद्ध अर्थाः पितरम् वृत्तम् तस्मिन् काले ह्य् उपस्थिते |
प्रेत कार्येषु सर्वेषु संस्करिष्यन्ति भूमिपम् || २-८६-१८_END
BEGIN_
"Those who have accomplished their purpose (Shatrughna and others) will perform all
the funeal honours to king Dasaratha, my father when the time comes for it."_END

B_2_C_86_18
BEGIN_
रम्य चत्वर संस्थानाम् सुविभक्त महा पथाम् |
हर्म्य प्रासाद सम्पन्नाम् सर्व रत्न विभूषिताम् || २-८६-१९
गज अश्व रथ सम्बाधाम् तूर्य नाद विनादिताम् |
सर्व कल्याण सम्पूर्णाम् हृष्ट पुष्ट जन आकुलाम् || २-८६-२०
आराम उद्यान सम्पूर्णाम् समाज उत्सव शालिनीम् |
सुखिता विचरिष्यन्ति राज धानीम् पितुर् मम || २-८६-२१_END
BEGIN_
"They will joyfully inhabit my father capital City, with its pleasant cross roads
and meeting places, with its main roads well laid out, sumptuous with large houses and lofty
mansions, with all the gems they are encrusted, with elephants horses and chariots that abound
there, the sound of trumpets with which the city resonates, the many diversions it contains, its
properous and well-fed people, its luxurious gardens and parks as well as the assmeblies and
festivals that continuously take place inti."_END

B_2_C_86_19
BEGIN_
अपि सत्य प्रतिज्नेन सार्धम् कुशलिना वयम् |
निवृत्ते समये ह्य् अस्मिन् सुखिताः प्रविशेमहि || २-८६-२२_END
BEGIN_
Shall we enter Ayodhya happily along with that virtuous Rama, who has truly redeemed
his promise, when he completed his term of exile?_END

B_2_C_86_20
BEGIN_
परिदेवयमानस्य तस्य एवम् सुमहात्मनः |
तिष्ठतो राज पुत्रस्य शर्वरी सा अत्यवर्तत || २-८६-२३_END
BEGIN_
While that magnamimous prince was lamenting thus, standing guard, the night
passed._END

B_2_C_86_21
BEGIN_
प्रभाते विमले सूर्ये कारयित्वा जटा उभौ |
अस्मिन् भागीरथी तीरे सुखम् सम्तारितौ मया || २-८६-२४_END
BEGIN_
"When the sun rose brightly in the next morning Rama and Lakshmana got their locks
of hair matted into a thick mass at the banks of River Ganga and they were safely ferried by
me."_END

B_2_C_86_22
BEGIN_
जटा धरौ तौ द्रुम चीर वाससौ |
महा बलौ कुन्जर यूथप उपमौ |
वर इषु चाप असि धरौ परम् तपौ |
व्यवेक्षमाणौ सह सीतया गतौ ||२-८६-२५_END
BEGIN_
"Rama and Lakshmana, who were capable of tormenting their enemies, possessing great
strength, wearing matted locks of hari and clothes made of bark, like unto the leaders of herd of
elephants, wielding excellent bow, arrows and sword, looking back at me, went away with Seetha._END

B_2_C_87_0
BEGIN_
गुहस्य वचनम् श्रुत्वा भरतो भृशम् अप्रियम् |
ध्यानम् जगाम तत्र एव यत्र तत् श्रुतम् अप्रियम् || २-८७-१_END
BEGIN_
Hearing those most disagreeable words from Guha, Bharata began to think deeply,
directing his mind on Rama, of whom those unpleasant words were heard._END

B_2_C_87_1
BEGIN_
सुकुमारो महा सत्त्वः सिम्ह स्कन्धो महा भुजः |
पुण्डरीक विशाल अक्षः तरुणः प्रिय दर्शनः || २-८७-२
प्रत्याश्वस्य मुहूर्तम् तु कालम् परम दुर्मनाः |
पपात सहसा तोत्रैर् हृदि विद्ध इव द्विपः || २-८७-३_END
BEGIN_
That gentle, extremely courageous and the mighty armed young prince, whose shoulders
resembled a lion's his large eyes opening like a flowering lotus and having pleasing appearance,
momentarily sighed and in his extreme anguish, sank to the ground suddenly like an elephant that
has been wounded in the heart with goads._END

B_2_C_87_2
BEGIN_
भरतम् मुर्च्छितम् द्रुष्ट्वा विवर्णवदनो गुहः |
बभूव व्यथितस्तत्र भूमिकम्पे यथा द्रुमः || २-८७-४_END
BEGIN_
Seeing Bharata unconscious, Guha growing pale, shook like a tree during an
earthquake._END

B_2_C_87_3
BEGIN_
तद् अवस्थम् तु भरतम् शत्रुघ्नो अनन्तर स्थितः |
परिष्वज्य रुरोद उच्चैर् विसम्ज्नः शोक कर्शितः || २-८७-५_END
BEGIN_
Shatrughna, who stood near, taking Bharata, who was in that unconscious state in his
arms, becoming non-pulsed, cried loudly, overcome as he was with grief._END

B_2_C_87_4
BEGIN_
ततः सर्वाः समापेतुर् मातरो भरतस्य ताः |
उपवास कृशा दीना भर्तृ व्यसन कर्शिताः || २-८७-६_END
BEGIN_
Then, all the queens, emaciated through fasting, extremely miserable, being unable
to find consolation for the sad end of their lord, rushed towards Bharata._END

B_2_C_87_5
BEGIN_
ताः च तम् पतितम् भूमौ रुदन्त्यः पर्यवारयन् |
कौसल्या तु अनुसृत्य एनम् दुर्मनाः परिषस्वजे || २-८७-७_END
BEGIN_
All of them, sobbing, surrounded Bharata who fell on the ground. Kausalya on her
part, torn with grief and bending over him, embraced him._END

B_2_C_87_6
BEGIN_
वत्सला स्वम् यथा वत्सम् उपगूह्य तपस्विनी |
परिपप्रग्च्छ भरतम् रुदन्ती शोक लालसा || २-८७-८_END
BEGIN_
That affectionate Kausalya, agitated as she was with grief and looking miserable,
pressing him to her bosom as a cow its own calf, questioned Bharata (in the following words)_END

B_2_C_87_7
BEGIN_
पुत्र व्याधिर् न ते कच्चित् शरीरम् परिबाधते |
अद्य राज कुलस्य अस्य त्वद् अधीनम् हि जीवितम् || २-८७-९_END
BEGIN_
"O, son! I hope that no ailment afflicts your body. Now, the life of this royal race
is indeed dependent on you."_END

B_2_C_87_8
BEGIN_
त्वाम् दृष्ट्वा पुत्र जीवामि रामे सभ्रातृके गते |
वृत्ते दशरथे राज्नि नाथ एकः त्वम् अद्य नः || २-८७-१०_END
BEGIN_
"O, son! Rama along with Lakshman has gone to the forest. The king Dasaratha is
dead. I survive, looking on you. Now, you alone are the protector for us."_END

B_2_C_87_9
BEGIN_
कच्चिन् न लक्ष्मणे पुत्र श्रुतम् ते किंचिद् अप्रियम् |
पुत्र वा ह्य् एकपुत्रायाः सह भार्ये वनम् गते || २-८७-११_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you have not heard any unpleasant news about Lakshmana or about Rama my one
and the only son who left for the forest along with his wife."_END

B_2_C_87_10
BEGIN_
स मुहूर्तम् समाश्वस्य रुदन्न् एव महा यशाः |
कौसल्याम् परिसान्त्व्य इदम् गुहम् वचनम् अब्रवीत् || २-८७-१२_END
BEGIN_
Bharata of great renown, easing himself well within a moment, consoled Kausalya and
while still weeping, spoke to Guha (as follows)_END

B_2_C_87_11
BEGIN_
भ्राता मे क्व अवसद् रात्रिम् क्व सीता क्व च लक्ष्मणः |
अस्वपत् शयने कस्मिन् किम् भुक्त्वा गुह शंस मे || २-८७-१३_END
BEGIN_
"O, guha! Tell me where did Rama my brother as also Seetha and Lakshmana halt in the
night? On what couch and eating what, did he repose?_END

B_2_C_87_12
BEGIN_
सो अब्रवीद् भरतम् पृष्टो निषाद अधिपतिर् गुहः |
यद् विधम् प्रतिपेदे च रामे प्रिय हिते अतिथौ || २-८७-१४_END
BEGIN_
Guha, the Lord of Nishadas, thrilling with rapture, spoke to Bharata about the
manner in which he made arrangements for (feeding and reposing) his beloved and kind guest,
Rama._END

B_2_C_87_13
BEGIN_
अन्नम् उच्च अवचम् भक्ष्याः फलानि विविधानि च |
रामाय अभ्यवहार अर्थम् बहु च उपहृतम् मया || २-८७-१५_END
BEGIN_
"Various kinds of food and drink and different varieties of fruits were brought
repeatedly by me to the presence of Rama for the purpose of his consumption."_END

B_2_C_87_14
BEGIN_
तत् सर्वम् प्रत्यनुज्नासीद् रामः सत्य पराक्रमः |
न हि तत् प्रत्यगृह्णात् स क्षत्र धर्मम् अनुस्मरन् || २-८७-१६_END
BEGIN_
Rama, the truly courageous man, refused all of them. Reminding himself of his
warrior's statute, he could not accept it._END

B_2_C_87_15
BEGIN_
न ह्य् अस्माभिः प्रतिग्राह्यम् सखे देयम् तु सर्वदा |
इति तेन वयम् राजन्न् अनुनीता महात्मना || २-८७-१७_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata! We were pacified by that high-souled Rama by saying thus: ' O, friend!
We are not allowed to receive anything we must always be givers."_END

B_2_C_87_16
BEGIN_
लक्ष्मणेन समानीतम् पीत्वा वारि महा यशाः |
औपवास्यम् तदा अकार्षीद् राघवः सह सीतया || २-८७-१८_END
BEGIN_
"Rama, of great glory, then along with Seetha drank the water brought by Lakshman as
observed fasting."_END

B_2_C_87_17
BEGIN_
ततः तु जल शेषेण लक्ष्मणो अप्य् अकरोत् तदा |
वाग् यताः ते त्रयः संध्याम् उपासत समाहिताः || २-८७-१९_END
BEGIN_
"Thereafter Lakshmana also drank the left-over water and those three practised
silence together in that evening-twilight._END

B_2_C_87_18
BEGIN_
सौमित्रिः तु ततः पश्चाद् अकरोत् स्वास्तरम् शुभम् |
स्वयम् आनीय बर्हीम्षि क्षिप्रम् राघव कारणात् || २-८७-२०_END
BEGIN_
"Lakshmana then personally brought a layer of Kusa grass and arranged a fittingly
nice bed with it for Rama immediately."_END

B_2_C_87_19
BEGIN_
तस्मिन् समाविशद् रामः स्वास्तरे सह सीतया |
प्रक्षाल्य च तयोः पादाउ अपचक्राम लक्ष्मणः || २-८७-२१_END
BEGIN_
"Rama, along with Seetha, settled down on that bed. After washing their feet,
Lakshmana went away to a distance."_END

B_2_C_87_20
BEGIN_
एतत् तद् इन्गुदी मूलम् इदम् एव च तत् तृणम् |
यस्मिन् रामः च सीता च रात्रिम् ताम् शयिताउ उभौ || २-८७-२२_END
BEGIN_
"Here at this fort of Ingndi Tree, on just this grass, on which both Rama and Seetha
slept that night."_END

B_2_C_87_21
BEGIN_
नियम्य पृष्ठे तु तल अन्गुलित्रवान् |
शरैः सुपूर्णाउ इषुधी परम् तपः |
महद् धनुः सज्यम् उपोह्य लक्ष्मणो |
निशाम् अतिष्ठत् परितो अस्य केवलम् || २-८७-२३_END
BEGIN_
"Lakshmana, the scourge of his foe, wearing a glove of goha skin, strapping two
quivers full of arrows on either side of his back and wielding a great stringed bow, remained on
his part walking round Rama during that night."_END

B_2_C_87_22
BEGIN_
ततः तु अहम् च उत्तम बाण चापधृक् |
स्थितो अभवम् तत्र स यत्र लक्ष्मणः |
अतन्द्रिभिर् ज्नातिभिर् आत्त कार्मुकैर् |
महा इन्द्र कल्पम् परिपालयमः तदा || २-८७-२४_END
BEGIN_
"Wearing excellent arrows and a bow along with my vigilant kinsmen carrying their
bows, I on my part remained near Lakshman, who was guarding Rama who vied with Indra the Lord of
celestials."_END

B_2_C_88_0
BEGIN_
तत् श्रुत्वा निपुणम् सर्वम् भरतः सह मन्त्रिभिः |
इन्गुदी मूलम् आगम्य राम शय्याम् अवेक्ष्य ताम् || २-८८-१
अब्रवीद् जननीः सर्वा इह तेन महात्मना |
शर्वरी शयिता भूमाउ इदम् अस्य विमर्दितम् || २-८८-२_END
BEGIN_
Having heard all that perfectly, Bharata approached the foot of Ingudi Tree along
with his ministers and gazed on that grass-bed on which Rama had slept. Thereafter, he said to all
his mothers as follows: "It is here that the magnanimous hero laid himself for that night, his
limbs pressing the earth."_END

B_2_C_88_1
BEGIN_
महा भाग कुलीनेन महा भागेन धीमता |
जातो दशरथेन ऊर्व्याम् न रामः स्वप्तुम् अर्हति || २-८८-३_END
BEGIN_
"Born of the great and segacious Dasaratha in an illustrious family, Rama verily
does not desrve to sleep on this bare earth!"_END

B_2_C_88_2
BEGIN_
अजिन उत्तर संस्तीर्णे वर आस्तरण संचये |
शयित्वा पुरुष व्याघ्रः कथम् शेते मही तले || २-८८-४_END
BEGIN_
"How could Rama the tiger among men, who used to sleep on a couch horded with rich
cushions covered with superior hairy skins of antelopes, sleep on a bare floor?"_END

B_2_C_88_3
BEGIN_
प्रासाद अग्र विमानेषु वलभीषु च सर्वदा |
हैम राजत भौमेषु वर आस्त्ररण शालिषु || २-८८-५
पुष्प संचय चित्रेषु चन्दन अगरु गन्धिषु |
पाण्डुर अभ्र प्रकाशेषु शुक सम्घ रुतेषु च || २-८८-६
प्रासादवरवर्येषु शीतवत्सु सुगन्धिषु |
उषित्वा मेरुकल्पेषु कृतकांचनभित्तिषु || २-८८-७
गीत वादित्र निर्घोषैर् वर आभरण निह्स्वनैः |
मृदन्ग वर शब्दैः च सततम् प्रतिबोधितः || २-८८-८
बन्दिभिर् वन्दितः काले बहुभिः सूत मागधैः |
गाथाभिर् अनुरूपाभिः स्तुतिभिः च परम्तपः || २-८८-९_END
BEGIN_
"Having ever dwelt in palaces, the upper apartments resembling the chariots of the
gods and in turrets, furnished with excellent carpets decked with heaps of flowers, perfumed with
sandal and aloes, like unto a bright and towering cloud, re-echoing to the cries of parrots,
suprassing the finest of palaces, which wre cool and fragrant with perfules, as unto Mount Meru
with its golden walls, where in that palace he was awakened at the fitting time by sogns and music
from various instruments, tinkling of ornaments and the excellent sounds of clay tomtoms, glorified
by many panegyrists, bards and ministrels throught appropriate ballads and songs of praise."_END

B_2_C_88_4
BEGIN_
अश्रद्धेयम् इदम् लोके न सत्यम् प्रतिभाति मा |
मुह्यते खलु मे भावः स्वप्नो अयम् इति मे मतिः || २-८८-१०_END
BEGIN_
"This ( such a prince becoming like this) is unbelievable in the world and does not
appear true to me. My mind is indeed bewildered. I wish that it were a dream."_END

B_2_C_88_5
BEGIN_
न नूनम् दैवतम् किंचित् कालेन बलवत्तरम् |
यत्र दाशरथी रामो भूमाउ एवम् शयीत सः || २-८८-११_END
BEGIN_
"Surely even a deity is not a little more powerful than Time (the will of god),
since that Rama, the son of Dasaratha has to sleep on the bare ground!"_END

B_2_C_88_6
BEGIN_
विदेह राजस्य सुता सीता च प्रिय दर्शना |
दयिता शयिता भूमौ स्नुषा दशरथस्य च || २-८८-१२_END
BEGIN_
"Even Seetha the daughter of the king of videha, lovely to look upon and the
cherished daughter-in-law of Dasaratha has to sleep on the floor!"_END

B_2_C_88_7
BEGIN_
इयम् शय्या मम भ्रातुर् इदम् हि परिवर्तितम् |
स्थण्डिले कठिने सर्वम् गात्रैर् विमृदितम् तृणम् || २-८८-१३_END
BEGIN_
"This is the bed of my elder brother. Here are indeed the blessed marks of his
changing sides, in the form of all the blades of Kusa grass, trampled by his limbs on the hard
ground."_END

B_2_C_88_8
BEGIN_
मन्ये साभरणा सुप्ता सीता अस्मिन् शयने तदा |
तत्र तत्र हि दृश्यन्ते सक्ताः कनक बिन्दवः || २-८८-१४_END
BEGIN_
"I think the blessed Seetha has slept on this bed along with her jewels for, some
particles of gold appear to be stuck up, here and there."_END

B_2_C_88_9
BEGIN_
उत्तरीयम् इह आसक्तम् सुव्यक्तम् सीतया तदा |
तथा ह्य् एते प्रकाशन्ते सक्ताः कौशेय तन्तवः || २-८८-१५_END
BEGIN_
"It is very clear that the upper garment of Seetha got entangled with these blades
here at that time. That is why, these silk-threads appear stuck to them."_END

B_2_C_88_10
BEGIN_
मन्ये भर्तुः सुखा शय्या येन बाला तपस्विनी |
सुकुमारी सती दुह्खम् न विजानाति मैथिली || २-८८-१६_END
BEGIN_
"I think the bed of her husband is sweet to a woman and thought Seetha is young and
unfortunate, yet however delicate she be, she would experience no suffering."_END

B_2_C_88_11
BEGIN_
हा हन्तास्मि नृशंसोऽहम् यत्सभार्यः कृतेमम |
ईदृशीं राघवः शय्यामधिशेते ह्यानाथवत् || २-८८-१७_END
BEGIN_
"Alas! I am a cruel man because on my account, Rama, like an orphan, along with his
wife slept on such a bed."_END

B_2_C_88_12
BEGIN_
सार्वभौम कुले जातः सर्व लोक सुख आवहः |
सर्व लोक प्रियः त्यक्त्वा राज्यम् प्रियम् अनुत्तमम् || २-८८-१८
कथम् इन्दीवर श्यामो रक्त अक्षः प्रिय दर्शनः |
सुख भागी च दुह्ख अर्हः शयितो भुवि राघवः || २-८८-१९_END
BEGIN_
"How can Rama, born in the race of monarchs, highly honoured by the entire world,
beloved of all the people, having a dark complexion as that of a blue-lotus, having red eyes,
lovely to look at who is entittled for comfort and who is not worthy of suffering, sleep on the
gound, abandoning excellent kingdom and comfort?"_END

B_2_C_88_13
BEGIN_
धन्यः खलु महाभागो लक्ष्मणः शुभलक्षमणः |
भ्रातरम् विषमे काले यो राममनुवर्तते || २-८८-२०_END
BEGIN_
"Lakshmana, having auspicious marks on his body and an exceedingly lucky man, who
accompanied his elder brother Rama in times of adversity in indeed a fortunate man."_END

B_2_C_88_14
BEGIN_
सिद्ध अर्था खलु वैदेही पतिम् या अनुगता वनम् |
वयम् संशयिताः सर्वे हीनाः तेन महात्मना || २-८८-२१_END
BEGIN_
"Seetha, who went together with her husband to the forest, is indeed an accomplished
woman. All of us, deprived of the highly virtuous Rama, are an unsettled lot."_END

B_2_C_88_15
BEGIN_
अकर्ण धारा पृथिवी शून्या इव प्रतिभाति मा |
गते दशरथे स्वर्गे रामे च अरण्यम् आश्रिते || २-८८-२२_END
BEGIN_
"Dasaratha went to heaven. Rama is dwelling in the forest. this kingdom appears to
me as a boat without ahelmsman."_END

B_2_C_88_16
BEGIN_
न च प्रार्थयते कश्चिन् मनसा अपि वसुंधराम् |
वने अपि वसतः तस्य बाहु वीर्य अभिरक्षिताम् || २-८८-२३_END
BEGIN_
"Even if staying in the forest, Rama protects this earth with the power of his arms.
Hence, nobdy can think even in his mind, to invade this kingdom."_END

B_2_C_88_17
BEGIN_
शून्य सम्वरणा रक्षाम् अयन्त्रित हय द्विपाम् |
अपावृत पुर द्वाराम् राज धानीम् अरक्षिताम् || २-८८-२४
अप्रहृष्ट बलाम् न्यूनाम् विषमस्थाम् अनावृताम् |
शत्रवो न अभिमन्यन्ते भक्ष्यान् विष कृतान् इव || २-८८-२५_END
BEGIN_
"Without guards to watch over its ramparts, with its unrestrained horses and
elephants, with its city-gates laid open, without any defenders, denuded of its happy army, plunged
in desolation in difficulties and exposed, that royal capital of Ayodhya will be shunned like
poisoned food even by the enemies."_END

B_2_C_88_18
BEGIN_
अद्य प्रभृति भूमौ तु शयिष्ये अहम् तृणेषु वा |
फल मूल अशनो नित्यम् जटा चीराणि धारयन् || २-८८-२६_END
BEGIN_
"From today onwards, I shall sleep on the earth or on the grass, with my locks
matted, wearing robes of bark and by all means living on fruits and roots."_END

B_2_C_88_19
BEGIN_
तस्य अर्थम् उत्तरम् कालम् निवत्स्यामि सुखम् वने |
तम् प्रतिश्रवम् आमुच्य न अस्य मिथ्या भविष्यति || २-८८-२७_END
BEGIN_
"For the rest of his exile, on behalf of Rama, I shall dwell cheerfully in the
forest, thereby discharging that promise so that the vows of Rama shall not have been made in
vain."_END

B_2_C_88_20
BEGIN_
वसन्तम् भ्रातुर् अर्थाय शत्रुघ्नो मा अनुवत्स्यति |
लक्ष्मणेन सह तु आर्यो अयोध्याम् पालयिष्यति || २-८८-२८_END
BEGIN_
"Shatrughna will bear company with me, residing in the forest on behalf of Rama. My
elder brother, Rama along with Lakshmana will protect Ayodhya."_END

B_2_C_88_21
BEGIN_
अभिषेक्ष्यन्ति काकुत्स्थम् अयोध्यायाम् द्विजातयः |
अपि मे देवताः कुर्युर् इमम् सत्यम् मनो रथम् |
प्रसाद्यमानः शिरसा मया स्वयम् |
बहु प्रकारम् यदि न प्रपत्स्यते || २-८८-२९_END
BEGIN_
"Rama will be enthroned in ayodhya, by Brahmanas the Twice-born! May the gods grant
that my desire be made a reality."_END

B_2_C_88_22
BEGIN_
ततोन्रुवत्सयामि चिराय राघवम् |
वनेचरम् नह्रुति माम्रुपेक्षित्रुम् || २-८८-३०_END
BEGIN_
"Should Rama not accept the respectful appeals made in many a way by me, I shall
follow the foot steps of Rama for any length of time he roams about in the forest thereafter. He
ought not to refuse this grace to me."_END

B_2_C_89_0
BEGIN_
व्युष्य रात्रिम् तु तत्र एव गन्गा कूले स राघवः |
भरतः काल्यम् उत्थाय शत्रुघ्नम् इदम् अब्रवीत् || २-८९-१_END
BEGIN_
Bharata, born in Raghu race, having passed the night in that place on the banks of
Ganga, rising at dawn, said to shatrughna as follows:_END

B_2_C_89_1
BEGIN_
शत्रुघ उत्तिष्ठ किम् शेषे निषाद अधिपतिम् गुहम् |
शीघ्रम् आनय भद्रम् ते तारयिष्यति वाहिनीम् || २-८९-२_END
BEGIN_
"O, Shatrughna! wake up! Why sleep longer/ Bring guha the king of Nishadhas quickly
and be happy. Let him convey the army across the river."_END

B_2_C_89_2
BEGIN_
जागर्मि न अहम् स्वपिमि तथैव आर्यम् विचिन्तयन् |
इत्य् एवम् अब्रवीद् भ्रात्रा शत्रुघ्नो अपि प्रचोदितः || २-८९-३_END
BEGIN_
Thus urged by Bhrata, his brother Shatrughna said, "I am not sleeping. Thinking of
that Rama alone, I have been wakeful."_END

B_2_C_89_3
BEGIN_
इति सम्वदतोर् एवम् अन्योन्यम् नर सिम्हयोः |
आगम्य प्रान्जलिः काले गुहो भरतम् अब्रवीत् || २-८९-४_END
BEGIN_
While those two lions among men were talking themselves with each other thus, Guha
came in time and with joined palms, addressed Bharata saying:_END

B_2_C_89_4
BEGIN_
कच्चित् सुखम् नदी तीरे अवात्सीः काकुत्स्थ शर्वरीम् |
कच्चिच् च सह सैन्यस्य तव सर्वम् अनामयम् || २-८९-५_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bhrata! Did you pass the night happily on the banks of the river? I hope all is
well with your army."_END

B_2_C_89_5
BEGIN_
गुहस्य तत् तु वचनम् श्रुत्वा स्नेहाद् उदीरितम् |
रामस्य अनुवशो वाक्यम् भरतो अपि इदम् अब्रवीत् || २-८९-६_END
BEGIN_
Hearing those words of Guha spoken with affection, Bharata also in his devotion to
Rama, replied as follows:_END

B_2_C_89_6
BEGIN_
सुखा नः शर्वरी राजन् पूजिताः च अपि ते वयम् |
गन्गाम् तु नौभिर् बह्वीभिर् दाशाः सम्तारयन्तु नः || २-८९-७_END
BEGIN_
"O, king! The night passed leasantly fo r us. We were treated hospitably by you. Let
your fisher-men ferry us across Ganga River on your courtless boats."_END

B_2_C_89_7
BEGIN_
ततो गुहः सम्त्वरितः श्रुत्वा भरत शासनम् |
प्रतिप्रविश्य नगरम् तम् ज्नाति जनम् अब्रवीत् || २-८९-८_END
BEGIN_
Hearing Bharata's command, Guha returned to the city in all haste and spoke to those
multitude of his people (as follows):_END

B_2_C_89_8
BEGIN_
उत्तिष्ठत प्रबुध्यध्वम् भद्रम् अस्तु हि वः सदा |
नावः समनुकर्षध्वम् तारयिष्याम वाहिनीम् || २-८९-९_END
BEGIN_
"Rise, awake and may prosperity ever attend you! Duly haul the boats to the bank.
Let us carry the army across the river."_END

B_2_C_89_9
BEGIN_
ते तथा उक्ताः समुत्थाय त्वरिताः राज शासनात् |
पन्च नावाम् शतान्य् एव समानिन्युः समन्ततः || २-८९-१०_END
BEGIN_
Rising immediately on hearing the command of their king, they quickly brought
together five hundred boats from every quarter._END

B_2_C_89_10
BEGIN_
अन्याः स्वस्तिक विज्नेया महा घण्डा धरा वराः |
शोभमानाः पताकिन्यो युक्त वाताः सुसम्हताः || २-८९-११_END
BEGIN_
Some excellent boats, possessing large bells were marked with Sawstika, well-kept
together with appropriate sails and adorned with flags._END

B_2_C_89_11
BEGIN_
ततः स्वस्तिक विज्नेयाम् पाण्डु कम्बल सम्वृताम् |
सनन्दि घोषाम् कल्याणीम् गुहो नावम् उपाहरत् || २-८९-१२_END
BEGIN_
Then, Guha brought there one boat also adorned with Swastika, was covered with white
canvas, re-echoing with acclamations and which was beautiful._END

B_2_C_89_12
BEGIN_
ताम् आरुरोह भरतः शत्रुघ्नः च महा बलः |
कौसल्या च सुमित्रा च याः च अन्या राज योषितः || २-८९-१३
पुरोहितः च तत् पूर्वम् गुरवे ब्राह्मणाः च ये |
अनन्तरम् राज दाराः तथैव शकट आपणाः || २-८९-१४_END
BEGIN_
Vasishta, the royal priest and whatever elderly Brahmanas were present there
ascended the boats, even before Bharata, Shatrughna, Kausalya, Sumitra. Whatever royal women were
present also took theri seats. Thereafter followed the king's wives a well as bullock- carts and
provisions._END

B_2_C_89_13
BEGIN_
आवासम् आदीपयताम् तीर्थम् च अप्य् अवगाहताम् |
भाण्डानि च आददानानाम् घोषः त्रिदिवम् अस्पृशत् || २-८९-१५_END
BEGIN_
The sound of men setting fire to the huts, of those who were descending the steps
leading to the boat and those who were transporting their effects touched the sky._END

B_2_C_89_14
BEGIN_
पताकिन्यः तु ता नावः स्वयम् दाशैर् अधिष्ठिताः |
वहन्त्यो जनम् आरूढम् तदा सम्पेतुर् आशुगाः || २-८९-१६_END
BEGIN_
Thos boats, adorned with flags, steered by fisher-men themselves ran speedily, duly
carrying those passengers._END

B_2_C_89_15
BEGIN_
नारीणाम् अभिपूर्णाः तु काश्चित् काश्चित् तु वाजिनाम् |
कश्चित् तत्र वहन्ति स्म यान युग्यम् महा धनम् || २-८९-१७_END
BEGIN_
Some were filled with women. Some were loaded with horses and some of them ferried
animals of draught of great value._END

B_2_C_89_16
BEGIN_
ताः स्म गत्वा परम् तीरम् अवरोप्य च तम् जनम् |
निवृत्ताः काण्ड चित्राणि क्रियन्ते दाश बन्धुभिः || २-८९-१८_END
BEGIN_
Having reached the opposite shore, thsoe boats cleared those people and on the
return journey, the kinsfolk of guha plied them as easily as toy- boats made of bamboo._END

B_2_C_89_17
BEGIN_
सवैजयन्ताः तु गजा गज आरोहैः प्रचोदिताः |
तरन्तः स्म प्रकाशन्ते सध्वजा इव पर्वताः || २-८९-१९_END
BEGIN_
Goaded on by their mahouts, elephants adorned with their flags, swimming across the
river, looked life winged mountains._END

B_2_C_89_18
BEGIN_
नावः च आरुरुहुः तु अन्ये प्लवैः तेरुः तथा अपरे |
अन्ये कुम्भ घटैः तेरुर् अन्ये तेरुः च बाहुभिः || २-८९-२०_END
BEGIN_
Some ascended boats. Some others crossed the river by rafts in the same manner. Some
others swam across with the help of big and small earthen vessels. The rest swam with arms._END

B_2_C_89_19
BEGIN_
सा पुण्या ध्वजिनी गन्गाम् दाशैः सम्तारिता स्वयम् |
मैत्रे मुहूर्ते प्रययौ प्रयाग वनम् उत्तमम् || २-८९-२१_END
BEGIN_
Having made to cross River Ganga by the fisher-men themselves, that holy army
reached the magnificient woods of Prayaga at the hour of Maitra._END

B_2_C_89_20
BEGIN_
आश्वासयित्वा च चमूम् महात्मा |
निवेशयित्वा च यथा उपजोषम् |
द्रष्टुम् भरद्वाजम् ऋषि प्रवर्यम् |
ऋत्विग् वृतः सन् भरतः प्रतस्थे || २-८९-२२_END
BEGIN_
The high-souled Bharata made the army to rest, by encamping it according to its
inclination and set out along with the priests and king's counsellors to meet Bharadwaja, the
foremost of sages._END

B_2_C_89_21
BEGIN_
स ब्राह्मणस्याश्रममभ्युपेत्य |
महात्मनो देवपुरोहितस्य |
ददर्श रम्योटजवृक्षषण्डं |
महद्वनं विप्रवरस्य रम्यम् || २-८९-२३_END
BEGIN_
Approaching the hermitage of that high-souled Brahmana and the family priest of
gods, Bharata saw an extensive and enchanting grove with its leafy huts and tress the chief of
ascatics._END

B_2_C_90_0
BEGIN_
द्भरद्वाज आश्रमम् दृष्ट्वा क्रोशाद् एव नर ऋषभः |
बलम् सर्वम् अवस्थाप्य जगाम सह मन्त्रिभिः || २-९०-१
पद्भ्याम् एव हि धर्मज्नो न्यस्त शस्त्र परिग्च्छदः |
वसानो वाससी क्षौमे पुरोधाय पुरोहितम् || २-९०-२_END
BEGIN_
Having seen Bharadwaja's hermitage at a couple of miles away, that excellent man
Bharata, knowing what is right, leaving all his army behind, discarding his weapons and ornaments,
and wearing simple silken garment, went forwards by foot, proceeded by Vasishta, his spiritual
preceptor._END

B_2_C_90_1
BEGIN_
ततः संदर्शने तस्य भरद्वाजस्य राघवः |
मन्त्रिणः तान् अवस्थाप्य जगाम अनु पुरोहितम् || २-९०-३_END
BEGIN_
Leaving his ministers behind at a visible distance to Bharadwaja, Bharata then went
along with Vasishta, his spiritual preceptor._END

B_2_C_90_2
BEGIN_
वसिष्ठम् अथ दृष्ट्वा एव भरद्वाजो महा तपाः |
संचचाल आसनात् तूर्णम् शिष्यान् अर्घ्यम् इति ब्रुवन् || २-९०-४_END
BEGIN_
On seeing Vasishta, Bharadwaja the great ascetic rose quickly from his seat, asking
his disciples to fetch water to wash the hand (of the distinguished guests) with._END

B_2_C_90_3
BEGIN_
समागम्य वसिष्ठेन भरतेन अभिवादितः |
अबुध्यत महा तेजाः सुतम् दशरथस्य तम् || २-९०-५_END
BEGIN_
Having met Vasishta and greeted by Bharata, Bharadwaja of great splendour recognized
him to be a son of Dasaratha._END

B_2_C_90_4
BEGIN_
ताभ्याम् अर्घ्यम् च पाद्यम् च दत्त्वा पश्चात् फलानि च |
आनुपूर्व्याच् च धर्मज्नः पप्रग्च्छ कुशलम् कुले || २-९०-६_END
BEGIN_
Bharadwaja, knowing what is right, offering them both, in order of seniority, water
to wash theri hands and feet with and fruits afterwards, made enquiries concerning the welfare of
their family._END

B_2_C_90_5
BEGIN_
अयोध्यायाम् बले कोशे मित्रेषु अपि च मन्त्रिषु |
जानन् दशरथम् वृत्तम् न राजानम् उदाहरत् || २-९०-७_END
BEGIN_
Subsequently, Bharadwaja made enquires with both of them as to whether all were well
in the city of Ayodhya, with the army, with the treasury, friends and counsellors. But knowing
Dasaratha friends and counsellors. But knowing Dasaratha to be dead, he did not speak of the
king._END

B_2_C_90_6
BEGIN_
वसिष्ठो भरतः च एनम् पप्रग्च्छतुर् अनामयम् |
शरीरे अग्निषु वृक्षेषु शिष्येषु मृग पक्षिषु || २-९०-८_END
BEGIN_
Vasishta and Bharata in return made enquires with Bharadwaja, if all were well with
his body his sacred fires, his disciples, the trees, the deer and birds in the hermitage._END

B_2_C_90_7
BEGIN_
तथा इति च प्रतिज्नाय भरद्वाजो महा तपाः |
भरतम् प्रत्युवाच इदम् राघव स्नेह बन्धनात् || २-९०-९_END
BEGIN_
The great ascetic Bharadwaja replied, "All is well" and spoke the following words to
Bharata, bound as he was with affection to Rama._END

B_2_C_90_8
BEGIN_
किम् इह आगमने कार्यम् तव राज्यम् प्रशासतः |
एतद् आचक्ष्व मे सर्वम् न हि मे शुध्यते मनः || २-९०-१०_END
BEGIN_
"For what reason have you, who are ruling the kingdom, come here? Tell me all this,
for my mind is not getting cleared of doubts."_END

B_2_C_90_9
BEGIN_
सुषुवे यम मित्रघ्नम् कौसल्य आनन्द वर्धनम् |
भ्रात्रा सह सभार्यो यः चिरम् प्रव्राजितो वनम् || २-९०-११
नियुक्तः स्त्री नियुक्तेन पित्रा यो असौ महा यशाः |
वन वासी भव इति इह समाः किल चतुर्दश || २-९०-१२
कच्चिन् न तस्य अपापस्य पापम् कर्तुम् इह इग्च्छसि |
अकण्टकम् भोक्तु मना राज्यम् तस्य अनुजस्य च || २-९०-१३_END
BEGIN_
"That annihilator of enemies, born of Kausalya for the increase of her happiness, he
who with his brother and his wife have been exiled to the forest for a long period, that Rama who
is full of glory, through the intrigues of a woman was condemned to dwell in the forest for
fourteen years by his father. I hope you do not intend to do any harm to that irreproachable prince
and his younger brother in order to enjoy the throne without hindrance."_END

B_2_C_90_10
BEGIN_
एवम् उक्तो भरद्वाजम् भरतः प्रत्युवाच ह |
पर्यश्रु नयनो दुह्खाद् वाचा संसज्जमानया || २-९०-१४_END
BEGIN_
"Thus spoken to as aforesaid, Bharata with his eyes filled with tears in grief and
in a faltering tone, replied to Bharadwaja as follows:_END

B_2_C_90_11
BEGIN_
हतो अस्मि यदि माम् एवम् भगवान् अपि मन्यते |
मत्तो न दोषम् आशन्केर् न एवम् माम् अनुशाधि हि || २-९०-१५_END
BEGIN_
"If you the Blessed One, regard me like this, I am lost indeed! I cannot conceive of
any harm towards Rama having proceeded from me. do not charge me thus."_END

B_2_C_90_12
BEGIN_
न च एतद् इष्टम् माता मे यद् अवोचन् मद् अन्तरे |
नाहम् एतेन तुष्टः च न तद् वचनम् आददे || २-९०-१६_END
BEGIN_
" I do not approve of what my mother has done when I was away from home. I am not
pleased with her nor do I accept her word in this matter."_END

B_2_C_90_13
BEGIN_
अहम् तु तम् नर व्याघ्रम् उपयातः प्रसादकः |
प्रतिनेतुम् अयोध्याम् च पादौ तस्य अभिवन्दितुम् || २-९०-१७_END
BEGIN_
"I, on my part, came to take back that tiger among men to Ayodhya, after prostrating
myself at his feet and having propitiated him."_END

B_2_C_90_14
BEGIN_
त्वम् माम् एवम् गतम् मत्वा प्रसादम् कर्तुम् अर्हसि |
शंस मे भगवन् रामः क्व सम्प्रति मही पतिः || २-९०-१८_END
BEGIN_
"O, venerable one! Believing me to have come for the aforesaid purpose, you ought to
do a favour for me. Tell me where Rama the Lord of the world is to be found now?"_END

B_2_C_90_15
BEGIN_
वशिष्ठादिभि ऋत्विग्भि र्याचितो भगवांस्ततः |
उवाच तम् भरद्वाजः प्रसादाद् भरतम् वचः || २-९०-१९_END
BEGIN_
Requested by Vasishta and other priests likewise, Bharadwaja answered Bharata in
affectionate words as follows:_END

B_2_C_90_16
BEGIN_
त्वय्य् एतत् पुरुष व्याघ्रम् युक्तम् राघव वंशजे |
गुरु वृत्तिर् दमः चैव साधूनाम् च अनुयायिता || २-९०-२०_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata the tiger among men! Good manners towards teachers as well as self
control and walking in the footsteps of virtuous men-these qualities are worthy of you, born as you
are in the Raghu dynasty."_END

B_2_C_90_17
BEGIN_
जाने च एतन् मनह्स्थम् ते दृढी करणम् अस्तु इति |
अपृग्च्छम् त्वाम् तव अत्यर्थम् कीर्तिम् समभिवर्धयन् || २-९०-२१_END
BEGIN_
" I was aware of your purpose in your mind. But, I desired to confirm it and it is
on this account that I asked you, in order to strengthen you fame immeasurably."_END

B_2_C_90_18
BEGIN_
जाने च रामं धर्मज्ञं ससीतं सहलक्ष्मणम् |
असौ वसति ते भ्राता चित्र कूटे महा गिरौ || २-९०-२२_END
BEGIN_
"I know where the virtuous Rama along with Seetha and LakSmana are to be found. Your
elder brother is staying on the great mountain called Chitrakuta."_END

B_2_C_90_19
BEGIN_
श्वः तु गन्ता असि तम् देशम् वस अद्य सह मन्त्रिभिः |
एतम् मे कुरु सुप्राज्न कामम् काम अर्थ कोविद || २-९०-२३_END
BEGIN_
"You may proceed to that place tomorrow. Stay here today along with your ministers.
O, man of great wisdom, who understands legitimate interest and desire! Grant me this desire."_END

B_2_C_90_20
BEGIN_
ततः तथा इत्य् एवम् उदार दर्शनः |
प्रतीत रूपो भरतो अब्रवीद् वचः |
चकार बुद्धिम् च तदा महा आश्रमे |
निशा निवासाय नर अधिप आत्मजः || २-९०-२४_END
BEGIN_
Bharata of a broad outlook and whose reality (as an admirer of Rama) had now come to
be known, answered thus: "So be it". Then, the prince made up his mind to stay for that night in
the hermitage."_END

B_2_C_91_0
BEGIN_
कृत बुद्धिम् निवासाय तथैव स मुनिः तदा |
भरतम् कैकयी पुत्रम् आतिथ्येन न्यमन्त्रयत् || २-९१-१_END
BEGIN_
Seeing he had resolved to halt at that place for the night, the sage Bharadwaja
prepared to offer Bharata the son of Kaikeyi the full honours due to a guest_END

B_2_C_91_1
BEGIN_
अब्रवीद् भरतः तु एनम् ननु इदम् भवता कृतम् |
पाद्यम् अर्घ्यम् तथा आतिथ्यम् वने यद् ऊपपद्यते || २-९१-२_END
BEGIN_
Then, Bharata said to Bharadwaja as follows: "Have you not presented me with water
to wash my hands and feet and offered me this hospitality fitting for a guest in this forest?"_END

B_2_C_91_2
BEGIN_
अथ उवाच भरद्वाजो भरतम् प्रहसन्न् इव |
जाने त्वाम् प्रीति सम्युक्तम् तुष्येः त्वम् येन केनचित् || २-९१-३_END
BEGIN_
Then, Bharadwaja smilingly replied to Bharata as follows: "I know you possess a
friendly disposition and you are pleased with whatever is offered to you."_END

B_2_C_91_3
BEGIN_
सेनायाः तु तव एतस्याः कर्तुम् इग्च्छामि भोजनम् |
मम प्रितिर् यथा रूपा त्वम् अर्हो मनुज ऋषभ || २-९१-४_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata the excellent among men! I wish to offer food to your army. You ought to
fulfil my satisfaction in every suitable way."_END

B_2_C_91_4
BEGIN_
किम् अर्थम् च अपि निक्षिप्य दूरे बलम् इह आगतः |
कस्मान् न इह उपयातो असि सबलः पुरुष ऋषभ || २-९१-५_END
BEGIN_
"O, warrior! Why did you come here, leaving your army at a distance? Why did you not
come to my place with your army?"_END

B_2_C_91_5
BEGIN_
भरतः प्रत्युवाच इदम् प्रान्जलिः तम् तपो धनम् |
ससैन्यो न उपयातो अस्मि भगवन् भगवद् भयात् || २-९१-६_END
BEGIN_
Bharata, with joined palms, replied to Bharadwaja who was rich with austerity in the
following words: "O, venerable one! I have not come here with my army for the fear of displeasing
you."_END

B_2_C_91_6
BEGIN_
राज्ञा च भगवन्नित्यं राजपुत्रेण वा सदा |
यत्नतः परिहर्तव्या विषयेषु तपस्विनः || २-९१-७_END
BEGIN_
"O, Venerable One! Either the king or the prince should always keep away from the
places occupied by ascetics"_END

B_2_C_91_7
BEGIN_
वाजि मुख्या मनुष्याः च मत्ताः च वर वारणाः |
प्रग्च्छाद्य महतीम् भूमिम् भगवन्न् अनुयान्ति माम् || २-९१-८_END
BEGIN_
"O, Holy one! Spirited horses, men and rare elephants in rut covering an immense
area are accompanying me."_END

B_2_C_91_8
BEGIN_
ते वृक्षान् उदकम् भूमिम् आश्रमेषु उटजामः तथा |
न हिंस्युर् इति तेन अहम् एक एव आगतः ततः || २-९१-९_END
BEGIN_
"Let them not damage the trees, huts and ground and defile the waters of hermitages'
- in this thought, I came alone."_END

B_2_C_91_9
BEGIN_
आनीयताम् इतः सेना इत्य् आज्नप्तः परम ऋषिणा |
तथा तु चक्रे भरतः सेनायाः समुपागमम् || २-९१-१०_END
BEGIN_
Thereafter Bharata, having been commanded by that great sage to bring the army
there, allowed the army's arrival to the hermitage._END

B_2_C_91_10
BEGIN_
अग्नि शालाम् प्रविश्य अथ पीत्वा अपः परिमृज्य च |
आतिथ्यस्य क्रिया हेतोर् विश्व कर्माणम् आह्वयत् || २-९१-११_END
BEGIN_
Meanwhile, entering the fire-sanctuary (the place where the sacrificial fire is
kept), sipping water and wiping the lips, Bharadwaja invoked Visvakarma (the architect of gods) in
order to fulfil his duties towards the guests (as follows)_END

B_2_C_91_11
BEGIN_
आह्वये विश्व कर्माणम् अहम् त्वष्टारम् एव च |
आतिथ्यम् कर्तुम् इग्च्छामि तत्र मे सम्विधीयताम् || २-९१-१२_END
BEGIN_
"I wish to offer hospitality to the guest I summon vishvakarma who is also the
divine carpenter. Let arrangements be made in that connection for me."_END

B_2_C_91_12
BEGIN_
अह्वये लोकपालां स्त्रीन् देवान् शक्रमुखांस्तथा |
आतिथ्यं कर्तुमिच्चामि तत्र मे संविधीयताम् || २-९१-१३_END
BEGIN_
"I further invoke the three gods (Yama, Varuna and Kubera) the guardians of the
worlds with Indra as their king. I wish to offer hospitality to the guests. Let arrangements be
made in this connection for me."_END

B_2_C_91_13
BEGIN_
प्राक् स्रोतसः च या नद्यः प्रत्यक् स्रोतस एव च |
पृथिव्याम् अन्तरिक्षे च समायान्तु अद्य सर्वशः || २-९१-१४_END
BEGIN_
"Let the rivers which flow towards the east and those which flow towards the west,
across the earth and in the aerial region now come together here from all quarters."_END

B_2_C_91_14
BEGIN_
अन्याः स्रवन्तु मैरेयम् सुराम् अन्याः सुनिष्ठिताम् |
अपराः च उदकम् शीतम् इक्षु काण्ड रस उपमम् || २-९१-१५_END
BEGIN_
"Let some rivers flow with Maireya ( a kind of wine made from date palms etc) some
others flow with highly refined spirituous liquor and some others flow with cool water with a taste
of sugarcane."_END

B_2_C_91_15
BEGIN_
आह्वये देव गन्धर्वान् विश्वा वसु हहा हुहून् |
तथैव अप्सरसो देवीर् गन्धर्वीः च अपि सर्वशः || २-९१-१६_END
BEGIN_
"I invoke the celestials and celestial musicians Vishvavasu, Haha and Huhu as also
Apsaras (nymphs) belonging to the celestial and celestial musicians' race from all regions._END

B_2_C_91_16
BEGIN_
घृताचीम् अथ विश्वाचीम् मिश्र केशीम् अलम्बुसाम् |
नागदन्तां च हेमां च हिमामद्रिकृतस्थलाम् || २-९१-१७_END
BEGIN_
"I invoke the celestial nymphs called ghritachi, Vishvachi, Mishra Kesi, Alambusa,
Nagadanta and Hema as also Hima who has an abode made in mountains."_END

B_2_C_91_17
BEGIN_
शक्रम् याः च उपतिष्ठन्ति ब्रह्माणम् याः च भामिनीः |
सर्वाः तुम्बुरुणा सार्धम् आह्वये सपरिग्च्छदाः || २-९१-१८_END
BEGIN_
"I invoke the fair women who are attending on Brahma the Lord of creation - all of
them with their external appendages (like musical instruments) along with (their teacher)
Tumburu."_END

B_2_C_91_18
BEGIN_
वनम् कुरुषु यद् दिव्यम् वासो भूषण पत्रवत् |
दिव्य नारी फलम् शश्वत् तत् कौबेरम् इह एव तु || २-९१-१९_END
BEGIN_
"Let that beautiful garden in the region of northern Kuru, presided over by Kubera
(the god of riches) always with its leaves which serve as raiment and ornaments, with its fruits in
the form of heavenly damsels appear in this place."_END

B_2_C_91_19
BEGIN_
इह मे भगवान् सोमो विधत्ताम् अन्नम् उत्तमम् |
भक्ष्यम् भोज्यम् च चोष्यम् च लेह्यम् च विविधम् बहु || २-९१-२०_END
BEGIN_
"Many the blessed moon-god (the duty presiding over annual plants) furnish me at
this place, excellent food of every variety, confections, sweets, sauces and syrups."_END

B_2_C_91_20
BEGIN_
विचित्राणि च माल्यानि पादप प्रच्युतानि च |
सुरा आदीनि च पेयानि मांसानि विविधानि च || २-९१-२१_END
BEGIN_
"May the blessed moon-god furnish me many-coloured flowers which have just fallen
from the flower-plants or trees, the drinks like wine and others as also various kinds of
meat."_END

B_2_C_91_21
BEGIN_
एवम् समाधिना युक्तः तेजसा अप्रतिमेन च |
शिक्षा स्वर समायुक्तम् तपसा च अब्रवीन् मुनिः || २-९१-२२_END
BEGIN_
That sage Bharadwaja, with his intense meditation, possessing unequal splendour and
with austerity, spoke as follows, in tones befitting proper articulation and pronunciation of the
scriptural texts:_END

B_2_C_91_22
BEGIN_
मनसा ध्यायतः तस्य प्रान् मुखस्य कृत अन्जलेः |
आजग्मुः तानि सर्वाणि दैवतानि पृथक् पृथक् || २-९१-२३_END
BEGIN_
While that sage Bharadwaja, with joined palms, was meditating with absorption in the
east, all those celestials came one by one._END

B_2_C_91_23
BEGIN_
मलयम् दुर्दुरम् चैव ततः स्वेद नुदो अनिलः |
उपस्पृश्य ववौ युक्त्या सुप्रिय आत्मा सुखः शिवः || २-९१-२४_END
BEGIN_
Then, a pleasant comfortable and gracious breeze, passing over the mountains of
Malaya and Dardura, began to blw, removing sweat by its influence._END

B_2_C_91_24
BEGIN_
ततो अभ्यवर्तन्त घना दिव्याः कुसुम वृष्टयः |
देव दुन्दुभि घोषः च दिक्षु सर्वासु शुश्रुवे || २-९१-२५_END
BEGIN_
Thereafter wonderful clouds let loose a rain of flowers, while the sound of divine
gongs could be heard on every side._END

B_2_C_91_25
BEGIN_
प्रववुः च उत्तमा वाता ननृतुः च अप्सरो गणाः |
प्रजगुर् देव गन्धर्वा वीणा प्रमुमुचुः स्वरान् || २-९१-२६_END
BEGIN_
Troops of Apsaras (divine nymphs) danced to the melodious rustling of the wind. The
clestials and the celestial musicians sang. Vinas, stringed musical instruments transmitted their
tunes._END

B_2_C_91_26
BEGIN_
स शब्दो द्याम् च भूमिम् च प्राणिनाम् श्रवणानि च |
विवेश उच्चारितः श्लक्ष्णः समो लय गुण अन्वितः || २-९१-२७_END
BEGIN_
Sweat and harmonious sounds emitted smoothly, entered the sky earth and the ears of
beings._END

B_2_C_91_27
BEGIN_
तस्मिन्न् उपरते शब्दे दिव्ये श्रोत्र सुखे नृणाम् |
ददर्श भारतम् सैन्यम् विधानम् विश्व कर्मणः || २-९१-२८_END
BEGIN_
When those celestial melodies ceased so pleasingly heard by the human ears,
Bharata's army saw the wonderful creations of Visvakarma._END

B_2_C_91_28
BEGIN_
बभूव हि समा भूमिः समन्तात् पन्च योजनम् |
शाद्वलैर् बहुभिः चन्ना नील वैदूर्य सम्निभैः || २-९१-२९_END
BEGIN_
A levelled land of approximately twenty miles on all sides, became covered by many
carpets of grass, dark as emerald._END

B_2_C_91_29
BEGIN_
तस्मिन् बिल्वाः कपित्थाः च पनसा बीज पूरकाः |
आमलक्यो बभूवुः च चूताः च फल भूषणाः || २-९१-३०_END
BEGIN_
At that place, Bilva, Kapittha, Panasa, Citron Amalaki and Mango Trees laden with
fruit appeared._END

B_2_C_91_30
BEGIN_
उत्तरेभ्यः कुरुभ्यः च वनम् दिव्य उपभोगवत् |
आजगाम नदी दिव्या तीरजैर् बहुभिर् वृता || २-९१-३१_END
BEGIN_
A forest of divine enjoyments from the territory of northern Kuru's along with a
river shaped with various trees on its bank appeared there._END

B_2_C_91_31
BEGIN_
चतुः शालानि शुभ्राणि शालाः च गज वाजिनाम् |
हर्म्य प्रासाद सम्घाताः तोरणानि शुभानि च || २-९१-३२_END
BEGIN_
Splendid square mansions with stables for elephants and horses as well as
resplendent gates with watch-towers flanked by turrets were seen._END

B_2_C_91_32
BEGIN_
सित मेघ निभम् च अपि राज वेश्म सुतोरणम् |
शुक्ल माल्य कृत आकारम् दिव्य गन्ध समुक्षितम् || २-९१-३३
चतुर् अस्रम् असम्बाधम् शयन आसन यानवत् |
दिव्यैः सर्व रसैर् युक्तम् दिव्य भोजन वस्त्रवत् || २-९१-३४
उपकल्पित सर्व अन्नम् धौत निर्मल भाजनम् |
क्लृप्त सर्व आसनम् श्रीमत् स्वास्तीर्ण शयन उत्तमम् || २-९१-३५_END
BEGIN_
A royal palace emerged, dazzling as a cloud, pierced by splendid arches, hung with
white garlands, filled with fragrance of celestial perfumes, forming a perfect quadrangle,
spacious, furnished with couches seats and palanquins, supplied with ambrosial drinks of every kind
as well as magnificent attire and food of every variety, well-prepared eatables of every
description in cleaned vessels free from dirt and all kinds of seats arranged in order looked
charming with superb couches duly covered with rich carpets._END

B_2_C_91_33
BEGIN_
प्रविवेश महा बाहुर् अनुज्नातो महर्षिणा |
वेश्म तद् रत्न सम्पूर्णम् भरतः कैकयी सुतः || २-९१-३६_END
BEGIN_
The mighty armed Bharata the son of Kaikeyi on invitation by the great sage, entered
that palace filled with precious gems._END

B_2_C_91_34
BEGIN_
अनुजग्मुः च तम् सर्वे मन्त्रिणः सपुरोहिताः |
बभूवुः च मुदा युक्ता तम् दृष्ट्वा वेश्म सम्विधिम् || २-९१-३७_END
BEGIN_
All the ministers together with priests accompanied Bharata and on entering that
excellent get-up of the house, were filled with delight_END

B_2_C_91_35
BEGIN_
तत्र राज आसनम् दिव्यम् व्यजनम् चत्रम् एव च |
भरतो मन्त्रिभिः सार्धम् अभ्यवर्तत राजवत् || २-९१-३८_END
BEGIN_
Bharata along with his ministers went clock-wise round the excellent royal throne,
whisk and the royal umbrella kept there, as if they were utilized by a king._END

B_2_C_91_36
BEGIN_
आसनम् पूजयाम् आस रामाय अभिप्रणम्य च |
वाल व्यजनम् आदाय न्यषीदत् सचिव आसने || २-९१-३९_END
BEGIN_
They paid reverence to the royal seat, bowing before it, as if Rama sat thereon and
thereafter Bharata, taking hold of the whisk, sat down on the seat meant for the chief
minister._END

B_2_C_91_37
BEGIN_
आनुपूर्व्यान् निषेदुः च सर्वे मन्त्र पुरोहिताः |
ततः सेना पतिः पश्चात् प्रशास्ता च निषेदतुः || २-९१-४०_END
BEGIN_
All the ministers and priests sat down in order of precedence. Thereafter, the chief
of the army and at last the officer-in-charge of the encampment occupied their seats._END

B_2_C_91_38
BEGIN_
ततः तत्र मुहूर्तेन नद्यः पायस कर्दमाः |
उपातिष्ठन्त भरतम् भरद्वाजस्य शासनत् || २-९१-४१_END
BEGIN_
Then, on an instant, by the orders of Bharadwaja, streams having milk thickened with
rice in the place of mud, flowed towards Bharata._END

B_2_C_91_39
BEGIN_
तासाम् उभयतः कूलम् पाण्डु मृत्तिक लेपनाः |
रम्याः च आवसथा दिव्या ब्रह्मणः तु प्रसादजाः || २-९१-४२_END
BEGIN_
On both the banks of those streams, enchanting and celestial houses plastered with
white clay born out of the grace of Brahma the Lord of creation, appeared._END

B_2_C_91_40
BEGIN_
तेन एव च मुहूर्तेन दिव्य आभरण भूषिताः |
आगुर् विंशति साहस्राः ब्राह्मणा प्रहिताः स्त्रियः || २-९१-४३_END
BEGIN_
At that moment itself, twenty thousand women adorned with beautiful ornaments, sent
by Brahma, arrived._END

B_2_C_91_41
BEGIN_
सुवर्ण मणि मुक्तेन प्रवालेन च शोभिताः |
आगुर् विंशति साहस्राः कुबेर प्रहिताः स्त्रियः || २-९१-४४_END
BEGIN_
Twenty thousand more women, who were radiant and adorned with gold, gems, pearls and
corals came from the region of Kubera._END

B_2_C_91_42
BEGIN_
याभिर् गृहीतः पुरुषः स उन्माद इव लक्ष्यते |
आगुर् विंशति साहस्रा नन्दनाद् अप्सरो गणाः || २-९१-४५_END
BEGIN_
A particular company of Apsaras, embraced by whom, a man looked as though seized
with insanity, came from Nandana grove._END

B_2_C_91_43
BEGIN_
नारदः तुम्बुरुर् गोपः पर्वतः सूर्य वर्चसः |
एते गन्धर्व राजानो भरतस्य अग्रतो जगुः || २-९१-४६_END
BEGIN_
Those most excellent kings among celestial musicians - Narada, Tumbura and Gopa
whose radiance is like that of the sun, began to sing in front of Bharata._END

B_2_C_91_44
BEGIN_
अलम्बुसा मिश्र केशी पुण्डरीका अथ वामना |
उपानृत्यमः तु भरतम् भरद्वाजस्य शासनात् || २-९१-४७_END
BEGIN_
Then, on the command of Bharadwaja, Alambusa, MishraKesi and Vamana started dancing
in the presence of Bharata._END

B_2_C_91_45
BEGIN_
यानि माल्यानि देवेषु यानि चैत्ररथे वने |
प्रयागे तान्य् अदृश्यन्त भरद्वाजस्य शासनात् || २-९१-४८_END
BEGIN_
By the command of Bharadwaja, wreaths of flowers which were beloved of the gods or
those which grow in the woods of chaitra ratha were seen at Prayaga._END

B_2_C_91_46
BEGIN_
बिल्वा मार्दन्गिका आसन् शम्या ग्राहा बिभीतकाः |
अश्वत्था नर्तकाः च आसन् भरद्वाजस्य तेजसा || २-९१-४९_END
BEGIN_
By the command of Bharadwaja, Bel trees assumed the form of drummers, Vibhitaka
trees assumed the form of cymbalists and Peepul trees assumed the form of dancers._END

B_2_C_91_47
BEGIN_
ततः सरल तालाः च तिलका नक्त मालकाः |
प्रहृष्टाः तत्र सम्पेतुः कुब्जा भूता अथ वामनाः || २-९१-५०_END
BEGIN_
Then, dcodars palmyras and Tilaka trees along with Tamala trees transformed into
hunch backs and dwarfs and joyfully arrived there._END

B_2_C_91_48
BEGIN_
शिंशपा आमलकी जम्बूर् याः च अन्याः कानने लताः |
मालती मल्लिका जातिर्याश्चान्याः कानने लताः || २-९१-५१
प्रमदा विग्रहम् कृत्वा भरद्वाज आश्रमे अवसन् |_END
BEGIN_
Shimshapas (Ashoka trees), Amalakis (Emblic myrobalan), Jambus (rose-apple trees),
Malati, Mallika Jati and other creepers in the forest had been changed into dancing girls in the
hermitage of Bharadwaja and they spoke as follows:_END

B_2_C_91_49
BEGIN_
सुराम् सुरापाः पिबत पायसम् च बुभुक्षिताः || २-९१-५२
मांसनि च सुमेध्यानि भक्ष्यन्ताम् यावद् इग्च्छथ || २-९१-५३_END
BEGIN_
"O, wine-bibbers! Drink the wine, however much you desire! O troops stricken with
hunger! Let milk thickened iwth rice and the meats which are very much fresh, be eaten (as you
will)"_END

B_2_C_91_50
BEGIN_
उत्साद्य स्नापयन्ति स्म नदी तीरेषु वल्गुषु |
अप्य् एकम् एकम् पुरुषम् प्रमदाः सत्प च अष्ट च || २-९१-५४_END
BEGIN_
Seven or eight young women bathed every single man on the beautiful river-banks,
after massaging their body with oil._END

B_2_C_91_51
BEGIN_
सम्वहन्त्यः समापेतुर् नार्यो रुचिर लोचनाः |
परिमृज्य तथा न्यायम् पाययन्ति वर अन्गनाः || २-९१-५५_END
BEGIN_
Women with charming eyes came running and shampooed their limbs. Lovely women
likewise wiped off the moisture on their body with towels and gave them beverages to drink,
mutually sharing them among each other._END

B_2_C_91_52
BEGIN_
हयान् गजान् खरान् उष्ट्रामः तथैव सुरभेः सुतान् |
अभोजयन् वाहनपास्तेषां भोज्यं यथाविधि || २-९१-५६_END
BEGIN_
The keepers of animals fed horses, elephants, donkeys, camels and bullocks (the
offspring of Surabhi the divine cow) with their suitable feed._END

B_2_C_91_53
BEGIN_
इक्षूमः च मधु जालामः च भोजयन्ति स्म वाहनान् |
इक्ष्वाकु वर योधानाम् चोदयन्तो महा बलाः || २-९१-५७_END
BEGIN_
The animals, belonging to the exceedingly strong and illustrious warriors, the
descendents of Ikshvaku, were fed with pieces of sugarcane and roasted grain soaked in honey, duly
cajoling them to eat._END

B_2_C_91_54
BEGIN_
न अश्व बन्धो अश्वम् आजानान् न गजम् कुन्जर ग्रहः |
मत्त प्रमत्त मुदिता चमूः सा तत्र सम्बभौ || २-९१-५८_END
BEGIN_
The groom did not recognise his horse. The elephant-keeper did not recognise his
elephant. That army there appeared intoxicated, maddened and enraptured on that spot._END

B_2_C_91_55
BEGIN_
तर्पिता सर्व कामैः ते रक्त चन्दन रूषिताः |
अप्सरो गण सम्युक्ताः सैन्या वाचम् उदैरयन् || २-९१-५९_END
BEGIN_
With all their desires gratified, their bodies anointed with red-sandal paste, and
surrounded by a company of Apsaras, those soldiers uttered the following words._END

B_2_C_91_56
BEGIN_
न एव अयोध्याम् गमिष्यामो न गमिष्याम दण्डकान् |
कुशलम् भरतस्य अस्तु रामस्य अस्तु तथा सुखम् || २-९१-६०_END
BEGIN_
"We shall not go either to Ayodhya or to Dandaka forest. Let Bharata be well!
Likewise, let Rama too be at east!"_END

B_2_C_91_57
BEGIN_
इति पादात योधाः च हस्त्य् अश्व आरोह बन्धकाः |
अनाथाः तम् विधिम् लब्ध्वा वाचम् एताम् उदैरयन् || २-९१-६१_END
BEGIN_
Having obtained that hospitality, the infantry, the cavalry as well as those mounted
on elephants and their keepers too, no longer acknowledging their leaders, spoke the following
words:_END

B_2_C_91_58
BEGIN_
सम्प्रहृष्टा विनेदुः ते नराः तत्र सहस्रशः |
भरतस्य अनुयातारः स्वर्गे अयम् इति च अब्रुवन् || २-९१-६२_END
BEGIN_
In the height of joy, those men in thousands there, the retinue of Bharata cried
out, "This is verily of heaven!"_END

B_2_C_91_59
BEGIN_
नृत्यन्ति स्म हसन्तिस्म गायन्ति स्म च सैनिकाः |
समन्तात् परिधावन्ति माल्यो पेताः सहस्रशः || २-९१-६३_END
BEGIN_
The soldiers in thousands, wreathed in flowers danced, laughed, sang and ran hither
and thither._END

B_2_C_91_60
BEGIN_
ततो भुक्तवताम् तेषाम् तद् अन्नम् अमृत उपमम् |
दिव्यान् उद्वीक्ष्य भक्ष्यामः तान् अभवद् भक्षणे मतिः || २-९१-६४_END
BEGIN_
To those soldiers who had partaken that food which was as sweet as ambrosia, when
they saw again those fresh dishes, there arose in them a desire to eat them again._END

B_2_C_91_61
BEGIN_
प्रेष्याः चेट्यः च वध्वः च बलस्थाः च अपि सर्वशः |
बभूवुः ते भृशम् तृप्ताः सर्वे च आहत वाससः || २-९१-६५_END
BEGIN_
Thousands of servants, slaves, youthful women and those in the army on every side,
clad in new raiment, became very much contented._END

B_2_C_91_62
BEGIN_
कुन्जराः च खर उष्ट्रः च गो अश्वाः च मृग पक्षिणः |
बभूवुः सुभृताः तत्र न अन्यो ह्य् अन्यम् अकल्पयत् || २-९१-६६_END
BEGIN_
Elephants, donkeys, camels, bullocks, horses, animals and birds there were suitably
well-fed. Hence, one did not afflict the other._END

B_2_C_91_63
BEGIN_
न अशुक्ल वासाः तत्र आसीत् क्षुधितो मलिनो अपि वा |
रजसा ध्वस्त केशो वा नरः कश्चिद् अदृश्यत || २-९१-६७_END
BEGIN_
There was no one seen in soiled attire or hungry or unkept or with hair powdered
with dust._END

B_2_C_91_64
BEGIN_
आजैः च अपि च वाराहैर् निष्टान वर संचयैः |
फल निर्यूह संसिद्धैः सूपैर् गन्ध रस अन्वितैः || २-९१-६८
पुष्प ध्वजवतीः पूर्णाः शुक्लस्य अन्नस्य च अभितः |
ददृशुर् विस्मिताः तत्र नरा लौहीः सहस्रशः || २-९१-६९_END
BEGIN_
Dishes of goat and boar with delicious sauces were there and condiments that were
spicy, fragrant and succulent, cooked in fruit juices; vessels of rare metals filled with rice,
decorated with flowers, were offered in thousands to those soldiers there. The soldiers saw them
with wonder on all sides._END

B_2_C_91_65
BEGIN_
बभूवुर् वन पार्श्वेषु कूपाः पायस कर्दमाः |
ताः च कामदुघा गावो द्रुमाः च आसन् मधुश्च्युतः || २-९१-७०_END
BEGIN_
The wells in various sides of the forest (surrounding Bharadwaja's hermitage) have
their mud transformed into milk in which rice was cooked. The cows in the region were transformed
into cows of plenty and the trees dripped honey._END

B_2_C_91_66
BEGIN_
वाप्यो मैरेय पूर्णाः च मृष्ट मांस चयैर् वृताः |
प्रतप्त पिठरैः च अपि मार्ग मायूर कौक्कुटैः || २-९१-७१_END
BEGIN_
Some ponds there were endowed with full of wine and some were filled with assortment
of various dressed meats pertaining to deer, peacocks and wild cocks; cooked in hot pans._END

B_2_C_91_67
BEGIN_
पात्रीणाम् च सहस्राणि शात कुम्भमयानि च |
स्थाल्यः कुम्भ्यः करम्भ्यः च दधि पूर्णाः सुसंस्कृताः || २-९१-७२
यौवनस्थस्य गौरस्य कपित्थस्य सुगन्धिनः |_END
BEGIN_
There were thousands of portable furnaces, lacs of culinary utensils ten crores of
golden vessels, well-cleaned bowls filled with curds, small water-jars and wide-mouthed dishes._END

B_2_C_91_68
BEGIN_
ह्रदाः पूर्णा रसालस्य दध्नः श्वेतस्य च अपरे |
बभूवुः पायसस्य अन्ते शर्करायाः च संचयाः || २-९१-७३
कल्कामः चूर्ण कषायामः च स्नानानि विविधानि च |
ददृशुर् भाजनस्थानि तीर्थेषु सरिताम् नराः || २-९१-७४_END
BEGIN_
Lakes full of fresh curds, shining fragrant and in the colour of a wood-apple, curds
mixed with sugar and spices, some other lakes filled with shite curds, some others filled with milk
soaked in rice as well as sugar and some other lakes with a mixture of barley and sugar were
formed._END

B_2_C_91_69
BEGIN_
कल्कान् चूर्णकषायांश्च स्नानानि विविधानि च |
ददृशुर्भाजनस्थानि तीर्थेषु सरितां नराः || २-९१-७५_END
BEGIN_
Those soldiers saw jellies, powders and syrups made of fruits and various kinds of
accessories used in bathing, kept stored in vessels, on the banks of rivers._END

B_2_C_91_70
BEGIN_
शुक्लान् अंशुमतः च अपि दन्त धावन संचयान् |
शुक्लामः चन्दन कल्कामः च समुद्गेषु अवतिष्ठतः || २-९१-७६
दर्पणान् परिमृष्टामः च वाससाम् च अपि संचयान् |
पादुक उपानहाम् चैव युग्मान् यत्र सहस्रशः ||२-९१-७७
आन्जनीः कन्कतान् कूर्चामः चत्राणि च धनूम्षि च |
मर्म त्राणानि चित्राणि शयनान्य् आसनानि च || २-९१-७८
प्रतिपान ह्रदान् पूर्णान् खर उष्ट्र गज वाजिनाम् |
अवगाह्य सुतीर्थामः च ह्रदान् स उत्पल पुष्करान् || २-९१-७९
नील वैदूर्य वर्णामः च मृदून् यवस संचयान् |
निर्वाप अर्थम् पशूनाम् ते ददृशुः तत्र सर्वशः || २-९१-८०_END
BEGIN_
Those soldiers saw there heaps of twings used for cleaning the teeth with white
brushes at their tips, white sandal pastes stored in caskets, polished mirrors, piles of clothes,
thousands of pairs of shoes and sandals, caskets containing collyrium for the eyes; combs, brushed,
raiments bows, protectors of vitals, strange couches and seats, drinking ponds for donkeys camels
elephants and horses, lakes with good stairs for descent having water-lilies and lotuses with
sky-blue colour, with clear water offering a comfortable bath and soft grasses having a colour of
Nipa tree and of cat's eye gems useful for feeding animals._END

B_2_C_91_71
BEGIN_
व्यस्मयन्त मनुष्यस्ते स्वप्नकल्फं तदद्भुतं |
दृष्ट्वाऽतिथ्यं कृतं तादृग्भरतस्य महार्षिणा २-९१-८१_END
BEGIN_
Seeing such a wonderful and dreamlike hospitality offered by the great sage
Bharadwaja, all those men were surprised._END

B_2_C_91_72
BEGIN_
इत्य् एवम् रममाणानाम् देवानाम् इव नन्दने |
भरद्वाज आश्रमे रम्ये सा रात्रिर् व्यत्यवर्तत || २-९१-८२_END
BEGIN_
While they were enjoying thus in that charming hermitage of Bharadwaja, in the same
manner as celestials enjoy the garden of Nandna, that night had elapsed._END

B_2_C_91_73
BEGIN_
प्रतिजग्मुः च ता नद्यो गन्धर्वाः च यथा आगतम् |
भरद्वाजम् अनुज्नाप्य ताः च सर्वा वर अन्गनाः || २-९१-८३_END
BEGIN_
Having been permitted by Bharadwaja, those rivers, the celestial musicians and all
those beautiful women went back by the same way they came._END

B_2_C_91_74
BEGIN_
तथैव मत्ता मदिर उत्कटा नराः |
तथैव दिव्य अगुरु चन्दन उक्षिताः |
तथैव दिव्या विविधाः स्रग् उत्तमाः |
पृथक् प्रकीर्णा मनुजैः प्रमर्दिताः || २-९१-८४_END
BEGIN_
The soldiers, intoxicated with spirituous liquor, were likewise excited with joy.
Likewise, the men were drenched in charming aloes and sandal paste. Various kinds of excellent and
charming garlands were there, crushed and garlands were there, crushed and scattered at distances,
likewise._END

B_2_C_92_0
BEGIN_
ततः ताम् रजनीम् उष्य भरतः सपरिग्च्छदः |
कृत आतिथ्यो भरद्वाजम् कामाद् अभिजगाम ह || २-९२-१_END
BEGIN_
Thereafter, Bharata along with his routine, who were treated hospitably, spent that
night there and sought out Bharadwaja with fondness._END

B_2_C_92_1
BEGIN_
तम् ऋषिः पुरुष व्याघ्रम् प्रेक्ष्य प्रान्जलिम् आगतम् |
हुत अग्नि होत्रो भरतम् भरद्वाजो अभ्यभाषत || २-९२-२_END
BEGIN_
The sage Bharadwaja, who had offered oblations in sacred fire, spoke to Bharata the
tiger among men, who had come there with joined palms, saying._END

B_2_C_92_2
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् अत्र सुखा रात्रिः तव अस्मद् विषये गता |
समग्रः ते जनः कच्चिद् आतिथ्ये शंस मे अनघ || २-९२-३_END
BEGIN_
"O, handsome Bharata! Have you passed this night at out place comfortably? Is your
retinue fully satisfied with my hospitality? Tell me."_END

B_2_C_92_3
BEGIN_
तम् उवाच अन्जलिम् कृत्वा भरतो अभिप्रणम्य च |
आश्रमाद् अभिनिष्क्रन्तम् ऋषिम् उत्तम तेजसम् || २-९२-४_END
BEGIN_
After joining his palms in salutation, Bharata replied to the very glorious sage
Bharawaja, who came out from his hermitage (as follows):_END

B_2_C_92_4
BEGIN_
सुख उषितो अस्मि भगवन् समग्र बल वाहनः |
तर्पितः सर्व कामैः च सामात्यो बलवत् त्वया || २-९२-५_END
BEGIN_
"O, venerable sage! With all the enjoyments in plenty provided by you, I felt
comfortable and satisfied, along with very ministers my entire army and our animals too used in
riding._END

B_2_C_92_5
BEGIN_
अपेत क्लम सम्तापाः सुभक्ष्याः सुप्रतिश्रयाः |
अपि प्रेष्यान् उपादाय सर्वे स्म सुसुख उषिताः || २-९२-६_END
BEGIN_
"All of us including our servants have become very much satisfied with our fatigue
and pains removed, having eaten a good food and having been provided an excellent
accommodation."_END

B_2_C_92_6
BEGIN_
आमन्त्रये अहम् भगवन् कामम् त्वाम् ऋषि सत्तम |
समीपम् प्रस्थितम् भ्रातुर् मैरेण ईक्षस्व चक्षुषा || २-९२-७_END
BEGIN_
"O, Blessed one! O, excellent sage I am taking leave of you. Look on me with favour
as I find myself in my brother's vicinity."_END

B_2_C_92_7
BEGIN_
आश्रमम् तस्य धर्मज्न धार्मिकस्य महात्मनः |
आचक्ष्व कतमो मार्गः कियान् इति च शंस मे || २-९२-८_END
BEGIN_
"O, knower of piety! Tell me about the abode of that high-souled and pious man,
