Rama. Tell me as to which way I have to go, how much distance it is from here and so forth."_END

B_2_C_92_8
BEGIN_
इति पृष्टः तु भरतम् भ्रातृ दर्शन लालसम् |
प्रत्युवाच महा तेजा भरद्वाजो महा तपाः || २-९२-९_END
BEGIN_
The highly glorious Bharadwaaja, of rigid asceticism, thus questioned by Bharata
(who intensely desired to see his brother again), answered him as follows:_END

B_2_C_92_9
BEGIN_
भरत अर्ध तृतीयेषु योजनेषु अजने वने |
चित्र कूटो गिरिः तत्र रम्य निर्दर काननः || २-९२-१०_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata! About twenty eight miles from here, there is a mountain called
Chitrakuta, in the middle of a lonely forest with its charming Cascades and groves."_END

B_2_C_92_10
BEGIN_
उत्तरम् पार्श्वम् आसाद्य तस्य मन्दाकिनी नदी |
पुष्पित द्रुम संचन्ना रम्य पुष्पित कानना || २-९२-११_END
BEGIN_
"Going towards its northern side, you will find River Mandakini, which is entirely
enveloped with flowering trees and having forests flourished with charming blossoms."_END

B_2_C_92_11
BEGIN_
अनन्तरम् तत् सरितः चित्र कूटः च पर्वतः |
ततो पर्ण कुटी तात तत्र तौ वसतो ध्रुवम् || २-९२-१२_END
BEGIN_
"O, beloved Bharata! Beyond that river, there is a mountain called Chitrakuta and on
it, their hut made of leafy twigs. Both of them are residing there. It is sure."_END

B_2_C_92_12
BEGIN_
दक्षिणेन एव मार्गेण सव्य दक्षिणम् एव च |
गज वाजि रथ आकीर्णाम् वाहिनीम् वाहिनी पते || २-९२-१३
वाहयस्व महा भाग ततो द्रक्ष्यसि राघवम् |_END
BEGIN_
"O, the illustrious chief of army! Direct the forces filled with elephants horses
and chariots either towards the southern route or to the left proceeding southward. You can see
Rama then."_END

B_2_C_92_13
BEGIN_
प्रयाणम् इति च श्रुत्वा राज राजस्य योषितः |
हित्वा यानानि यान अर्हा ब्राह्मणम् पर्यवारयन् || २-९२-१४_END
BEGIN_
Hearing him speak of the journey, Dasaratha's wives eligible of sitting in
palanquins, descended from their palanquins and stood encircling Bharadwaja._END

B_2_C_92_14
BEGIN_
वेपमाना कृशा दीना सह देव्या सुमन्त्रिया |
कौसल्या तत्र जग्राह कराभ्याम् चरणौ मुनेः || २-९२-१५_END
BEGIN_
Kaikeyi with her unfulfilled desire and despised by the whole world, clasped the
sage's feet with bashfulness._END

B_2_C_92_15
BEGIN_
असमृद्धेन कामेन सर्व लोकस्य गर्हिता |
कैकेयी तस्य जग्राह चरणौ सव्यपत्रपा || २-९२-१६_END
BEGIN_
Kaikeyi with her unfulfilled desire and despised by the whole world, clasped the
sage's feet with bashfullness._END

B_2_C_92_16
BEGIN_
तम् प्रदक्षिणम् आगम्य भगवन्तम् महा मुनिम् |
अदूराद् भरतस्य एव तस्थौ दीन मनाः तदा || २-९२-१७_END
BEGIN_
Then, having gone around that venerable and eminent sage clock-wise, she stood close
to Bharata himself, distressed as she was at heart._END

B_2_C_92_17
BEGIN_
ततः पप्रग्च्छ भरतम् भरद्वाजो दृढ व्रतः |
विशेषम् ज्नातुम् इग्च्छामि मातृऋणाम् तव राघव || २-९२-१८_END
BEGIN_
Then, Bharadwaja, firm in austerity, enquired Bharata as follows: "O, Bharata! I
wish to know the distinctions of your mothers."_END

B_2_C_92_18
BEGIN_
एवम् उक्तः तु भरतो भरद्वाजेन धार्मिकः |
उवाच प्रान्जलिर् भूत्वा वाक्यम् वचन कोविदः || २-९२-१९_END
BEGIN_
Hearing the words of the learned sage, Bharadwaja, Bharata who was skilled in
expression, with joined palms, spoke the following words._END

B_2_C_92_19
BEGIN_
याम् इमाम् भगवन् दीनाम् शोकान् अशन कर्शिताम् |
पितुर् हि महिषीम् देवीम् देवताम् इव पश्यसि || २-९२-२०
एषा तम् पुरुष व्याघ्रम् सिम्ह विक्रान्त गामिनम् |
कौसल्या सुषुवे रामम् धातारम् अदितिर् यथा || २-९२-२१_END
BEGIN_
"O, venerable sage! This miserable queen emaciated by grief and fasting, is the
royal consort of my father, who you see resembling a goddess - it is she, Kausalya who, as Aditi
gave birth to Upendra, begot that Tiger among the heroes, with the great gait and pride of a lion
that Rama."_END

B_2_C_92_20
BEGIN_
अस्या वाम भुजम् श्लिष्टा या एषा तिष्ठति दुर्मनाः |
कर्णिकारस्य शाखा इव शीर्ण पुष्पा वन अन्तरे || २-९२-२२
एतस्याः तौ सुतौ देव्याः कुमारौ देव वर्णिनौ |
उभौ लक्ष्मण शत्रुघ्नौ वीरौ सत्य पराक्रमौ || २-९२-२३_END
BEGIN_
She, who stands clinging to the left shoulder of Kausalya, plunged in grief is the
unfortunate Sumitra, looking like a branch of Karnikara tree with withered flowers standing in the
interior of the grove. Both Lakshmana and Shatrughna, the two heroic princes of god-like appearance
and unfailing prowess are the sons of this godly woman, Sumitra._END

B_2_C_92_21
BEGIN_
यस्याः कृते नर याघ्रौ जीव नाशम् इतो गतौ |
राजा पुत्र विहीनः च स्वर्गम् दशरथो गतः || २-९२-२४
क्रोधनामकृतप्रज्ञां दृप्तां सुभगमानिनीम् |
ऐश्वर्य कामाम् कैकेयीम् अनार्याम् आर्य रूपिणीम् || २-९२-२५
मम एताम् मातरम् विद्धि नृशंसाम् पाप निश्चयाम् |
यतो मूलम् हि पश्यामि व्यसनम् महद् आत्मनः || २-९२-२६_END
BEGIN_
"She, through whose fault, those two tigers among men have to obtain a miserable
existence and King Dasaratha deprived of his son, has gone to heaven this woman, who is irate,
imprudent, arrogant, who esteems herself to be good-looking, who is covetous of power, unworthy
though noble to all appearance, know her to be Kaikeyi, my mother of wicked and sinful resolve, in
whom I see the root cause of my great misfortune."_END

B_2_C_92_22
BEGIN_
इत्य् उक्त्वा नर शार्दूलो बाष्प गद्गदया गिरा |
स निशश्वास ताम्र अक्षो क्रुद्धो नाग इव असकृत् || २-९२-२७_END
BEGIN_
Bharata, the tiger among men, with his red eyes spoke thus in a voice broken by sobs
and breathing as he like an enraged and hissing snake._END

B_2_C_92_23
BEGIN_
भरद्वाजो महर्षिः तम् ब्रुवन्तम् भरतम् तदा |
प्रत्युवाच महा बुद्धिर् इदम् वचनम् अर्थवत् || २-९२-२८_END
BEGIN_
Hearing the aforesaid words spoken by Bharata, Bharadwaja the great intellectual
sage replied in the following meaningful words._END

B_2_C_92_24
BEGIN_
न दोषेण अवगन्तव्या कैकेयी भरत त्वया |
राम प्रव्राजनम् ह्य् एतत् सुख उदर्कम् भविष्यति || २-९२-२९_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata! Kaikeyi is not intended to be understood by you accusatively. The exile
of Rama with indeed become ultimately a cause for happiness!"_END

B_2_C_92_25
BEGIN_
देवानाम् दानवानाम् च ऋषीणाम् भावितात्मनाम् |
हितमेव भविष्यद्धि रामप्रव्राजनादिह || २-९२-३०_END
BEGIN_
"Now, due to Rama's exile, there will indeed be a benefit to the celestials the
demons and the sages whose souls are purified by meditating on the Universal Spirit."_END

B_2_C_92_26
BEGIN_
अभिवाद्य तु संसिद्धः कृत्वा च एनम् प्रदक्षिणम् |
आमन्त्र्य भरतः सैन्यम् युज्यताम् इत्य् अचोदयत् || २-९२-३१_END
BEGIN_
Bharata satisfied, paid obeisance to him and circumambulated him in bidding a
farewell, directing the army to get prepared to leave._END

B_2_C_92_27
BEGIN_
ततो वाजि रथान् युक्त्वा दिव्यान् हेम परिष्क्रितान् |
अध्यारोहत् प्रयाण अर्थी बहून् बहु विधो जनः || २-९२-३२_END
BEGIN_
Then, setting out for their destination, countless people ascended many excellent
chariots, decorated with gold, duly harnessed to horses._END

B_2_C_92_28
BEGIN_
गज कन्या गजाः चैव हेम कक्ष्याः पताकिनः |
जीमूता इव घर्म अन्ते सघोषाः सम्प्रतस्थिरे || २-९२-३३_END
BEGIN_
Female and male elephants, wearing golden chains and flags, distinguished by the
sound of bells, like thundering clouds at the end of a summer marched in a form._END

B_2_C_92_29
BEGIN_
विविधान्य् अपि यानानि महानि च लघूनि च |
प्रययुः सुमहा अर्हाणि पादैर् एव पदातयः || २-९२-३४_END
BEGIN_
Various precious conveyances, both big and small, marched forward. Pedestrians
marched forward by foot._END

B_2_C_92_30
BEGIN_
अथ यान प्रवेकैः तु कौसल्या प्रमुखाः स्त्रियः |
राम दर्शन कान्क्षिण्यः प्रययुर् मुदिताः तदा || २-९२-३५_END
BEGIN_
Desirous of seeing Rama and delighted, Kausalya and other honourable women
thereafter advanced on their excellent conveyances._END

B_2_C_92_31
BEGIN_
चंद्र्क तरुण आभासाम् नियुक्ताम् शिबिकाम् शुभाम् |
आस्थाय प्रययौ श्रीमान् भरतः सपरिग्च्छदः || २-९२-३६_END
BEGIN_
The illustrious Bharata mounted a readily kept palanquin which was auspiciously
shining like rising moon and sun and proceeded along with his escort._END

B_2_C_92_32
BEGIN_
सा प्रयाता महा सेना गज वाजि रथ आकुला |
दक्षिणाम् दिशम् आवृत्य महा मेघ इव उत्थितः || २-९२-३७
वनानि तु व्यतिक्रम्य जुष्टानि मृग पक्षिभिः |
गङ्गायाः परवेलायां गिरिष्वपि नदीषु च २-९२-३८_END
BEGIN_
That vast army with its countless elephants horses and chariots proceeded, covering
the southern direction, like a great cloud that has risen in the sky and on the other bank of the
Ganges, by mountains and streams, crossing the woods inhabited by deer and birds._END

B_2_C_92_33
BEGIN_
सा सम्प्रहृष्ट द्विप वाजि योधा |
वित्रासयन्ती मृग पक्षि सम्घान् |
महद् वनम् तत् प्रविगाहमाना |
रराज सेना भरतस्य तत्र || २-९२-३९_END
BEGIN_
That army of Bharata, with its squadrons of rejoicing elephants horses and warriors,
penetrating into the vast forest, frightening innumerable beasts and birds, appeared resplendent
there._END

B_2_C_93_0
BEGIN_
तया महत्या यायिन्या ध्वजिन्या वन वासिनः |
अर्दिता यूथपा मत्ताः सयूथाः सम्प्रदुद्रुवुः || २-९३-१_END
BEGIN_
Seeing that large army on the march, the herds of beasts with their leaders, the
denizens of the woods were frightened and ran away together._END

B_2_C_93_1
BEGIN_
ऋक्षाः पृषत सम्घाः च रुरवः च समन्ततः |
दृश्यन्ते वन राजीषु गिरिषु अपि नदीषु च || २-९३-२_END
BEGIN_
Bears, dappled deer and antelopes could be seen every where, on the tracks of the
forest, on the hills and by the rivers._END

B_2_C_93_2
BEGIN_
स सम्प्रतस्थे धर्म आत्मा प्रीतो दशरथ आत्मजः |
वृतो महत्या नादिन्या सेनया चतुर् अन्गया || २-९३-३_END
BEGIN_
That pious minded Bharata gracefully marched ahead, surrounded by that clamorous
army of four divisions._END

B_2_C_93_3
BEGIN_
सागर ओघ निभा सेना भरतस्य महात्मनः |
महीम् संचादयाम् आस प्रावृषि द्याम् इव अम्बुदः || २-९३-४_END
BEGIN_
The army, of the magnanimous Bharata, which resembled the high tide of an ocean,
covered the earth as clouds cover the sky in a rainy season._END

B_2_C_93_4
BEGIN_
तुरम्ग ओघैर् अवतता वारणैः च महा जवैः |
अनालक्ष्या चिरम् कालम् तस्मिन् काले बभूव भूः || २-९३-५_END
BEGIN_
Submerged by the waves of horses and elephants of great speed at that time, the
earth became invisible for a long time._END

B_2_C_93_5
BEGIN_
स यात्वा दूरम् अध्वानम् सुपरिश्रान्त वाहनः |
उवाच भरतः श्रीमान् वसिष्ठम् मन्त्रिणाम् वरम् || २-९३-६_END
BEGIN_
Having travelled for a long distance, that glorious Bharata, whose animals were now
fully exhausted, said to Vasishta, the most segaceios of his counsellors (as follows)_END

B_2_C_93_6
BEGIN_
यादृशम् लक्ष्यते रूपम् यथा चैव श्रुतम् मया |
व्यक्तम् प्राप्ताः स्म तम् देशम् भरद्वाजो यम् अब्रवीत् || २-९३-७_END
BEGIN_
"Looking at the features of the pace and from what has been heard by me, it is clear
that we reached that area of which Bharadwaja spoke."_END

B_2_C_93_7
BEGIN_
अयम् गिरिः चित्र कूटः तथा मन्दाकिनी नदी |
एतत् प्रकाशते दूरान् नील मेघ निभम् वनम् || २-९३-८_END
BEGIN_
"This mountain is Chitrakuta. This river is Mandakini. This forest is appearing like
a blue cloud from a distance."_END

B_2_C_93_8
BEGIN_
गिरेः सानूनि रम्याणि चित्र कूटस्य सम्प्रति |
वारणैर् अवमृद्यन्ते मामकैः पर्वत उपमैः || २-९३-९_END
BEGIN_
"By my elephants appearing themselves like mountains, the lovely peaks of Chitrakuta
mountain are being trampled."_END

B_2_C_93_9
BEGIN_
मुन्चन्ति कुसुमान्य् एते नगाः पर्वत सानुषु |
नीला इव आतप अपाये तोयम् तोय धरा घनाः || २-९३-१०_END
BEGIN_
"These trees on the peaks of the mountain are shedding flowers, as black and intense
clouds shower water in a rainy season."_END

B_2_C_93_10
BEGIN_
किन्नर आचरित उद्देशम् पश्य शत्रुघ्न पर्वतम् |
हयैः समन्ताद् आकीर्णम् मकरैर् इव सागरम् || २-९३-११_END
BEGIN_
"Behold, O Shatrughna, this mountain, (hitherto) frequented by Kinnaras, now teaming
with horses on every side, as a sea is infested by allegators."_END

B_2_C_93_11
BEGIN_
एते मृग गणा भान्ति शीघ्र वेगाः प्रचोदिताः |
वायु प्रविद्धाः शरदि मेघ राज्य इव अम्बरे || २-९३-१२_END
BEGIN_
"These herds of antelopes, having a rapid speed, as urged forward (by the troops)
appear like a mass of clouds driven by the wind in the sky in antumn."_END

B_2_C_93_12
BEGIN_
कुर्वन्ति कुसुम आपीडान् शिरह्सु सुरभीन् अमी |
मेघ प्रकाशैः फलकैर् दाक्षिणात्या यथा नराः || २-९३-१३_END
BEGIN_
"Those tree, with their leaves in multitude dazzling, crowned with fragrant chaplets
of flowers, resemble the people of the south."_END

B_2_C_93_13
BEGIN_
निष्कूजम् इव भूत्वा इदम् वनम् घोर प्रदर्शनम् |
अयोध्या इव जन आकीर्णा सम्प्रति प्रतिभाति मा || २-९३-१४_END
BEGIN_
"This forest, which was silent and wore a terrifying look till now, appears to me
like Ayodhya, swarning with people."_END

B_2_C_93_14
BEGIN_
खुरैर् उदीरितो रेणुर् दिवम् प्रग्च्छाद्य तिष्ठति |
तम् वहत्य् अनिलः शीघ्रम् कुर्वन्न् इव मम प्रियम् || २-९३-१५_END
BEGIN_
"The dust raised from the hooves of the horses blots out the heavens, but the wind
carries it away immediately as if to give me pleasure."_END

B_2_C_93_15
BEGIN_
स्यन्दनामः तुरग उपेतान् सूत मुख्यैर् अधिष्ठितान् |
एतान् सम्पततः शीघ्रम् पश्य शत्रुघ्न कानने || २-९३-१६_END
BEGIN_
"Behold, O Shatrughna, these chariots yoked with horses and mounted by the chief
charioteers are rushing together rapidly in the forest."_END

B_2_C_93_16
BEGIN_
एतान् वित्रासितान् पश्य बर्हिणः प्रिय दर्शनान् |
एतम् आविशतः शैलम् अधिवासम् पतत्रिणाम् || २-९३-१७_END
BEGIN_
"Behold these peacocks and birds, which are pleasant to the sight, are frightened
and are entering their dwelling places hastily."_END

B_2_C_93_17
BEGIN_
अतिमात्रम् अयम् देशो मनोज्नः प्रतिभाति मा |
तापसानाम् निवासो अयम् व्यक्तम् स्वर्ग पथो यथा || २-९३-१८_END
BEGIN_
"This place to me is appearing very much lovely. Resembling in every way like a
threshold of heaven, it is clearly an abode of ascetics."_END

B_2_C_93_18
BEGIN_
मृगा मृगीभिः सहिता बहवः पृषता वने |
मनोज्न रूपा लक्ष्यन्ते कुसुमैर् इव चित्रितः || २-९३-१९_END
BEGIN_
"In this forest, many dappled deer with their hinds, endowed with enchanting forms,
are seen as if studded with flowers."_END

B_2_C_93_19
BEGIN_
साधु सैन्याः प्रतिष्ठन्ताम् विचिन्वन्तु च काननम् |
यथा तौ पुरुष व्याघ्रौ दृश्येते राम लक्ष्मणौ || २-९३-२०_END
BEGIN_
"Let the soldiers proceed quickly to explore the woods to find those tigers among
men, Rama and Lakshamana."_END

B_2_C_93_20
BEGIN_
भरतस्य वचः श्रुत्वा पुरुषाः शस्त्र पाणयः |
विविशुः तद् वनम् शूरा धूमम् च ददृशुः ततः || २-९३-२१_END
BEGIN_
Hearing the words of Bharata, valiant men wearing weapons in their hands, penetrated
into the forest suddenly they observed a plume of smoke rising._END

B_2_C_93_21
BEGIN_
ते समालोक्य धूम अग्रम् ऊचुर् भरतम् आगताः |
न अमनुष्ये भवत्य् अग्निर् व्यक्तम् अत्र एव राघवौ || २-९३-२२_END
BEGIN_
Seeing that spiral of smoke, they returned to bharata and said; "There can be no
fire in a deserted place. Assuredly, Rama and Lakshmana are there."_END

B_2_C_93_22
BEGIN_
अथ न अत्र नर व्याघ्रौ राज पुत्रौ परम् तपौ |
अन्ये राम उपमाः सन्ति व्यक्तम् अत्र तपस्विनः || २-९३-२३_END
BEGIN_
"If it be not those two tigers among men, the two princes, the scourger of their
foes here, obviously there are other ascetics like Rama here."_END

B_2_C_93_23
BEGIN_
तत् श्रुत्वा भरतः तेषाम् वचनम् साधु सम्मतम् |
सैन्यान् उवाच सर्वामः तान् अमित्र बल मर्दनः || २-९३-२४_END
BEGIN_
Hearing those words concurred even by pious men, Bharata the destroyer of enemy's
forces, spoke to the entire army (as follows)_END

B_2_C_93_24
BEGIN_
यत् ता भवन्तः तिष्ठन्तु न इतो गन्तव्यम् अग्रतः |
अहम् एव गमिष्यामि सुमन्त्रो गुरुर् एव च || २-९३-२५_END
BEGIN_
"You stay here vigilantly. Do no proceed any further. I alone will go along with
Sumantra and also Dhriti, my spiritual preceptor."_END

B_2_C_93_25
BEGIN_
एवम् उक्ताः ततः सर्वे तत्र तस्थुः समन्ततः |
भरतो यत्र धूम अग्रम् तत्र दृष्टिम् समादधत् || २-९३-२६_END
BEGIN_
On this command, all the troops halted there and Bharat with his gaze fixed on the
column of smoke, went forward._END

B_2_C_93_26
BEGIN_
व्यवस्थिता या भरतेन सा चमूर् |
निरीक्षमाणा अपि च धूमम् अग्रतः |
बभूव हृष्टा नचिरेण जानती |
प्रियस्य रामस्य समागमम् तदा || २-९३-२७_END
BEGIN_
The army, which was held up there by Bharata, eventhough perceiving the place ahead,
felt rejoiced in the thought of meeting their beloved Rama soon._END

B_2_C_94_0
BEGIN_
दीर्घ काल उषितः तस्मिन् गिरौ गिरि वन प्रियः |
विदेह्याः प्रियमाकान्क्षन् स्वम् च चित्तम् विलोभयन् || २-९४-१
अथ दाशरथिः चित्रम् चित्र कूटम् अदर्शयत् |
भार्याम् अमर सम्काशः शचीम् इव पुरम् दरः || २-९४-२_END
BEGIN_
Having dwelt for some time in that mountain, Rama, who resembled God, who liked
mountains and groves, who desired Seetha's happiness and himself delightful in his mind, began to
point out the beauty of Chitrakuta to his consort, as Indra the god of celestials converses with
Shachi the wife of Indra, saying:_END

B_2_C_94_1
BEGIN_
न राज्याद् भ्रंशनम् भद्रे न सुहृद्भिर् विना भवः |
मनो मे बाधते दृष्ट्वा रमणीयम् इमम् गिरिम् || २-९४-३_END
BEGIN_
"O, my good lady! By seeing this beautiful mountain, neither the loss of kingdom nor
the non-existence of friends distresses my mind."_END

B_2_C_94_2
BEGIN_
पश्य इमम् अचलम् भद्रे नाना द्विज गण आयुतम् |
शिखरैः खम् इव उद्विद्धैर् धातुमद्भिर् विभूषितम् || २-९४-४_END
BEGIN_
"O, my good lady! Behold this mountain, abounding with flocks of birds of every kind
where minerals lie and crowned with peaks that seem to project upwards to the sky."_END

B_2_C_94_3
BEGIN_
केचिद् रजत सम्काशाः केचित् क्षतज सम्निभाः |
पीत माज्जिस्थ वर्नाः च केचिन् मनि वर प्रभाः || २-९४-५
पुष्य अर्क केतुक आभाः च केचिज् ज्योती रस प्रभाः |
विराजन्ते अचल इन्द्रस्य देशा धातु विभूषिताः || २-९४-६_END
BEGIN_
"Some areas of the mountain are encrusted with minerals, having appearance of
silver, some resembling blood, some yellowish, some red as madder, some sparkle like precious
stones, some possessing, the luster of topaz and crystal and a hue of Ketaka flower and some
sparkle with the splendour of a kind of gem called Jyotirasa."_END

B_2_C_94_4
BEGIN_
नना मृग गण द्वीपि तरक्षु ऋक्ष गणैर् वृतः |
अदुष्टैर् भात्य् अयम् शैलो बहु पक्षि समाकुलः || २-९४-७_END
BEGIN_
"The mountain is filled with tame beasts of every kind, tigers, panthers and bears,
and is enlivened by a flock of many birds."_END

B_2_C_94_5
BEGIN_
आम्र जम्बु असनैर् लोध्रैः प्रियालैः पनसैर् धवैः |
अन्कोलैर् भव्य तिनिशैर् ब्लिव तिन्दुक वेणुभिः || २-९४-८
काश्मर्य् अरिष्ट वरणैर् मधूकैः तिलकैः तथा |
बदर्य् आमलकैर् नीपैर् वेत्र धन्वन बीजकैः || २-९४-९
पुष्पवद्भिः फल उपेतैः चायावद्भिर् मनो रमैः |
एवम् आदिभिर् आकीर्णः श्रियम् पुष्यत्य् अयम् गिरिः || २-९४-१०_END
BEGIN_
"This mountain abounds with such type of trees as mangoes, rose-apples and Asanas
laden with flowers and fruits, affording magnificient shade, and pleasing to the mind, Lodhras,
Priyalas (commonly called Payals), bread-fruit trees, Dhavas, Ankolas, Bhavyas and Tinisas, Bilvas
(Bel trees), Tindukas and bamboos, Kashmaris, margosas and Varaas, Madhukas; Tilaks, jujube trees,
emblic myrobalans, Kadamoos, came, Dhanvanas and pomegranates, enhancing its beauty."_END

B_2_C_94_6
BEGIN_
शैल प्रस्थेषु रम्येषु पश्य इमान् काम हर्षणान् |
किन्नरान् द्वंद्वशो भद्रे रममाणान् मनस्विनः || २-९४-११_END
BEGIN_
"O, my good lady! See these Kinnaras, thrilling to be looked at, in their high
spirits, wandering in couples in these lovely mountain-plains."_END

B_2_C_94_7
BEGIN_
शाखा अवसक्तान् खड्गामः च प्रवराण्य् अम्बराणि च |
पश्य विद्याधर स्त्रीणाम् क्रीडेद् देशान् मनो रमान् || २-९४-१२_END
BEGIN_
"Behold their swords hanging on the trees, their excellent swords and the charming
retreats, where vidyadharas and their women sport."_END

B_2_C_94_8
BEGIN_
जल प्रपातैर् उद्भेदैर् निष्यन्दैः च क्वचित् क्वचित् |
स्रवद्भिर् भात्य् अयम् शैलः स्रवन् मद इव द्विपः || २-९४-१३_END
BEGIN_
"This mountain resembles an elephant with ichors flowing from its forehead, as from
its crevices, springs and cascades flow here and there."_END

B_2_C_94_9
BEGIN_
गुहा समीरणो गन्धान् नाना पुष्प भवान् वहन् |
घ्राण तर्पणम् अभ्येत्य कम् नरम् न प्रहर्षयेत् || २-९४-१४_END
BEGIN_
"Who would not be filled with delight, by these glades from which fragrance of
various flowers issues, pleasing to the senses?"_END

B_2_C_94_10
BEGIN_
यदि इह शरदो अनेकाः त्वया सार्धम् अनिन्दिते |
लक्ष्मणेन च वत्स्यामि न माम् शोकः प्रधक्ष्यति || २-९४-१५_END
BEGIN_
"O, irreproachable lay! If I am live with you and Lakshmana for many autumns here,
grief will not overpower me."_END

B_2_C_94_11
BEGIN_
बहु पुष्प फले रम्ये नाना द्विज गण आयुते |
विचित्र शिखरे ह्य् अस्मिन् रतवान् अस्मि भामिनि || २-९४-१६_END
BEGIN_
"O, Seetha! Seeing this mountain laden with many flowers and fruit, the enchanting
resort of flocks of birds as also the ravishing peaks of the mountain, I am really captivated."_END

B_2_C_94_12
BEGIN_
अनेन वन वासेन मया प्राप्तम् फल द्वयम् |
पितुः च अनृणता धर्मे भरतस्य प्रियम् तथा || २-९४-१७_END
BEGIN_
"By residing in the forest, a two-fold advantage is secured by me; freedom from debt
to my father in regards my duty and Bharata's happiness."_END

B_2_C_94_13
BEGIN_
वैदेहि रमसे कच्चिच् चित्र कूटे मया सह |
पश्यन्ती विविधान् भावान् मनो वाक् काय सम्यतान् || २-९४-१८_END
BEGIN_
"O, Seetha! Are you happy with me on this Chitrakuta mountain, seeing various
objects agreeable to your thought word and temperament?"_END

B_2_C_94_14
BEGIN_
इदम् एव अमृतम् प्राहू राज्नाम् राज ऋषयः परे |
वन वासम् भव अर्थाय प्रेत्य मे प्रपितामहाः || २-९४-१९_END
BEGIN_
"My paternal great grand fathers the ancient royal sages have said that for a king
to obtain liberation after death, such a residence in the forest is nectar like."_END

B_2_C_94_15
BEGIN_
शिलाः शैलस्य शोभन्ते विशालाः शतशो अभितः |
बहुला बहुलैर् वर्णैर् नील पीत सित अरुणैः || २-९४-२०_END
BEGIN_
"Hundreds and multitude of rocks of this extensive mountain are shining around in
multifarious colours like blue, yellow, white and red."_END

B_2_C_94_16
BEGIN_
निशि भान्त्य् अचल इन्द्रस्य हुत अशन शिखा इव |
ओषध्यः स्वप्रभा लक्ष्म्या भ्राजमानाः सहस्रशः || २-९४-२१_END
BEGIN_
"Thousands of herbs of this Chitrakuta mountain, glittering with their lovely light,
are sparkling like points of fire."_END

B_2_C_94_17
BEGIN_
केचित् क्षय निभा देशाः केचिद् उद्यान सम्निभाः |
केचिद् एक शिला भान्ति पर्वतस्य अस्य भामिनि || २-९४-२२_END
BEGIN_
"O, Seetha! Some parts of this mountain resemble mansions, some look like parks and
some others appear like a single pile."_END

B_2_C_94_18
BEGIN_
भित्त्वा इव वसुधाम् भाति चित्र कूटः समुत्थितः |
चित्र कूटस्य कूटो असौ दृश्यते सर्वतः शुभः || २-९४-२३_END
BEGIN_
"Chitrakuta appears as though emerged, having split the earth. This summit of
Chitrakuta appears charming on all sides."_END

B_2_C_94_19
BEGIN_
कुष्ठ पुम्नाग तगर भूर्ज पत्र उत्तरच् चदान् |
कामिनाम् स्वास्तरान् पश्य कुशेशय दल आयुतान् || २-९४-२४_END
BEGIN_
"See the leaves of lilies, Sthagara trees, Punnaga trees and Bhurja trees heaped
with flowers of water-lilies form the cozy beds of voluptuaries."_END

B_2_C_94_20
BEGIN_
मृदिताः च अपविद्धाः च दृश्यन्ते कमल स्रजः |
कामिभिर् वनिते पश्य फलानि विविधानि च || २-९४-२५_END
BEGIN_
"O, Seetha! Look at the garlands of lotus-flowers crushed and thrown aside by
voluptuaries as also fruits of every kind that have been tasted."_END

B_2_C_94_21
BEGIN_
वस्वौक साराम् नलिनीम् अत्येति इव उत्तरान् कुरून् |
पर्वतः चित्र कूटो असौ बहु मूल फल उदकः || २-९४-२६_END
BEGIN_
"This mountain f Chitrakuta with its abundance of roots fruits and water is more
beautiful than Vasvankasara better known as Alaka the capital of Kubera the Lord of Riches, Nalini
the capital of Indra (the God of celestials) better known as Amaravati and Uttarakuru the country
of Eternal Beatitude."_END

B_2_C_94_22
BEGIN_
इमम् तु कालम् वनिते विजह्निवामः |
त्वया च सीते सह लक्ष्मणेन च |
रतिम् प्रपत्स्ये कुल धर्म वर्धिनीम् |
सताम् पथि स्वैर् नियमैः परैः स्थितः || २-९४-२७_END
BEGIN_
"O, Seetha! Strolling with you and Lakshmana during this period of exile, on my part
established in the path of the pious, following the highest salutary practices, I shall obtain joy,
enhancing the piety of my race."_END

B_2_C_95_0
BEGIN_
अथ शैलाद् विनिष्क्रम्य मैथिलीम् कोसल ईश्वरः |
अदर्शयत् शुभ जलाम् रम्याम् मन्दाकिनीम् नदीम् || २-९५-१_END
BEGIN_
Then, turning away from the mountain, Rama (The prospective ruler of Kosala) showed
Seetha (the daughter of the King of Mithila) the beautiful river of Mandakini carrying splendid
waters._END

B_2_C_95_1
BEGIN_
अब्रवीच् च वर आरोहाम् चारु चन्द्र निभ आननाम् |
विदेह राजस्य सुताम् रामो राजीव लोचनः || २-९५-२_END
BEGIN_
The lotus-eyed Rama spoke to Seetha, (the daughter of Janaka) who was having an
elegant waist and whose face resembled the moon:_END

B_2_C_95_2
BEGIN_
विचित्र पुलिनाम् रम्याम् हंस सारस सेविताम् |
कुसुमैर् उपसम्पन्नाम् पश्य मन्दाकिनीम् नदीम् || २-९५-३_END
BEGIN_
"Behold this charming river of Mandakini, with its multi-coloured sandy beaches,
frequented by swans and geese and laden with flowers."_END

B_2_C_95_3
BEGIN_
नाना विधैः तीर रुहैर् वृताम् पुष्प फल द्रुमैः |
राजन्तीम् राज राजस्य नलिनीम् इव सर्वतः || २-९५-४_END
BEGIN_
"Behold this river, hedged on all sides with various kinds of flowers and fruits,
growing on its banks and enhance its loveliness like the lake (Sangadhika) of Kubera (the ruler of
Yakshas)"_END

B_2_C_95_4
BEGIN_
मृग यूथ निपीतानि कलुष अम्भांसि साम्प्रतम् |
तीर्थानि रमणीयानि रतिम् सम्जनयन्ति मे || २-९५-५_END
BEGIN_
"At this moment, its pleasant fords, where herds of deer drink and make the waters
turbid, create ecstasy in me."_END

B_2_C_95_5
BEGIN_
जटा अजिन धराः काले वल्कल उत्तर वाससः |
ऋषयः तु अवगाहन्ते नदीम् मन्दाकिनीम् प्रिये || २-९५-६_END
BEGIN_
"O, beloved Seetha! Sages with matted locks and wearing antelope-skins and having
bark of trees for their upper garment, take a dip in the River Mandakini, at the appointed
hour."_END

B_2_C_95_6
BEGIN_
आदित्यम् उपतिष्ठन्ते नियमाद् ऊर्ध्व बाहवः |
एते अपरे विशाल अक्षि मुनयः संशित व्रताः || २-९५-७_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lady of wide eyes! Here are some other sages of austere vows, worshipping the
sun with uplifted arms; as per the scriptural injunctions."_END

B_2_C_95_7
BEGIN_
मारुत उद्धूत शिखरैः प्रनृत्त इव पर्वतः |
पादपैः पत्र पुष्पाणि सृजद्भिर् अभितो नदीम् || २-९५-८_END
BEGIN_
"The trees, their crowns agitated by the breeze, that shower down leaves and flowers
on both sides of the river cause the mountain to appear as though it were dancing!"_END

B_2_C_95_8
BEGIN_
कच्चिन् मणि निकाश उदाम् कच्चित् पुलिन शालिनीम् |
कच्चित् सिद्ध जन आकीर्णाम् पश्य मन्दाकिनीम् नदीम् || २-९५-९_END
BEGIN_
"See this River Mandakini with its crystal-like clear water at some places, with its
shining sand-dunes at some places and crowded with Siddhas who are bathing at some other
places."_END

B_2_C_95_9
BEGIN_
निर्धूतान् वायुना पश्य विततान् पुष्प संचयान् |
पोप्लूयमानान् अपरान् पश्य त्वम् जल मध्यगान् || २-९५-१०_END
BEGIN_
"Behold you, heaps of flowers shaken down by the wind and shattered. See some other
heaps of flowers floating, O lady with slender waist!"_END

B_2_C_95_10
BEGIN_
तामः च अतिवल्गु वचसो रथ अन्ग आह्वयना द्विजाः |
अधिरोहन्ति कल्याणि निष्कूजन्तः शुभाः गिरः || २-९५-११_END
BEGIN_
"O, Kalyani! Behold the sweet-voiced ruddy geese, ascending the banks uttering
harmonious tones."_END

B_2_C_95_11
BEGIN_
दर्शनम् चित्र कूटस्य मन्दाकिन्याः च शोभने |
अधिकम् पुर वासाच् च मन्ये च तव दर्शनात् || २-९५-१२_END
BEGIN_
"I consider this sight of Mandakini River and of Chitrakuta, particularly at your
sight, to be more delightful than dwelling in the City of Ayodhya, O, lovely woman!"_END

B_2_C_95_12
BEGIN_
विधूत कलुषैः सिद्धैः तपो दम शम अन्वितैः |
नित्य विक्षोभित जलाम् विहाहस्व मया सह || २-९५-१३_END
BEGIN_
Here are Siddhas (semi-divine beings endowed with mystic powers), free from
impurities and rich in asceticism, with their senses and mind under control, who perpetually stir
the waters. You too should take a dip in the river along with me."_END

B_2_C_95_13
BEGIN_
सखीवच् च विगाहस्व सीते मन्दकिनीम् इमाम् |
कमलान्य् अवमज्जन्ती पुष्कराणि च भामिनि || २-९५-१४_END
BEGIN_
"Enter the Mandakini River, as on the breast of a friend, submerging the red and
white lotuses in it- O, Lovely Seetha!"_END

B_2_C_95_14
BEGIN_
त्वम् पौर जनवद् व्यालान् अयोध्याम् इव पर्वतम् |
मन्यस्व वनिते नित्यम् सरयूवद् इमाम् नदीम् || २-९५-१५_END
BEGIN_
"My darling! Think of the wild beasts as inhabitants of the city of Ayodhya, this
mountain of Chitrakuta as the city of Ayodhya and this river as the Sarayu from now on!"_END

B_2_C_95_15
BEGIN_
लक्ष्मणः चैव धर्म आत्मा मन् निदेशे व्यवस्थितः |
त्वम् च अनुकूला वैदेहि प्रीतिम् जनयथो मम || २-९५-१६_END
BEGIN_
"O, Seetha!; The virtuous Lakshmana is obeying my commands and you too are
well-disposed, causing delight to me."_END

B_2_C_95_16
BEGIN_
उपस्पृशमः त्रि षवणम् मधु मूल फल अशनः |
न अयोध्यायै न राज्याय स्पृहये अद्य त्वया सह || २-९५-१७_END
BEGIN_
"Bathing three times a day in the river and living on honey, roots and fruits in
your company, I do not desire for the kingdom nor do I long for Ayodhya now."_END

B_2_C_95_17
BEGIN_
इमाम् हि रम्याम् गज यूथ लोलिताम् |
निपीत तोयाम् गज सिम्ह वानरैः |
सुपुष्पितैः पुष्प धरैर् अलम्कृताम् |
न सो अस्ति यः स्यान् न गत क्रमः सुखी || २-९५-१८_END
BEGIN_
"There is none in the world, who would not be relieved of his fatigue and feel
refreshed on the banks of this enchanting river, frequented by herds of elephants, who with lions
and monkeys, come here to drink and which is adorned with innumerable flowers in full bloom."_END

B_2_C_95_18
BEGIN_
इति इव रामो बहु सम्गतम् वचः |
प्रिया सहायः सरितम् प्रति ब्रुवन् |
चचार रम्यम् नयन अन्जन प्रभम् |
स चित्र कूटम् रघु वंश वर्धनः || २-९५-१९_END
BEGIN_
Describing the varied beauties of the Mandakini River, Rama the bestower of delight
to Raghu dynasty with his beloved consort as a companion, strolled in the lovely mountain of
Chitrakuta which was shining like a piece of collieries."_END

B_2_C_96_0
BEGIN_
तां तथा दर्शयित्वा तु मैथिलीं गिरिनिम्नगाम् |
निषसाद गिरिप्रस्थे सीतां मांसेन चन्दयन् || २-९६-१_END
BEGIN_
Having shown Mandakini River in that manner to Seetha, the daughter of Mithila, Rama
set on the hill-side in order to gratify her appetite with a piece of flesh._END

B_2_C_96_1
BEGIN_
इदं मेध्यमिदं स्वादु निष्टप्तमिदमग्निना |
एवमास्ते स धर्मात्मा सीतया सह राघवः || २-९६-२_END
BEGIN_
Rama, whose mind was devoted to righteousness stayed there with Seetha, saying;
"This meat is fresh, this is savoury and roasted in the fire."_END

B_2_C_96_2
BEGIN_
तथा तत्र आसतः तस्य भरतस्य उपयायिनः |
सैन्य रेणुः च शब्दः च प्रादुर् आस्ताम् नभः स्पृशौ || २-९६-३_END
BEGIN_
While Rama was thus sitting there the dust and clamour of Bharata's army, which was
approaching, ascended into the sky._END

B_2_C_96_3
BEGIN_
एतस्मिन्न् अन्तरे त्रस्ताः शब्देन महता ततः |
अर्दिता यूथपा मत्ताः सयूथा दुद्रुवुर् दिशः || २-९६-४_END
BEGIN_
Meanwhile, frightened by that gigantic clamour, the leaders of elephants and other
animal - troops, in rut, were tormented and fled in different directions from there._END

B_2_C_96_4
BEGIN_
स तम् सैन्य समुद्भूतम् शब्दम् शुश्रव राघवः |
तामः च विप्रद्रुतान् सर्वान् यूथपान् अन्ववैक्षत || २-९६-५_END
BEGIN_
Rama heard that sound generated from the army and also saw all those leaders of the
animal-flock, running away from there._END

B_2_C_96_5
BEGIN_
तामः च विद्रवतो दृष्ट्वा तम् च श्रुत्वा स निह्स्वनम् |
उवाच रामः सौमित्रिम् लक्ष्मणम् दीप्त तेजसम् || २-९६-६_END
BEGIN_
Seeing those animals running away and hearing that clamour, Rama spoke to Lakshmana
(son of Sumitra) of burning courage as follows:_END

B_2_C_96_6
BEGIN_
हन्त लक्ष्मण पश्य इह सुमित्रा सुप्रजाः त्वया |
भीम स्तनित गम्भ्हिरः तुमुलः श्रूयते स्वनः || २-९६-७_END
BEGIN_
"Alas! O, Lakshmana! Sumitra is blessed with a noble son in you. Here is heard a
tumultuous sound as terrific as that of a roaring cloud. See what it is."_END

B_2_C_96_7
BEGIN_
गजयूथानि वारण्ये महिषा वा महावने |
वित्रासिता मृगाह् सिंहैः सहसा प्रद्रुता दिशः २-९६-८_END
BEGIN_
"The lordly elephants in the forest, the buffaloes in the great woods and the wild
beasts frightened by lions are suddenly running away in various directions."_END

B_2_C_96_8
BEGIN_
राजा वा राज मात्रो वा मृगयाम् अटते वने |
अन्यद् वा श्वा पदम् किंचित् सौमित्रे ज्नातुम् अर्हसि || २-९६-९_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lakshmana! You ought to find out whether it is a king or a prince roaming for a
hunt or some other savage beast."_END

B_2_C_96_9
BEGIN_
सुदुश्चरो गिरिश्चायं पक्षिणामपि लक्ष्मण |
सर्वम् एतद् यथा तत्त्वम् अचिराज् ज्नातुम् अर्हसि || २-९६-१०_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lakshmana! This mountain is difficult of access even to birds. You ought to find
out soon, all this in an accurate manner."_END

B_2_C_96_10
BEGIN_
स लक्ष्मणः सम्त्वरितः सालम् आरुह्य पुष्पितम् |
प्रेक्षमाणो दिशः सर्वाः पूर्वाम् दिशम् अवैक्षत || २-९६-११_END
BEGIN_
Lakshmana quickly ascended a Sala tree in flowering and looking towards all
directions, saw towards eastern side._END

B_2_C_96_11
BEGIN_
उदन् मुखः प्रेक्षमाणो ददर्श महतीम् चमूम् |
रथ अश्व गज सम्बाधाम् यत्तैर् युक्ताम् पदातिभिः || २-९६-१२_END
BEGIN_
Looking in northern direction, Lakshmana saw a huge army, full of chariots, steeds
and elephants accompanied by smart foot-soldiers._END

B_2_C_96_12
BEGIN_
ताम् अश्व गज सम्पूर्णाम् रथ ध्वज विभूषिताम् |
शशंस सेनाम् रामाय वचनम् च इदम् अब्रवीत् || २-९६-१३_END
BEGIN_
Lakshmana informed Rama about that army which was full of horses, elephants and
chariots decorated with flags and spoke the following words also._END

B_2_C_96_13
BEGIN_
अग्निम् संशमयतु आर्यः सीता च भजताम् गुहाम् |
सज्यम् कुरुष्व चापम् च शरामः च कवचम् तथा || २-९६-१४_END
BEGIN_
"O, honourable brother! Extinguish the fire. Let Seetha occupy a hiding place. Make
your bow ready with a bow-string and arrows. Wear an armour."_END

B_2_C_96_14
BEGIN_
तम् रामः पुरुष व्याघ्रो लक्ष्मणम् प्रत्युवाच ह |
अन्ग अवेक्षस्व सौमित्रे कस्य एताम् मन्यसे चमूम् || २-९६-१५_END
BEGIN_
Rama the tiger among men replied to Lakshmana, saying: "O, Lakshmana! See, whose
army do you think is this?"_END

B_2_C_96_15
BEGIN_
एवम् उक्क्तः तु रामेण लक्ष्माणो वाक्यम् अब्रवीत् |
दिधक्षन्न् इव ताम् सेनाम् रुषितः पावको यथा || २-९६-१६_END
BEGIN_
Hearing Rama's words, Lakshmana was irritated like a fire and spoke the following
words, as though he was wishing to scorch the army._END

B_2_C_96_16
BEGIN_
सम्पन्नम् राज्यम् इग्च्छमः तु व्यक्तम् प्राप्य अभिषेचनम् |
आवाम् हन्तुम् समभ्येति कैकेय्या भरतः सुतः || २-९६-१७_END
BEGIN_
"Bharata, Kaikeyi's son, having obtained coronation and desirous of making the
kingdom free of enemies, is coming here to kill both of us. It is clear."_END

B_2_C_96_17
BEGIN_
एष वै सुमहान् श्रीमान् विटपी सम्प्रकाशते |
विराजत्य् उद्गत स्कन्धः कोविदार ध्वजो रथे || २-९६-१८_END
BEGIN_
"The gigantic and glorious tree with superb branches is shining over there
prominently. The ensign bearing the device of a kovidara (pomegranate) tree is shining on that
chariot."_END

B_2_C_96_18
BEGIN_
भजन्त्य् एते यथा कामम् अश्वान् आरुह्य शीघ्रगान् |
एते भ्राजन्ति सम्हृष्टा जगान् आरुह्य सादिनः || २-९६-१९_END
BEGIN_
Among the cavalry, some are cavorting merrily on their swift horses, while others
are beaming with delight, mounted on their elephants._END

B_2_C_96_19
BEGIN_
गृहीत धनुषौ च आवाम् गिरिम् वीर श्रयावहे |
अथवेहैव तिष्ठावः सन्नद्धावुद्यतायुधौ २-९६-२०_END
BEGIN_
"O, warrior! Let us take up our bows and ascend the mountain or let us stay here
itself, fully prepared with our weapons in our hands."_END

B_2_C_96_20
BEGIN_
अपि नौ वशम् आगग्च्छेत् कोविदार ध्वजो रणे |
अपि द्रक्ष्यामि भरतम् यत् कृते व्यसनम् महत् || २-९६-२१
त्वया राघव सम्प्राप्तम् सीतया च मया तथा |_END
BEGIN_
"O, Rama! Will that flag with the insignia of a Kovidara tree come into our
subjugation? Can we see Bharata, because of whom a great misfortune has occurred to you, to Seetha
and to me?"_END

B_2_C_96_21
BEGIN_
यन् निमित्तम् भवान् राज्याच् च्युतो राघव शाश्वतीम् |
सम्प्राप्तो अयम् अरिर् वीर भरतो वध्य एव मे || २-९६-२२_END
BEGIN_
"O, Rama the warrior! By the reason of whom you were deprived of an eternal kingdom,
such Bharata as a foe who is coming here, deserves to be slain by me."_END

B_2_C_96_22
BEGIN_
भरतस्य वधे दोषम् न अहम् पश्यामि राघव |
पूर्व अपकारिणम् हत्वा न ह्यधर्मेण युज्यते || २-९६-२३_END
BEGIN_
"O, Rama! I see no sin in slaying Bharata. None is charged with unlawfulness, if one
strikes down an aggressor."_END

B_2_C_96_23
BEGIN_
पूर्वापकारी भरतस्य्तक्तधर्मश्च राघव |
एतस्मिन्न् निहते कृत्स्नाम् अनुशाधि वसुंधराम् || २-९६-२४_END
BEGIN_
"Bharata is the assailant and his death is legitimate. He being dead, you will rule
the entire earth."_END

B_2_C_96_24
BEGIN_
अद्य पुत्रम् हतम् सम्ख्ये कैकेयी राज्य कामुका |
मया पश्येत् सुदुह्ख आर्ता हस्ति भग्नम् इव द्रुमम् || २-९६-२५_END
BEGIN_
"Let Kaikeyi, who is craving for the kingdom see, with great sorrow, her son slain
by me today in battle, as a tree is crushed down by an elephant."_END

B_2_C_96_25
BEGIN_
कैकेयीम् च वधिष्यामि सानुबन्धाम् सबान्धवाम् |
कलुषेण अद्य महता मेदिनी परिमुच्यताम् || २-९६-२६_END
BEGIN_
"I shall kill Kaikeyi too along with her friend the hunch-back and other
accomplices. Let the earth today be relieved of a great sinner."_END

B_2_C_96_26
BEGIN_
अद्य इमम् सम्यतम् क्रोधम् असत्कारम् च मानद |
मोक्ष्यामि शत्रु सैन्येषु कक्षेषु इव हुत अशनम् || २-९६-२७_END
BEGIN_
"O, warrior bestowing an honour! Today in the concentrated fury that injustice has
kindled I shall scatter the enemy - battalions as a fire consumes the dry wood."_END

B_2_C_96_27
BEGIN_
अद्य एतच् चित्र कूटस्य काननम् निशितैः शरैः |
चिन्दन् शत्रु शरीराणि करिष्ये शोणित उक्षितम् || २-९६-२८_END
BEGIN_
"Today, with my sharpened arrows, I shall slay the bodies of my foes and make this
forest of Chitrakuta overflow with blood."_END

B_2_C_96_28
BEGIN_
शरैर् निर्भिन्न हृदयान् कुन्जरामः तुरगामः तथा |
श्वापदाः परिकर्षन्तु नराः च निहतान् मया || २-९६-२९_END
BEGIN_
"The elephants and horses whose breasts were laid open with my darts and the men too
struck down by me, be dragged about by savage beasts."_END

B_2_C_96_29
BEGIN_
शराणाम् धनुषः च अहम् अनृणो अस्मि महा वने |
ससैन्यम् भरतम् हत्वा भविष्यामि न संशयः || २-९६-३०_END
BEGIN_
"By killing Bharata together with his army in this great forest, I shall discharge
my debt to my bow and arrows."_END

B_2_C_97_0
BEGIN_
सुसम्रब्धम् तु सौमित्रिम् लक्ष्मणम् क्रोध मूर्चितम् |
रामः तु परिसान्त्व्य अथ वचनम् च इदम् अब्रवीत् || २-९७-१_END
BEGIN_
Rama on the other hand, pacifying Lakshmana (son of Sumitra), who was very much
agitated and infatuated with anger, spoke the following words:_END

B_2_C_97_1
BEGIN_
किम् अत्र धनुषा कार्यम् असिना वा सचर्मणा |
महा इष्वासे महा प्राज्ने भरते स्वयम् आगते || २-९७-२_END
BEGIN_
"While Bharata, wieldin a bow and highly wise-man himself is coming here, what is
the use of a bow or sword with a shield?"_END

B_2_C_97_2
BEGIN_
पितुस्सत्यं प्रतिश्रुत्य हत्वा भरतमागतम् |
किम् करिष्यामि राज्येन सापवादेन लक्ष्मण || २-९७-३_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lakshmana! Having promised to make our father's wish a reality. What shall I do
with the kingdom by acquiring an ill-fame in killing Bharata who came here to see me?"_END

B_2_C_97_3
BEGIN_
यद्द्रव्यं बान्दवानां वा मित्राणां वाक्षये भवत् |
नाहं तप्त्प्रतिगृह्णीयां भक्षान्विषकृतानिव २-९७-४_END
BEGIN_
"I should not enjoy the spoils obtained by slaying a relative or friend, like the
partaking of a poisoned food."_END

B_2_C_97_4
BEGIN_
धर्ममर्थं च कामं च पृथिवीं चापि लक्षण |
इच्छामि भवतामर्थे एतत् प्रतिशृणोमि ते || २-९७-५_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lakshmana! It is for your sake I desire virtue, legitimately acquired wealth and
pleasure or even the earth itself. I promise this to you."_END

B_2_C_97_5
BEGIN_
भ्रातृइणां संग्रहार्थं च सुखार्थं चापि लक्ष्मण |
राज्यमप्यहमिच्छामि सत्येनायुधमालभे || २-९७-६_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lakshmana! I desire the throne only for the protection and happiness of my
brothers. I touch my weapon and swear this fact."_END

B_2_C_97_6
BEGIN_
नेयं मम मही सौम्य दुर्लभा सागराम्बरा |
न हीच्छेयमधर्मेण शक्रत्वमपि लक्ष्मण || २-९७-७_END
BEGIN_
"This earth, bounded by the sea is not hard to obtain for me, O the excellent man! I
do not indeed wish even the position of Indra by unrighteousness."_END

B_2_C_97_7
BEGIN_
यद्विना भरतं त्वां च शत्रुघ्नं चापि मानद |
भवेन्मम सुखं किंचिद्भस्म तत्कुरुतां शिखी || २-९७-८_END
BEGIN_
"If there be happiness that I could enjoy without Bharata or you or without
Shatrughna, may it be without Shatrughna, may it be burnt to ashes by fire, O the
honour-giver!"_END

B_2_C_97_8
BEGIN_
मन्येऽहमागतोऽयेध्यां भरतो भ्रातृवत्सलः |
मम प्राणात्र्पियतरः कुलधर्ममनुस्मरन् || २-९७-९
श्रुत्वा प्रव्राजितं मां हि जटावल्कलधारिणम् |
जानक्यासहितं वीर त्वया च पुरुषर्षभ || २-९७-१०
स्नेहेनाक्रान्तहृदयः शिकेनाकुलितेन्द्रियः |
द्रष्टुमभ्यागतो ह्येष भरतो नान्यथऽऽगतः || २-९७-११_END
BEGIN_
"I think Bharata was back to Ayodhya, with full of affection for his brothers. He is
dearer to me than my life- he who is mindful of the duties of his race. Hearing of my exile and
that I was wearing matted locks and the antelope skin, accompanied by Seetha and you, O most
valiant of warriors, in his devotion towards me and due to the distress that troubles his mind,
Bharata has come to see me. He has not come with any other motive."_END

B_2_C_97_9
BEGIN_
अम्बाअं च कैकयीं रुष्य परुषं चाप्रियं वदन् |
प्रसाद्य पितरं स्रीमान् राज्यं मे दातुमागतः || २-९७-१२_END
BEGIN_
"Getting angry with Kaikeyi his mother and speaking unkind and harsh words to her,
the glorious Bharata after getting permission from our further, came here to bestow kingdom to
me."_END

B_2_C_97_10
BEGIN_
प्राप्त कालम् यद् एषो अस्मान् भरतो द्रष्टुम् इग्च्छति |
अस्मासु मनसा अप्य् एष न अहितम् किंचिद् आचरेत् || २-९७-१३_END
BEGIN_
"This is the proper time for Bharata to come here and see us. He does not behave or
even think unkindly towards us."_END

B_2_C_97_11
BEGIN_
विप्रियम् कृत पूर्वम् ते भरतेन कदा न किम् |
ईदृशम् वा भयम् ते अद्य भरतम् यो अत्र शन्कसे || २-९७-१४_END
BEGIN_
"Has Bharata at any time done any harm to you previously? What so the reason for you
to be so apprehensive of Bharata now?"_END

B_2_C_97_12
BEGIN_
न हि ते निष्ठुरम् वाच्यो भरतो न अप्रियम् वचः |
अहम् ह्य् अप्रियम् उक्तः स्याम् भरतस्य अप्रिये कृते || २-९७-१५_END
BEGIN_
"Indeed, Bharata must not hear harsh or disagreeable word from your lips. If an
affront is offered to him, it is offered to me!"_END

B_2_C_97_13
BEGIN_
कथम् नु पुत्राः पितरम् हन्युः कस्यांचिद् आपदि |
भ्राता वा भ्रातरम् हन्यात् सौमित्रे प्राणम् आत्मनः || २-९७-१६_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lakshmana! How should a son strike his father, even in a distress or a brother
strike a brother who is as dear to him as his life?"_END

B_2_C_97_14
BEGIN_
यदि राज्यस्य हेतोः त्वम् इमाम् वाचम् प्रभाषसे |
वक्ष्यामि भरतम् दृष्ट्वा राज्यम् अस्मै प्रदीयताम् || २-९७-१७_END
BEGIN_
"If you are uttering these words for the sake of the kingdom, I shall tell Bharata
to give the kingdom to you, when I see him."_END

B_2_C_97_15
BEGIN_
उच्यमानो हि भरतो मया लक्ष्मण तत्त्वतः |
राज्यम् अस्मै प्रयग्च्छ इति बाढम् इत्य् एव वक्ष्यति || २-९७-१८_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lakshmana! When Bharata receives this command from me, "Cede the empire to him",
he will answer, So, be it."_END

B_2_C_97_16
BEGIN_
तथा उक्तो धर्म शीलेन भ्रात्रा तस्य हिते रतः |
लक्ष्मणः प्रविवेश इव स्वानि गात्राणि लज्जया || २-९७-१९_END
BEGIN_
At these words spoken by his honourable brother, to whom he was devoted, abashed,
shrank into himself._END

B_2_C_97_17
BEGIN_
तद्वाक्यं लक्ष्मणः श्रुत्वा व्रीशितः प्रत्युवाच ह |
त्व मन्ये द्रष्टुमायातः पिता दशरथः स्वयम् || २-९७-२०_END
BEGIN_
Listening to these words ashamed, answered: "I think that our father Dasaratha came
here to see you himself."_END

B_2_C_97_18
BEGIN_
व्रीडितम् लक्ष्मणम् दृष्ट्वा राघवः प्रत्युवाच ह |
एष मन्ये महा बाहुर् इह अस्मान् द्रष्टुम् आगतः || २-९७-२१_END
BEGIN_
Observing the emberassed , Rama said, "I think the mighty armed Dasaratha came here
to see us."_END

B_2_C_97_19
BEGIN_
अथवा नौ ध्रुवं मन्ये मन्यमानः सुखोचितौ |
वन वासम् अनुध्याय गृहाय प्रतिनेष्यति || २-९७-२२_END
BEGIN_
"Or rather, to my mind, as he knows that we have been accustomed to comfort,
reflecting that we are dwelling in the forest, he wishes to take us home."_END

B_2_C_97_20
BEGIN_
इमाम् वा अप्य् एश वैदेहीम् अत्यन्त सुख सेविनीम् |
एतौ तौ सम्प्रकाशेते गोत्रवन्तौ मनो रमौ || २-९७-२३_END
BEGIN_
"The glorious Dasaratha, my father possibly will take back Seetha from the forest,
she who has ever lived in the heart of prosperity."_END

B_2_C_97_21
BEGIN_
एतौ तौ संप्रकाशेते गोत्रवन्तौ मनोरमौ |
वायु वेग समौ वीर जवनौ तुरग उत्तमौ || २-९७-२४_END
BEGIN_
"O, warrior! See those two excellent horses of noble breed, shining attractively and
vying with the wind in swiftness."_END

B_2_C_97_22
BEGIN_
स एष सुमहा कायः कम्पते वाहिनी मुखे |
नागः शत्रुम्जयो नाम वृद्धः तातस्य धीमतः || २-९७-२५_END
BEGIN_
"Here is that colossal elephant who is moving at the head of the army called
Shatrunjaya, the aged companion of our sagacious father."_END

B_2_C_97_23
BEGIN_
न तु पश्यामि तच्छत्रं पाण्डरं लोकसत्कृअम् |
पितुर्दिव्यं महाबाहो संशयो भवतीह मे २-९७-२६_END
BEGIN_
"O, the mighty armed! But I do not see that white heavenly canopy of our father,
well known insignia in the world. An apprehension on this point is created in my mind."_END

B_2_C_97_24
BEGIN_
वृक्षाग्रादवरोह त्वं कुरु लक्ष्म्मण मद्वचः |
इतीव रामो धर्मात्मा सौमित्रिं तमुवाच ह || २-९७-२७_END
BEGIN_
"O, Lakshmana! You get down from the top of the tree. Act on my word." Thus spoke
the virtuous Rama to that Lakshmana._END

B_2_C_97_25
BEGIN_
अवतीर्य तु साल अग्रात् तस्मात् स समितिम् जयः |
लक्ष्मणः प्रान्जलिर् भूत्वा तस्थौ रामस्य पार्श्वतः || २-९७-२८_END
BEGIN_
Descending from the top of that Sala tree, Lakshmana the victorious in battle, with
joined palms, stood by the side of Rama._END

B_2_C_97_26
BEGIN_
भरतेन अथ संदिष्टा सम्मर्दो न भवेद् इति |
समन्तात् तस्य शैलस्य सेना वासम् अकल्पयत् || २-९७-२९_END
BEGIN_
Commanded by Bharata that no trampling of army should be made in the hermitage of
Rama, the army was encamped round the mountain._END

B_2_C_97_27
BEGIN_
अध्यर्धम् इष्क्वाकु चमूर् योजनम् पर्वतस्य सा |
पार्श्वे न्यविशद् आवृत्य गज वाजि रथ आकुला || २-९७-३०_END
BEGIN_
That royal army of Ikshvaku race, crowded with elephants horses and chariots was
encamped around the edge of the mountain occupying an area of one Yojana and a half._END

B_2_C_97_28
BEGIN_
सा चित्र कूटे भरतेन सेना |
धर्मम् पुरः कृत्य विधूय दर्पम् |
प्रसादन अर्थम् रघु नन्दनस्य |
विरोचते नीतिमता प्रणीता || २-९७-३१_END
BEGIN_
Brought by the virtuous Bharata, who laid aside his arrogance, placing the
righteousness in forefront in order to propitiate Rama, that army showed itself to be disciplined
in the vicinity of Chitrakuta._END

B_2_C_98_0
BEGIN_
निवेश्य सेनाम् तु विभुः पद्भ्याम् पादवताम् वरः |
अभिगन्तुम् स काकुत्स्थम् इयेष गुरु वर्तकम् || २-९८-१_END
BEGIN_
After encamping the army, the mighty Bharata the excellent among men, sought to
approach on foot, Rama who was complying with the words of his father._END

B_2_C_98_1
BEGIN_
निविष्ट मात्रे सैन्ये तु यथा उद्देशम् विनीतवत् |
भरतो भ्रातरम् वाक्यम् शत्रुघ्नम् इदम् अब्रवीत् || २-९८-२_END
BEGIN_
Soon after encamping the army in a well-behaved manner per the guidelines, Bharata
spoke the following words to Shatrughna:_END

B_2_C_98_2
BEGIN_
क्षिप्रम् वनम् इदम् सौम्य नर सम्घैः समन्ततः |
लुब्धैः च सहितैर् एभिः त्वम् अन्वेषितुम् अर्हसि || २-९८-३_END
BEGIN_
"O, gentle brother! You, along with a troop of men and trackers, ought to search on
all sides of this forest."_END

B_2_C_98_3
BEGIN_
गुहो ज्ञातिसहस्रेण शरचापासिधारिणा |
समन्वेषतु काकुत्थ्समस्मिन् परिवृतः स्वयम् || २-९८-४_END
BEGIN_
"Let Guha search for Rama and Lakshmana in this forest, himself accompanied by a
multitude of his kinsmen, duly wielding their bows, arrows and swords."_END

B_2_C_98_4
BEGIN_
अमात्यैः सह पौरैश्च गुरुभिश्च द्विजातिभिः |
वनं सर्वं चरिष्यामि पद्भ्यां परिवृतः स्वयम् || २-९८-५_END
BEGIN_
"I too, surrounded by the ministers, citizens, priests and Brahmanas; shall
personally go round the entire forest on foot._END

B_2_C_98_5
BEGIN_
यावन् न रामम् द्रक्ष्यामि लक्ष्मणम् वा महा बलम् |
वैदेहीम् वा महा भागाम् न मे शान्तिर् भविष्यति || २-९८-६_END
BEGIN_
"Peace will not be with me until I do not see Rama or the very mighty Lakshmana or
the illustrious Seetha."_END

B_2_C_98_6
BEGIN_
यावन् न चन्द्र सम्काशम् द्रक्ष्यामि शुभम् आननम् |
भ्रातुः पद्म पलाश अक्षम् न मे शान्तिर् भविष्यति || २-९८-७_END
BEGIN_
"Peace will not be with me until I do not see the auspicious face of my elder
brother, resembling the moon and having eyes bearing resemblance to lotus-leaves._END

B_2_C_98_7
BEGIN_
यावन् न चरणौ भ्रातुः पार्थिव व्यन्जन अन्वितौ |
शिरसा धारयिष्यामि न मे शान्तिर् भविष्यति || २-९८-८_END
BEGIN_
"Peace will nt be with me until I do not hold firmly on my head, the soles of my
elder brother, bearing royal insignia._END

B_2_C_98_8
BEGIN_
यावन् राज्ये राज्य अर्हः पितृ पैतामहे स्थितः |
अभिषेक जल क्लिन्नो न मे शान्तिर् भविष्यति || २-९८-९_END
BEGIN_
"Peace will not come to me until my elder brother, who is eligible for the crown, is
not installed in the kingdom of Ayodhya, which was derived from our father and grand father and
consecrated by sprinkling water on his head (as a symbol of crowing the kingdom)."_END

B_2_C_98_9
BEGIN_
सिद्धार्थः खलु सौमित्रिर्यश्चन्द्रविमलोवमम् |
मुखं पश्यति रामस्य राजीवाक्षं महाद्युति || २-९८-१०_END
BEGIN_
"Lakshmana, who is seeing regularly the face of Rama having a great luminance
resembling the bright moon and having lotus eyes, is indeed an accomplished man."_END

B_2_C_98_10
BEGIN_
कृत कृत्या महा भागा वैदेही जनक आत्मजा |
भर्तारम् सागर अन्तायाः पृथिव्या या अनुगग्च्छति || २-९८-११_END
BEGIN_
"Seetha, the illustrious daughter of Janaka, who is following the steps of Rama the
Lord of the earth extending to the sea, has fulfilled her object."_END

B_2_C_98_11
BEGIN_
सुभगः चित्र कूटो असौ गिरि राज उपमो गिरिः |
यस्मिन् वसति काकुत्स्थः कुबेर इव नन्दने || २-९८-१२_END
BEGIN_
"That enchanting mountain of Chitrakuta resembles the King of Mountains on which
Rama is residing, as Kubera the Lord of riches is living in the garden of Nandana."_END

B_2_C_98_12
BEGIN_
कृत कार्यम् इदम् दुर्गम् वनम् व्याल निषेवितम् |
यद् अध्यास्ते महा तेजा रामः शस्त्रभृताम् वरः || २-९८-१३_END
BEGIN_
"Blessed is this dense forest, inhabited by wild animals, where Rama, the great
warrior and the excellent man among the wielders of weapons, dwells."_END

B_2_C_99_0
BEGIN_
निविष्टायाम् तु सेनायाम् उत्सुको भरतः तदा |
जगाम भ्रातरम् द्रष्टुम् शत्रुघ्नम् अनुदर्शयन् || २-९९-१_END
BEGIN_
Having stationed his forces, Bharata set out eagerly to see his brother, pointing
out the sign of Rama's habitation to Shatrughna._END

B_2_C_99_1
BEGIN_
ऋषिम् वसिष्ठम् संदिश्य मातृऋर् मे शीघ्रम् आनय |
इति तरितम् अग्रे स जागम गुरु वत्सलः || २-९९-२_END
BEGIN_
Bharata, who was affectionate towards the elders, asked the sage Vasishta to bring
his mothers soon thereafter and went ahead quickly._END

B_2_C_99_2
BEGIN_
सुमन्त्रः तु अपि शतुघ्नम् अदूराद् अन्वपद्यत |
राम दार्शनजः तर्षो भरतस्य इव तस्य च || २-९९-३_END
BEGIN_
Sumantra also, equally desirous of seeing Rama; followed Shatrughna at a little
distance._END

B_2_C_99_3
BEGIN_
गग्च्छन्न् एव अथ भरतः तापस आलय संस्थिताम् |
भ्रातुः पर्ण कुटीम् श्रीमान् उटजम् च ददर्श ह || २-९९-४_END
BEGIN_
While the illustrious Bharata passed on, he observed in that wood of ascetics, a
leafy hut of his brother together with a small hut made of leaves, nearby._END

B_2_C_99_4
BEGIN_
शालायाः तु अग्रतः तस्या ददर्श भरतः तदा |
काष्टानि च अवभग्नानि पुष्पाण्य् अवचितानि च || २-९९-५_END
BEGIN_
Bharata then beheld wood that had been broken up and heaps of flowers gathered in
front of that hermitage._END

B_2_C_99_5
BEGIN_
स लक्ष्मणस्य रामस्य ददर्शाश्रममीयुषः |
कृतं वृक्षेष्वभिज्ञानं कुशचीरैः क्वचित् क्वचित् || २-९९-६_END
BEGIN_
While coming to the hermitage, Bharata saw some signs here and there serving as a
proper direction to that hermitage, tufts of Kusha grass and strips of bark tied to the trees by
Rama and Lakshmana._END

B_2_C_99_6
BEGIN_
स ददर्श वने तस्मिन् महतः संचयान् कृतान् |
मृगाणाम् महिषाणाम् च करीषैः शीत कारणात् || २-९९-७_END
BEGIN_
Bharata also saw in the vicinity great heaps of dried dung of deers and buffaloes,
kept ready for protection against cold._END

B_2_C_99_7
BEGIN_
गग्च्छन् एव महा बाहुर् द्युतिमान् भरतः तदा |
शत्रुघ्नम् च अब्रवीद्द् हृष्टः तान् अमात्यामः च सर्वशः || २-९९-८_END
BEGIN_
Then, proceeding further, the valiant and the mighty armed Bharata spoke to
Shatrughna in joy, as also those ministers who surrounded him._END

B_2_C_99_8
BEGIN_
मन्ये प्राप्ताः स्म तम् देशम् भरद्वाजो यम् अब्रवीत् |
न अतिदूरे हि मन्ये अहम् नदीम् मन्दाकिनीम् इतः || २-९९-९_END
BEGIN_
"I think we have reached the place about which Bharadwaja directed us. I believe
Mandakini River is not far from here."_END

B_2_C_99_9
BEGIN_
उच्चैर् बद्धानि चीराणि लक्ष्मणेन भवेद् अयम् |
अभिज्नान कृतः पन्था विकाले गन्तुम् इग्च्छता || २-९९-१०_END
BEGIN_
"These pieces of bark have been tied up from above. This may be the path provided as
signs by Lakshmana in order to find his way back in odd hours of darkness."_END

B_2_C_99_10
BEGIN_
इदम् च उदात्त दन्तानाम् कुन्जराणाम् तरस्विनाम् |
शैल पार्श्वे परिक्रान्तम् अन्योन्यम् अभिगर्जताम् || २-९९-११_END
BEGIN_
"At the side of the mountain, this is a roaming place of elephants, having huge
teeth, violent as they are and ferociously roaring at each other."_END

B_2_C_99_11
BEGIN_
यम् एव आधातुम् इग्च्छन्ति तापसाः सततम् वने |
तस्य असौ दृश्यते धूमः सम्कुलः कृष्ट वर्त्मनः || २-९९-१२_END
BEGIN_
"See this intense smoke coming from that fire which the sages in the forest always
desire to keep in their hermitages."_END

B_2_C_99_12
BEGIN_
अत्र अहम् पुरुष व्याघ्रम् गुरु सत्कार कारिणम् |
आर्यम् द्रक्ष्यामि सम्हृष्टो महर्षिम् इव राघवम् || २-९९-१३_END
BEGIN_
"Here, I can see joyfully Rama, the tiger among men, who gives respect to elders and
is as venerable as a sage."_END

B_2_C_99_13
BEGIN_
अथ गत्वा मुहूर्तम् तु चित्र कूटम् स राघवः |
मन्दाकिनीम् अनुप्राप्तः तम् जनम् च इदम् अब्रवीत् || २-९९-१४_END
BEGIN_
Proceeding for a while on Chitrakuta mountain and reaching the River Mandakini, that
Bharata said to his ministers and others as follows:_END

B_2_C_99_14
BEGIN_
जगत्याम् पुरुष व्याघ्र आस्ते वीर आसने रतः |
जन इन्द्रो निर्जनम् प्राप्य धिन् मे जन्म सजीवितम् || २-९९-१५_END
BEGIN_
"The foremost of men and the Lord of the people, having sought seclusion, sat on the
floor, delighted as he was in the posture of a hero (with his left foot placed on his right knee).
O Fie unto my birth and life!"_END

B_2_C_99_15
BEGIN_
मत् कृते व्यसनम् प्राप्तो लोक नाथो महा द्युतिः |
सर्वान् कामान् परित्यज्य वने वसति राघवः || २-९९-१६_END
BEGIN_
"Rama the Lord of Men with great luster, has been overtaken by this misfortune
because of me and leaving all enjoyments, is living in the forest."_END

B_2_C_99_16
BEGIN_
इति लोक समाक्रुष्टः पादेषु अद्य प्रसादयन् |
रामस्य निपतिष्यामि सीतायाः च पुनः पुनः || २-९९-१७_END
BEGIN_
"Thus abhhored by the world, I will fall on the feet of Rama, Seetha and Lakshmana
and seek to regain Rama's grace."_END

B_2_C_99_17
BEGIN_
एवम् स विलपमः तस्मिन् वने दशरथ आत्मजः |
ददर्श महतीम् पुण्याम् पर्ण शालाम् मनो रमाम् || २-९९-१८
साल ताल अश्व कर्णानाम् पर्णैर् बहुभिर् आवृताम् |
विशालाम् मृदुभिः तीर्णाम् कुशैर् वेदिम् इव अध्वरे || २-९९-१९
शक्र आयुध निकाशैः च कार्मुकैर् भार साधनैः |
रुक्म पृष्ठैर् महा सारैः शोभिताम् शत्रु बाधकैः || २-९९-२०
अर्क रश्मि प्रतीकाशैर् घोरैः तूणी गतैः शरैः |
शोभिताम् दीप्त वदनैः सर्पैर् भोगवतीम् इव || २-९९-२१
महा रजत वासोभ्याम् असिभ्याम् च विराजिताम् |
रुक्म बिन्दु विचित्राभ्याम् चर्मभ्याम् च अपि शोभिताम् || २-९९-२२
गोधा अन्गुलित्रैर् आसाक्तैः चित्रैः कान्चन भूषितैः |
अरि सम्घैर् अनाधृष्याम् मृगैः सिम्ह गुहाम् इव || २-९९-२३_END
BEGIN_
As Bharata was lamenting thus, he beheld in that forest, a splendid and sacred leafy
hut, which was covered with many soft leaves of Sala, Tala and Asvakarna trees, overspread with
blades of Kusa grass in a sacrificial performance, appearing like an extensive altar and it was
adorned with bows plated with gold, like unto the weapons of Indra the Lord of celestials,
constructed for heroic exploits, having great power, the torments of their foes, graced with
fearful arrows in their quivers, like unto the rays of the sun, bright as serpents with shining
hoods, in the same way of Bhagavati (the realm of Nagas), decked with a couple of swords encased in
sheaths of gold, adorned with two shields decorated with flowers of gold, finger-guards embroidered
with gold and in different colours suspended on walls and which hut was unassailable by hordes of
enemies as is a lion's cave to deer._END

B_2_C_99_18
BEGIN_
प्राग् उदक् स्रवणाम् वेदिम् विशालाम् दीप्त पावकाम् |
ददर्श भरतः तत्र पुण्याम् राम निवेशने || २-९९-२४_END
BEGIN_
Bharata saw a sacrificial altar in the north-east corner having a steep descent,
extensive in area and having a sacred fire burned in the hermitage of Rama._END

B_2_C_99_19
BEGIN_
निरीक्ष्य स मुहूर्तम् तु ददर्श भरतो गुरुम् |
उटजे रामम् आसीनाम् जटा मण्डल धारिणम् || २-९९-२५_END
BEGIN_
Looking around for a moment, Bharata beheld his elder brother, Rama himself seated
in the hut, wearing matted locks._END

B_2_C_99_20
BEGIN_
तम् तु कृष्ण अजिन धरम् चीर वल्कल वाससम् |
ददर्श रामम् आसीनम् अभितः पावक उपमम् || २-९९-२६
सिम्ह स्कन्धम् महा बाहुम् पुण्डरीक निभ ईक्षणम् |
पृथिव्याः सगर अन्ताया भर्तारम् धर्म चारिणम् || २-९९-२७
उपविष्टम् महा बाहुम् ब्रह्माणम् इव शाश्वतम् |
स्थण्डिले दर्भ सस्म्तीर्णे सीतया लक्ष्मणेन च || २-९९-२८_END
BEGIN_
Bharata saw that Rama clad in an antelope-skin and robes of bark, seated close by,
resembling a fire (in brilliance), with the neck and shoulders of a lion, mighty arms and eyes
resembling the lotus, the very virtuous Lord of the Earth extending upto the ocean, the Eternal
Brahma, and seated on the ground spread with Darbha grass, with Seetha and Lakshmana._END

B_2_C_99_21
BEGIN_
तम् दृष्ट्वा भरतः श्रीमान् दुह्ख मोह परिप्लुतः |
अभ्यधावत धर्म आत्मा भरतः कैकयी सुतः || २-९९-२९_END
BEGIN_
Beholding him, the illustrious and the high-souled Bharata the son of Kaikeyim
distraught by the grief that possessed him, rushed towards Rama._END

B_2_C_99_22
BEGIN_
दृष्ट्वा च विललाप आर्तो बाष्प संदिग्धया गिरा |
अशक्नुवन् धारयितुम् धैर्याद् वचनम् अब्रवीत् || २-९९-३०_END
BEGIN_
On seeing his brother, Bharata broke into lamentations and in a voice strangled with sobs, unable to restrain his agony with firmeness, said:_END

B_2_C_99_23
BEGIN_
यः संसदि प्रकृतिभिर् भवेद् युक्त उपासितुम् |
वन्यैर् मृगैर् उपासीनः सो अयम् आस्ते मम अग्रजः || २-९९-३१_END
BEGIN_
"My elder brother who is fit to be honoured in an assembly by a body of ministers
around him, is now being served by a body of wild beasts around him in this jungle."_END

B_2_C_99_24
BEGIN_
वासोभिर् बहु साहस्रैर् यो महात्मा पुर उचितः |
मृग अजिने सो अयम् इह प्रवस्ते धर्मम् आचरन् || २-९९-३२_END
BEGIN_
"That magnanimous hero, who formerly used to possess countless articles of apparel
is now wearing two antelope-skins, following ascetic righteousness._END

B_2_C_99_25
BEGIN_
अधारयद् यो विविधाः चित्राः सुमनसः तदा |
सो अयम् जटा भारम् इमम् सहते राघवः कथम् || २-९९-३३_END
BEGIN_
"How this Rama, who used to wear various kinds of colourful flowers, is bearing this
burden of matted locks now?"_END

B_2_C_99_26
BEGIN_
यस्य यज्नैर् यथा आदिष्टैर् युक्तो धर्मस्य संचयः |
शरीर क्लेश सम्भूतम् स धर्मम् परिमार्गते || २-९९-३४_END
BEGIN_
"He who acquired merit through countless sacrifices performed according to the
prescribed injunctions, now follows the path of righteousness through asceticism!"_END

B_2_C_99_27
BEGIN_
चन्दनेन महा अर्हेण यस्य अन्गम् उपसेवितम् |
मलेन तस्य अन्गम् इदम् कथम् आर्यस्य सेव्यते || २-९९-३५_END
BEGIN_
"He whose body was formerly rendered fragrant by white sandal paste, has only dust
with which to smear the limbs of this venerable elder brother!"_END

B_2_C_99_28
BEGIN_
मन् निमित्तम् इदम् दुह्खम् प्राप्तो रामः सुख उचितः |
धिग् जीवितम् नृशंसस्य मम लोक विगर्हितम् || २-९९-३६_END
BEGIN_
"Rama who used to have happiness, has fallen into this misfortune, because of me
cursed be my reprehensive existence that the whole world condemns!"_END

B_2_C_99_29
BEGIN_
इत्य् एवम् विलपन् दीनः प्रस्विन्न मुख पन्कजः |
पादाउ अप्राप्य रामस्य पपात भरतो रुदन् || २-९९-३७_END
BEGIN_
Thus did that pitiable Bharata lament, perspiration be-dewing his lotus-like
countenance and, without touching Rama's feet, fell down grooming._END

B_2_C_99_30
BEGIN_
दुह्ख अभितप्तो भरतो राज पुत्रो महा बलः |
उक्त्वा आर्य इति सकृद् दीनम् पुनर् न उवाच किंचन || २-९९-३८_END
BEGIN_
Overcome with grief, the highly valiant prince Bharata cried out "O, Noble One!"
once and in his distress, was unable to speak anything further._END

B_2_C_99_31
BEGIN_
बाष्प अपिहित कण्ठः च प्रेक्ष्य रामम् यशस्विनम् |
आर्य इत्य् एव अभिसम्क्रुश्य व्याहर्तुम् न अशकत् ततः || २-९९-३९_END
BEGIN_
Crying at the top of his voice, "O, Noble One" only, on seeing the illustrious Rama,
he was unable to speak further, his throat choked with tears._END

B_2_C_99_32
BEGIN_
शत्रुघ्नः च अपि रामस्य ववन्दे चरणौ रुदन् |
ताउ उभौ स समालिन्ग्य रामो अप्य् अश्रूण्य् अवर्तयत् || २-९९-४०_END
BEGIN_
Shatrughna too, weeping, threw himself at Rama's feet and Rama too, embracing them
both, allowed his tears to fall._END

B_2_C_99_33
BEGIN_
ततः सुमन्त्रेण गुहेन चैव |
समीयतू राज सुताउ अरण्ये |
दिवा करः चैव निशा करः च |
यथा अम्बरे शुक्र बृहस्पतिभ्याम् || २-९९-४१_END
BEGIN_
Then, in that forest, the princes Rama and Lakshmana were seen by Sumantra and Guha,
as in the sky, the sun and the moon are seen in conjunction with Venus and Jupiter._END

B_2_C_99_34
BEGIN_
तान् पार्थिवान् वारण यूथप आभान् |
समागतामः तत्र महत्य् अरण्ये |
वन ओकसः ते अपि समीक्ष्य सर्वे अप्य् |
अश्रूण्य् अमुन्चन् प्रविहाय हर्षम् || २-९९-४२_END
BEGIN_
All those dwellers in the woods, seeing those princes resembling leaders of
elephant-herbs meeting together there in that great forest, losing their cheerfulness, began to
shed tears._END

B_2_C_100_0
BEGIN_
जटिलं चीरवसनं प्राञ्जलिं पतितं भुवि |
ददर्श रामो दुर्दर्शं युगान्ते भास्करं यथा || २-१००-१_END
BEGIN_
Rama saw Bharata, with matted locks, wearing bark-robes and, with joined palms,
lying on the ground, incapable of being seen as the sun at the time of the dissolution of the
world._END

B_2_C_100_1
BEGIN_
कथं चिदभिविज्ञाय विवर्णवदनं कृशम् |
भ्रातरं भरतं रामः परिजग्राह बाहुना || २-१००-२_END
BEGIN_
Rama recognized with some difficulty his brother Bharata, whose face became pale and
who was emaciated, and took him by the arm._END

B_2_C_100_2
BEGIN_
आघ्राय रामः तम् मूर्ध्नि परिष्वज्य च राघवः |
अन्के भरतम् आरोप्य पर्यपृग्च्छत् समाहितः || २-१००-३_END
BEGIN_
Smelling the crown of his head, placing him on his lap, Rama who was born in Raghu
dynasty embraced Bharata and with an absorbent mind, enquired of him as follows:_END

B_2_C_100_3
BEGIN_
क्व नु ते अभूत् पिता तात यद् अरण्यम् त्वम् आगतः |
न हि त्वम् जीवतः तस्य वनम् आगन्तुम् अर्हसि || २-१००-४_END
BEGIN_
"My darling! Where is our father, that you have come to the forest? He, being alive,
you ought not have to come to the forest."_END

B_2_C_100_4
BEGIN_
चिरस्य बत पश्यामि दूराद् भरतम् आगतम् |
दुष्प्रतीकम् अरण्ये अस्मिन् किम् तात वनम् आगतः || २-१००-५_END
BEGIN_
"I see you after a long time, coming from a far-off distance, wearing a mournful
face into this forest Alas! Why have you come to the forest, my darling?"_END

B_2_C_100_5
BEGIN_
कच्चिद्धारयए तात राजा यत्त्वमिहागतः |
कच्चिन्न दीनः सहसा राजा लोकान्तरं गतः || २-१००-६_END
BEGIN_
"My dear brother! Is the king alive, that you have come here? I hope the miserable
king has not indeed departed to the other world, all of a sudden."_END

B_2_C_100_6
BEGIN_
कच्चित्सौम्य नते राज्यं भ्रष्ठं बालस्य शाश्वतम् |
कच्चिछुश्रूषसे तात पितरं सत्यविक्रमम् || २-१००-७_END
BEGIN_
"O, gentle brother! I hope the eternal kingdom has in a no way suffered from your
youthful experience. My darling! Are you rendering service to our father, who is truly
valiant?"_END

B_2_C_100_7
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् दशरथो राजा कुशली सत्य सम्गरः |
राज सूय अश्व मेधानाम् आहर्ता धर्म निश्चयः || २-१००-८_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that the King Dasaratha is well, he who is true to his promise, he who
performs Rajasuya and Ashvamedha Sacrifices and he who has a righteous resolve."_END

B_2_C_100_8
BEGIN_
स कच्चिद् ब्राह्मणो विद्वान् धर्म नित्यो महा द्युतिः |
इक्ष्वाकूणाम् उपाध्यायो यथावत् तात पूज्यते || २-१००-९_END
BEGIN_
"My darling! Are you treating respectfully as before that preceptor of the
Ikshvakus, the one who knows the sacred scriptures, the one who knows the sacred scriptures, the
learned who constantly keep up the virtues and he who has a great splendour?"_END

B_2_C_100_9
BEGIN_
सा तात कच्चिच् च कौसल्या सुमित्रा च प्रजावती |
सुखिनी कच्चिद् आर्या च देवी नन्दति कैकयी || २-१००-१०_END
BEGIN_
"My darling! I hope that Kausalya and Sumitra having good offspring are happy. I
hope the venerable queen Kaikeyi is rejoicing."_END

B_2_C_100_10
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् विनय सम्पन्नः कुल पुत्रो बहु श्रुतः |
अनसूयुर् अनुद्रष्टा सत्कृतः ते पुरोहितः || २-१००-११_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that the preceptor (Suyajgna the son of Vasishta); who is rich in humility,
a son of a noble family, who has a knowledge of many scriptures an unenvious person and who is full
of insight, is duly honoured by you."_END

B_2_C_100_11
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् अग्निषु ते युक्तो विधिज्नो मतिमान् ऋजुः |
हुतम् च होष्यमाणम् च काले वेदयते सदा || २-१००-१२_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that a brahmin who is versed in the traditions, who is intelligent and just,
employed in your sacred fires, always informs you in time, about a sacrificial fire having been or
going to be fed with oblations."_END

B_2_C_100_12
BEGIN_
कच्चिद्देवान् पित्ऱ्^ऊन् भृत्वान्गुरून् पितृसमानपि |
वृद्धांश्च तात वैद्यांश्च ब्राह्मणांश्चाभिमन्यसे || २-१००-१३_END
BEGIN_
"My darling! I hope that you are holding in high esteem the gods, your ancestors,
dependents and teachers of your father's age the doctors and the brahmins."_END

B_2_C_100_13
BEGIN_
इषु अस्त्र वर सम्पन्नम् अर्थ शास्त्र विशारदम् |
सुधन्वानम् उपाध्यायम् कच्चित् त्वम् तात मन्यसे || २-१००-१४_END
BEGIN_
"O, my darling! I hope that you treat with due respect; Sudhanva, your teacher in
archery, who is furnished with the most excellent arrows and darts and well-versed in political
economy."_END

B_2_C_100_14
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् आत्म समाः शूराः श्रुतवन्तो जित इन्द्रियाः |
कुलीनाः च इन्गितज्नाः च कृताः ते तात मन्त्रिणः || २-१००-१५_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that ministers who are valiant like you, learned, masters of their senses of
noble birth and skilled interpreting internal sentiments by external gesture, are assigned to
you."_END

B_2_C_100_15
BEGIN_
मन्त्रो विजय मूलम् हि राज्नाम् भवति राघव |
सुसम्वृतो मन्त्र धरैर् अमात्यैः शास्त्र कोविदैः || २-१००-१६_END
BEGIN_
"The source of victory for kings indeed comes from a concealed counsel by ministers,
who are well-versed in political sciences and who can hide their thoughts within themselves."_END

B_2_C_100_16
BEGIN_
कच्चिन् निद्रा वशम् न एषि कच्चित् काले विबुध्यसे |
कच्चिन् च अपर रात्रिषु चिन्तयस्य् अर्थ नैपुणम् || २-१००-१७_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you do not fall a prey to excess of sleep and do wake up at appropriate
time. I hope you contemplate during the later half of the night, about the adroitness of an
action."_END

B_2_C_100_17
BEGIN_
कच्चिन् मन्त्रयसे न एकः कच्चिन् न बहुभिः सह |
कच्चित् ते मन्त्रितो मन्त्रो राष्ट्रम् न परिधावति || २-१००-१८_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that you do not deliberate alone nor indeed with numerous men. I hope your
decision arrived at by you through such deliberation does not flow to the public (even before it is
carried out)"._END

B_2_C_100_18
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् अर्थम् विनिश्चित्य लघु मूलम् महा उदयम् |
क्षिप्रम् आरभसे कर्तुम् न दीर्घयसि राघव || २-१००-१९_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata! I hope considering your interest fully, you lanuch an undertaking,
which has maximum benefit with minimum coast and indeed do not delay it further."_END

B_2_C_100_19
BEGIN_
कच्चित् तु सुकृतान्य् एव कृत रूपाणि वा पुनः |
विदुः ते सर्व कार्याणि न कर्तव्यानि पार्थिवाः || २-१००-२०_END
BEGIN_
"I hope the other kings know your entire undertakings only after they have been
successfully completed as well as those which have taken a shape, but not your proposed
undertakings."_END

B_2_C_100_20
BEGIN_
कच्चिन् न तर्कैर् युक्त्वा वा ये च अप्य् अपरिकीर्तिताः |
त्वया वा तव वा अमात्यैर् बुध्यते तात मन्त्रितम् || २-१००-२१_END
BEGIN_
"My darling! I hope that others are not knowing, by their enquiries or strategies or
by any other approaches not mentioned, the details of discussions you make with your
ministers."_END

B_2_C_100_21
BEGIN_
कच्चित् सहस्रान् मूर्खाणाम् एकम् इग्च्छसि पण्डितम् |
पण्डितो ह्य् अर्थ कृग्च्छ्रेषु कुर्यान् निह्श्रेयसम् महत् || २-१००-२२_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you solicit for one wise man rather than for a thousand stupids for, a wise
man can be of a great help to you in difficult matters."_END

B_2_C_100_22
BEGIN_
सहस्राण्य् अपि मूर्खाणाम् यद्य् उपास्ते मही पतिः |
अथ वा अप्य् अयुतान्य् एव न अस्ति तेषु सहायता || २-१००-२३_END
BEGIN_
"Even if a king employs thousands or tens of thousands of fools, they will not be
helpful to him."_END

B_2_C_100_23
BEGIN_
एको अप्य् अमात्यो मेधावी शूरो दक्षो विचक्षणः |
राजानम् राज मात्रम् वा प्रापयेन् महतीम् श्रियम् || २-१००-२४_END
BEGIN_
"Even one wise, valiant sagacious and efficient minister alone can cause to secure a
great prosperity to the king or to one who enjoys royal authority."_END

B_2_C_100_24
BEGIN_
कच्चिन् मुख्या महत्सु एव मध्यमेषु च मध्यमाः |
जघन्याः च जघन्येषु भृत्याः कर्मसु योजिताः || २-१००-२५_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that superior servants are assigned superior works only, mediocre servants
in mediocre works and inferior servants in inferior works."_END

B_2_C_100_25
BEGIN_
अमात्यान् उपधा अतीतान् पितृ पैतामहान् शुचीन् |
श्रेष्ठान् श्रेष्ठेषु कच्चित् त्वम् नियोजयसि कर्मसु || २-१००-२६_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you are appointing those ministers, who are eminent incorruptible, born of
the fathers and for bears of good family and who are full of integrity in matters of great
importance."_END

B_2_C_100_26
BEGIN_
कच्चिन्नोग्रेण दण्डेन भृशमुद्वेजितप्रजम् |
राज्यं तवानुजानन्ति मन्त्रिणः कैकयीसुत || २-१००-२७_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata! I hope your ministers do not watch as mere witnesses, while your
subjects in the kingdom wielding tremble with great fear, under your inflexible wielding of the
scepter."_END

B_2_C_100_27
BEGIN_
कच्चित् त्वाम् न अवजानन्ति याजकाः पतितम् यथा |
उग्र प्रतिग्रहीतारम् कामयानम् इव स्त्रियः || २-१००-२८_END
BEGIN_
"I hope those who perform the sacrifice do not hold you in contempt, as one who
accepts terrible gifts; as one who is fallen, as women hold in contempt of those highly lustful
men."_END

B_2_C_100_28
BEGIN_
उपाय कुशलम् वैद्यम् भृत्य संदूषणे रतम् |
शूरम् ऐश्वर्य कामम् च यो न हन्ति स वध्यते || २-१००-२९_END
BEGIN_
"He, who does not slay a physician skilled in ways and means of aggravating a
disease, a servant intent on bringing disgrace and a valiant warrior seeking kingly power, is
*himself) slain by them."_END

B_2_C_100_29
BEGIN_
कच्चिद्द् हृष्टः च शूरः च धृतिमान् मतिमान् शुचिः |
कुलीनः च अनुरक्तः च दक्षः सेना पतिः कृतः || २-१००-३०_END
BEGIN_
"I hope an army-chief, who is cheerful, wise, courageous, valiant, well-behaved,
born in a good family, who is beloved by his subordinates and efficient, is selected by you."_END

B_2_C_100_30
BEGIN_
बलवन्तः च कच्चित् ते मुख्या युद्ध विशारदाः |
दृष्ट अपदाना विक्रान्ताः त्वया सत्कृत्य मानिताः || २-१००-३१_END
BEGIN_
"I hope those warriors, who are excellent strong, skilled in war-face, whose
excellent actions were seen before and the most courageous ones are duly honoured and respected by
you."_END

B_2_C_100_31
BEGIN_
कचिद् बलस्य भक्तम् च वेतनम् च यथा उचितम् |
सम्प्राप्त कालम् दातव्यम् ददासि न विलम्बसे || २-१००-३२_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you are regularly giving your army, the daily provisions and the suitable
salary to them, without any delay."_END

B_2_C_100_32
BEGIN_
काल अतिक्रमणे ह्य् एव भक्त वेतनयोर् भृताः |
भर्तुः कुप्यन्ति दुष्यन्ति सो अनर्थः सुमहान् स्मृतः || २-१००-३३_END
BEGIN_
"When there is delay in giving bread and wages, the servants become incensed against
their master and become corrupt; and that is said to be a great unfortunate occurrence."_END

B_2_C_100_33
BEGIN_
कच्चित् सर्वे अनुरक्ताः त्वाम् कुल पुत्राः प्रधानतः |
कच्चित् प्राणामः तव अर्थेषु सम्त्यजन्ति समाहिताः || २-१००-३४_END
BEGIN_
"I hope all the foremost descendents of your race (kshatriyas) are devoted to you
and do they lay down their lives steadfastly for your sake?"_END

B_2_C_100_34
BEGIN_
कच्चिज् जानपदो विद्वान् दक्षिणः प्रतिभानवान् |
यथा उक्त वादी दूतः ते कृतो भरत पण्डितः || २-१००-३५_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that a knowledgeable man, living in your own country, a wise man a skilled
person endowed with presence of mind and the one who knows how to speak to the point, is selected
as an ambassador by you."_END

B_2_C_100_35
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् अष्टादशान्य् एषु स्व पक्षे दश पन्च च |
त्रिभिः त्रिभिर् अविज्नातैर् वेत्सि तीर्थानि चारकैः || २-१००-३६_END
BEGIN_
"Do you get to know throught three spies, each unacquainted with each other, about
the eighteen* functionaries of the enemies and the fifteen functionaries of your own side?"_END

B_2_C_100_36
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् व्यपास्तान् अहितान् प्रतियातामः च सर्वदा |
दुर्बलान् अनवज्नाय वर्तसे रिपु सूदन || २-१००-३७_END
BEGIN_
"O, slayer of your Foes! I hope you do not forever think lightly of your foes, who
are weak and having been expelled, return again."_END

B_2_C_100_37
BEGIN_
कच्चिन् न लोकायतिकान् ब्राह्मणामः तात सेवसे |
अनर्थ कुशला ह्य् एते बालाः पण्डित मानिनः || २-१००-३८_END
BEGIN_
I hope are not honouring the materialistic brahmins, My dear brother! These men are
skilled in perverting the mind, ignorant as they are and thinking themselves to be learned."_END

B_2_C_100_38
BEGIN_
धर्म शास्त्रेषु मुख्येषु विद्यमानेषु दुर्बुधाः |
बुद्धिमान् वीक्षिकीम् प्राप्य निरर्थम् प्रवदन्ति ते || २-१००-३९_END
BEGIN_
"Reaching to their logical acumen, these men of perverted intellect preach
meaninglessly, in the presence of eminent books on righteousness."_END

B_2_C_100_39
BEGIN_
वीरैर् अध्युषिताम् पूर्वम् अस्माकम् तात पूर्वकैः |
सत्य नामाम् दृढ द्वाराम् हस्त्य् अश्व रथ सम्कुलाम् || २-१००-४०
ब्राह्मणैः क्षत्रियैर् वैश्यैः स्व कर्म निरतैः सदा |
जित इन्द्रियैर् महा उत्साहैर् वृत अमात्यैः सहस्रशः || २-१००-४१
प्रासादैर् विविध आकारैर् वृताम् वैद्य जन आकुलाम् |
कच्चित् समुदिताम् स्फीताम् अयोध्याम् परिरक्षसि || २-१००-४२_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you preserve the City of Ayodhya, furnished with everything and flourishing,
that was formerly inhabited by our heroic ancestors, O my dear brother, that is worthy of its name,
with its fortified gates, its elephant horses and chariots that fill it, with its brahmins,
warriors and merchants in thousands, ever engaged in their respective duties, with its noble
citizens self-controlled and full of energy, with its palaces in various shapes and the learned who
abound there."_END

B_2_C_100_40
BEGIN_
कच्चिच् चैत्य शतैर् जुष्टः सुनिविष्ट जन आकुलः |
देव स्थानैः प्रपाभिः च तडागैः च उपशोभितः || २-१००-४३
प्रहृष्ट नर नारीकः समाज उत्सव शोभितः |
सुकृष्ट सीमा पशुमान् हिंसाभिर् अभिवर्जितः || २-१००-४४
अदेव मातृको रम्यः श्वा पदैः परिवर्जितः |
परित्यक्तो भयैः सर्वैः खनिभिश्चोपशोभितः २-१००-४५
विवर्जितो नरैः पापैर्मम पूर्वैः सुरक्षितः |
कच्चिज् जन पदः स्फीतः सुखम् वसति राघव || २-१००-४६_END
BEGIN_
I hope that the kingdom, adorned with peaceful places rich in temples and sheds
where water stored for distribution to passers-by in tanks, with happy men and women, graced by
social festivities, with land well-tilled, abiding in cattle which are totally free from cruelties,
the agricultural land not exclusively fed by rains, which is beautiful and is purged of beasts of
prey, which is completely rid of fears, studded with mines, a destitute of sinful men, and
well-protected by our fore-fathers, is prosperous and an abode of happiness._END

B_2_C_100_41
BEGIN_
कच्चित् ते दयिताः सर्वे कृषि गो रक्ष जीविनः |
वार्तायाम् संश्रितः तात लोको हि सुखम् एधते || २-१००-४७_END
BEGIN_
"Are you cherishing all those who live by agriculture and cattle-rearing, O, dear
borhter! The people living on agriculture and cattle-rearing indeed prosper well."_END

B_2_C_100_42
BEGIN_
तेषाम् गुप्ति परीहारैः कच्चित् ते भरणम् कृतम् |
रक्ष्या हि राज्ना धर्मेण सर्वे विषय वासिनः || २-१००-४८_END
BEGIN_
"I hope their maintenance is being looked after by you, in providing what they need
and eschewing what they fear. All the citizens are indeed to be protected by a king through his
righteousness."_END

B_2_C_100_43
BEGIN_
कच्चित् स्त्रियः सान्त्वयसि कच्चित् ताः च सुरक्षिताः |
कच्चिन् न श्रद्दधास्य आसाम् कच्चिद् गुह्यम् न भाषसे || २-१००-४९_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you are pacifying the women well. Are they protected by you? I hope you are
not believing the words of these women and not telling them the secrets."_END

B_2_C_100_44
BEGIN_
कच्चिन्नागवनं गुप्तं कच्चित्ते सन्ति धेनुकाः |
कचिन्न गणिकाश्वानां कुञ्जराणां च तृप्यसि || २-१००-५०_END
BEGIN_
"Are you supervising the woods inhabited by elephants? I hope female elephants are
there to you in good number. I hope you are not simply satisfied with the existing population of
female elephants, horses and male-elephants."_END

B_2_C_100_45
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् दर्शयसे नित्यम् मनुष्याणाम् विभूषितम् |
उत्थाय उत्थाय पूर्व अह्णे राज पुत्रो महा पथे || २-१००-५१_END
BEGIN_
"O, Prince! Do you, regally adorned, appear before the people on rising each
morning, on the great high way?"_END

B_2_C_100_46
BEGIN_
कच्चिन्न सर्वे कर्मान्ताः प्रत्यक्षास्तेऽविशङ्कया |
सर्वे वा पुनरुत्सृष्टा मध्यमे वात्र कारणम् २-१००-५२_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that all your servants, in your presence, do not adopt a disrespectful
attitude or on the other hand all of them do not hasten away on seeing you. Ofcourse, a middle
course only in the principle to be followed in this matter."_END

B_2_C_100_47
BEGIN_
कच्चित् सर्वाणि दुर्गाणि धन धान्य आयुध उदकैः |
यन्त्रैः च परिपूर्णानि तथा शिल्पि धनुर् धरैः || २-१००-५३_END
BEGIN_
"I hope all your citadels are quite full of money, grain, weapons, water and
mechanical contrivances as well as artisans and archers."_END

B_2_C_100_48
BEGIN_
आयः ते विपुलः कच्चित् कच्चिद् अल्पतरो व्ययः |
अपात्रेषु न ते कच्चित् कोशो गग्च्छति राघव || २-१००-५४_END
BEGIN_
"I hope your income is abundant and expenditure, minimum. I hope your treasure does
not reach undeserving people, O, Bharata!"_END

B_2_C_100_49
BEGIN_
देवता अर्थे च पित्र् अर्थे ब्राह्मण अभ्यागतेषु च |
योधेषु मित्र वर्गेषु कच्चिद् गग्च्छति ते व्ययः || २-१००-५५_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that your expenditure goes for the cause of divinity, manes, brahmins,
unexpected visitors, soldiers and hosts of friends."_END

B_2_C_100_50
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् आर्यो विशुद्ध आत्मा क्षारितः चोर कर्मणा |
अपृष्टः शास्त्र कुशलैर् न लोभाद् बध्यते शुचिः || २-१००-५६_END
BEGIN_
"If one of noble work, despite his honesty and integrity, is falsely accused of some
offence, I hope he is not killed impatiently, without enquiry by those well-versed in
law-books."_END

B_2_C_100_51
BEGIN_
गृहीतः चैव पृष्टः च काले दृष्टः सकारणः |
कच्चिन् न मुच्यते चोरो धन लोभान् नर ऋषभ || २-१००-५७_END
BEGIN_
"O, foremost of men! If a thief is seen and even caught at the time of his act on
sufficient ground and interrogated-I hope, he is not released from greed of wealth."_END

B_2_C_100_52
BEGIN_
व्यसने कच्चिद् आढ्यस्य दुगतस्य च राघव |
अर्थम् विरागाः पश्यन्ति तव अमात्या बहु श्रुताः || २-१००-५८_END
BEGIN_
"O, Bharata! I hope that your well-educated ministers examine a case dispassionately
when a contention occurs between a rich man and a poor man, after studying the situation
carefully."_END

B_2_C_100_53
BEGIN_
यानि मिथ्या अभिशस्तानाम् पतन्त्य् अस्राणि राघव |
तानि पुत्र पशून् घ्नन्ति प्रीत्य् अर्थम् अनुशासतः || २-१००-५९_END
BEGIN_
"The tears fallen from those who are the victims of false accusations, O Bharata,
destroy their sons and herds of those who are indifferent to justice, merely for the sake of
pleasure."_END

B_2_C_100_54
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् वृधामः च बालामः च वैद्य मुख्यामः च राघव |
दानेन मनसा वाचा त्रिभिर् एतैर् बुभूषसे || २-१००-६०_END
BEGIN_
"I hope that you seek to conciliate by the following three means, viz. gifts, a
loving mind and polite words- the aged, the children and the foremost physicians."_END

B_2_C_100_55
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् गुरूमः च वृद्धामः च तापसान् देवता अतिथीन् |
चैत्यामः च सर्वान् सिद्ध अर्थान् ब्राह्मणामः च नमस्यसि || २-१००-६१_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you greet your teachers, the elderly, the ascetics, the deities; the
unexpected visitors, the trees standing at cross roads and all the brahmins of auspicious life and
conduct."_END

B_2_C_100_56
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् अर्थेन वा धर्मम् धर्मम् धर्मेण वा पुनः |
उभौ वा प्रीति लोभेन कामेन न विबाधसे || २-१००-६२_END
BEGIN_
"I hope you do not abrogate virtue by your excessive devotion to wealth or your
excessive devotion to wealth or your earthly interests by your over-emphasis on religion or both
your religious and secular interests by your self-indulgence in pleasure, greed and gratification
of the senses."_END

B_2_C_100_57
BEGIN_
कच्चिद् अर्थम् च धर्मम् च कामम् च जयताम् वर |
